Row(id=5597, title=u'Politics of Cyprus', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\nThe Rep of Cyprus is a ry state presidential system representative democracy, whereby the President of Cyprus is both head of state and head of government. Exec power is exercised by the government. Legislative power is vested in both the Forms of government and the House of Representatives of Cyprus. The Jary is independent of the exec and the legislature.\n\nCyprus has been a divided island since 1974 when T invaded the north in response to a military coup on the island which was backed by the Athens government.  Since then, the internationally recognized Rep of Cyprus has controlled the south two-thirds, and the Th Rep of Northern Cyprus, only recognized by T, the northern one-third. The Government of the Rep of Cyprus has continued as the sole internationally recognized aity on the island (as well as the United Kingdom being internationally recognized with respect to the Sovereign Base Areas), though in practice its power extends only to the government-controlled area.\n\nCyprus operates  a m-party system, with comm Progressive Party of Working People and right-leaning Democratic Rally in the forefront. Centrist Democratic Party (Cyprus) and lesser parties often form a political coalition with the Presidents party and are allotted a n of ministries.\n\n\nThe 1960 Cypriot Constit provided for a presidential system of government with separation of powers exec (government), legislative, and jal branches, as well as a complex system of checks and balances incl a weighted power-sharing ratio designed to protect the interests of the Th Cypriots. The exec, for example, was headed by a Greek Cypriot president, Archbishop Makarios III, and a Th Cypriot vice president, Fazil K|Dr Faz\u0131l K\xfc\xe7\xfck, elected by their respective commes for 5-year terms and each possessing a right of veto over certain types of legislation and exec decisions.\n\nThe House of Representatives was elected on the basis of separate voters rolls. Since 1964, following clashes between the two commes, the Th Cypriot seats in the House remained vacant, while the Greek Cypriot Comm Chambers was abolished. The responsibilities of the chamber were transferred to the newfo Ministry of Edon.\n\nBy 1967, when a Greek military j of 1967-1974 had seized power in Greece, the political impetus for enosis had faded, partly as a result of the non-aligned foreign policy of Cypriot President Makarios. Enosis remained an ideological goal, despite being p significantly fr down the political agenda. Dissatisfaction in Greece with Makarios convinced the Greek colonels to sponsor the 1974 coup in Nicosia.\n\nT responded by lang a military operation on Cyprus in a move not approved by the other two international gtor powers, Greece and the United Kingdom, claiming that this was for the protection of the Th minority from Greek militias. The invasion is called "Cyprus Peace Operation" by the Th side. Th forces capt the northern part of the island. Many thos of others, from both sides, left the island entirely. In addition to many of the Greek Cypriot ref (a third of the popon), many Th Cypriots also moved to the UK.\n\nSy, the Th Cypriots established their own separatist instits with a popy elected de facto President and a Prime Minister responsible to the National Assembly exercising joint exec powers. In 1983, the Th Cypriots declared an independent state called the Th Rep of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), an action opposed by the United Nations Sec Co. In 1985, the TRNC adopted a constit and held its first elections.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1974, following a coup sponsored by the Greek military j of 1967-1974 and exec by the Cypriot National G the Th invasion of Cyprus (citing its aity as one of the three gtor powers established by the Constit), the Th Cypriots formally set up their own instits with a popy elected president and a prime minister, responsible to the National Assembly, exercising joint exec powers.  Cyprus has been divided, de facto, into the Greek Cypriot controlled son two-thirds of the island and the Th-occ northern third.  The Rep of Cyprus is the internationally recognised government of the Rep of Cyprus, that controls the son two-thirds of the island. Aside from T, all foreign governments and the United Nations recognise the sovereignty of the Rep of Cyprus over the whole island of Cyprus.\n\nT, which does not recognise the Rep of Cyprus, and the Th Cypriot administration of the northern part of the island, do not accept the Reps rule over the whole island and refer to it not by its international name, but as the "Greek Cypriot Administration of Son Cyprus". Its territory, a result of the Th invasion of 1974 and whose status remains disp, extends over the northern third of the island.\n\nThe north proclaimed its independence in 1975. In 1983, the Th Cypriots declared an independent "Th Rep of Northern Cyprus", which has never been non-recognized nations except T.  In 1985, they adopted a constit and held elections\u2014an arrangement recognized only by T.  For information pertaining to this, see Politics of the Th Rep of Northern Cyprus. The Organisation of the Islamic Conference (now the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation) granted it observer member status  the name of "Th Cypriot State".\n\n\nFile:Ministry of Commerce Ind and To in Nicosia capital of Repl of Cyprus.jpg|thumb\nThe division of Cyprus has remained an intractable conflict political problem plag relations between Greece and T, and drawing in NATO, of which both Greece and T are members, and latterly the Ean Union, which has admitted Greece and Cyprus and which T has been seeking to join for over twenty years.\n\nThe most recent developments on the island have incl the reopening of the Green Line (Cyprus) between the two sides, and the failure of an attempt to re the island  the terms of a Annan Plan for Cyprus g by the UN Secretary-General, Kofi Annan.\n\nNone of the Greek Cypriot parties has been able to elect a president by itself or dominate the 56-seat House of Representatives. The 165,000 Greek Cypriot ref are also a potent political force, along with the independent Orthodox Ch of Cyprus, which has some infl in temporal as well as ecclesiastical matters.\n\nThe working of the Cypriot state was fra with diffic from the very early days after independence in 1960, and intercomm tension and occasionally violence was a feature of the first decade of Cypriot independence. In 1963, the Cypriot president, Makarios III, proposed 13 amendments to the Constit in order to \u201cremove obstacles to the smooth foning and development of the state.\u201d This was done with the encoment of the British High Commissioner in Cyprus, who considered the amendments \u201ca reasonable basis for discn.\u201d Violence er between Greek and Th Cypriots in December 1963 and by the following year the United Nations agreed to take peacekeeping operations (United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus).\n\nUnited Nations-sponsored negotiations to develop instital arrangements acceptable to the Greek Cypriot and Th Cypriot commes began in 1968; several sets of negotiations and other initiatives followed.\n\nAfter the 1974 Th invasion of Cyprus following a Greek Military dictatorship-based coup d\xe9tat attempt, Makarios sec international recognition of his Greek Cypriot government as the sole legal aity on Cyprus, which has proved to be a very significant strategic advantage for the Greek Cypriots in the decades since. Negotiations continued in the years after 1974 with varying degrees of regty and ss, but none res in a full recation. \nOn 15 November 1983 the Th Cypriot North declared independence and the formation of the Th Rep of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), which has been non-recognized nations only by T. Both sides ply call for the resol of intercomm differences and creation of a new federation of government.\n\nFollowing the Cypriot presidential election, 1998, Glafkos Klerides tried to form a government of national , by incl six ministers from Klerides Democratic Rally party, two ministers from the socialism Movement for Social Democracy, three from the Democratic Party (Cyprus) (who broke ranks with party leader Spyros Kyprianou) and one from the United Democrats. However, a national  government was not achieved due to the leftist AKEL and centrist Democratic Party rejecting the offer, preferring to remain opposition parties.\n\n\nThe res of early negotiations between the Greek and Th politicians res in a broad agreement in principle to recation as a bicameral, bi-zonal federation with territory allocated to the Greek and Th commes within a d island. However, agreement was never reached on the finer details, and the two sides often met deadlock over the following points, among others:\n\nThe Greek side:\n* took a strong line on the right of return for ref to properties vacated in the 1974 displacement of Cypriots on both sides, which was based on both UN Resols and decisions of the Ean Court of H Rights;\n* took a dim view of any proposals which did not allow for the repatriation of Th settlers from the mainland who had emigrated to Cyprus since 1974; and\n* sted a stronger central government.\n\nThe Th side:\n* favo a weak central government presiding over two sovereign states in voly association, a legacy of earlier fears of domination by the majority Greek Cypriots; and\n* opposed plans for demilitarisation, citing sec concerns.\n\nThe continued diffics in finding a settlement presented a potential obstacle to Cypriot entry to the Ean Union, for which the government had applied in 1997. UN-sponsored talks between the Greek and Th leaders, Glafkos Klerides and Rauf Denkta\u015f, continued intensively in 2002, but without resol. In December 2002, the EU formally invited Cyprus to join in 2004, insisting that EU membership would apply to the whole island and hoping that it would provide a significant enticement for recation resg from the oe of ongoing talks. However, weeks before the UN deadline, Klerides was defeated in presidential elections by centre candidate Tassos Papadopo. Papadopo had a repon as a hard-liner on recation and based his stance on international law and h rights. By mid-March, the UN declared that the talks had failed.\n\nA United Nations plan sponsored by Secretary-General of the United Nations Kofi Annan was anno on 31 March 2004, based on what progress had been made d the talks in Switzerland and fleshed out by the UN, was put for the first time to civilians on both sides in separate referendums on 24 April 2004. The Greek side overwhelmingly rejected the Annan Plan for Cyprus, and the Th side voted in favour.\n\n\n\nIn May 2004, Cyprus entered the EU, still divided, although in practice membership only applies to the son part of the island which is in the control of the Rep of Cyprus. In acknowledgment of the Th Cypriot comms st for recation, however, the EU made it clear that trade concessions would be reached to stim economic growth in the north, and remains committed to recation  acceptable terms. Though some trade restrictions were lifted on the north to alleviate economic isolation for the Th Cypriots, fr negotiations have not been a priority. There is now a focus on convincing T to recognise the government of Cyprus, a reqent for Th admission advocated most strongly by Cyprus and France.\n\n\nThe 16 A 1960 constit envisioned power sharing between the Greek Cypriots and Th Cypriots.  Efforts to amends the constit sparked the intercomm strife in 1963.  This constit is still in force, though there is no Th Cypriot presence in the Cypriot government.\n\n\n\n|President of Cyprus\n|Nicos Anastasiades\n|Democratic Rally\n|28 Febr 2013\n|\nThe president, elected by pop vote for a five-year term, is both the chief of state and head of government; post of vice president is ctly vacant;  the 1960 constit, the post is reserved for a Th Cypriot. The Co of Ministers is appointed jointly by the president and vice president.\n\nCtly there are eleven ministries: \n#Ministry of Agrice, Nat Reso and the Environment. Minister: Nikos Coes\n#Ministry of Energy, Commerce, Ind and To. Minister: Georgios Lakkotrypis\n#Ministry of Commtions and Works. Minister: Tasos Mitsopo\n#Ministry of Defence. Minister: Fotis Fotiou\n#Ministry of Edon and Ce.  Minister: Kyriakos Kenevezos\n#Ministry of Finance. Christos Georgiades\n#Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Minister: Ioannis Kasos\n#Ministry of Health. Minister: Petros Petrides\n#Ministry of the Interior. Minister: Socratis Hasikos\n#Ministry of Je and P Order. Minister: Ionas Nikolaou\n#Ministry of Labour and Social Inse: Zeta Aimilianidou\n\n\nThe House of Representatives of Cyprus (Vouli Antipros\xf3pon/Temsilciler Meclisi) has 59 members elected for a five-year term: 56 Greek Cypriot members chosen by proportional representation and 3 observer members representing the Maronite, Roman Catholic and Armenians minorities. 24 seats are allocated to the Th comm, but are ctly vacant.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n# Cyprus Workers Confederation (\u03a3.\u0395.\u039a. \u03a3\u03c5\u03bd\u03bf\u03bc\u03bf\u03c3\u03c0\u03bf\u03bd\u03b4\u03af\u03b1 \u0395\u03c1\u03b3\u03b1\u03c4\u03ce\u03bd \u039a\u03cd\u03c0\u03c1\u03bf\u03c5)\n# Confederation of Revolary Labor Unions or Dev-Is \n# Pancyprian Federation of Labour (\u03a0.\u0395.\u039f. \u03a0\u03b1\u03b3\u03ba\u03cd\u03c0\u03c1\u03b9\u03b1 \u0395\u03c1\u03b3\u03b1\u03c4\u03b9\u03ba\u03ae \u039f\u03bc\u03bf\u03c3\u03c0\u03bf\u03bd\u03b4\u03af\u03b1)\n# Eleftheria Citizens Initiative (\u03a0\u03c1\u03c9\u03c4\u03bf\u03b2\u03bf\u03c5\u03bb\u03af\u03b1 \u03a0\u03bf\u03bb\u03b9\u03c4\u03ce\u03bd \u0395\u03bb\u03b5\u03c5\u03b8\u03b5\u03c1\u03af\u03b1)\n\n\n6 districts; Famag (Ammochostos), Kyrenia, Larnaca, Limassol (Lemesos), Nicosia (Lefkosia), Paphos; note - occ areas administrative divisions include Kyrenia, all but a small part of Famag (Ammochostos), and small parts of Lefkosia (Nicosia) and Larnaca.\n\n\nCyprus has four exclaves, all in territory that belongs to the Akrotiri and Dhekelia. The first two are the villages of Ormidhia and Xylotymvou. Additionally there is the Dhekelia Power Station, which is divided by a British road into two parts. The northern part is an enclave, like the two villages, whereas the son part is located by the sea and therefore not an enclave &mdash;although it has no territorial waters of its own.\n\nThe UN b zone separating the territory controlled by the Th Cypriot administration from the rest of Cyprus runs up against Dhekelia and picks up again from its east side, off of Ayios Nikolaos, SBA (connected to the rest of Dhekelia by a thin land corridor). In that sense, the b zone t the south-east corner of the island, the Paralimni area, into a de facto, though not de jure, exclave.\n\n\nCommonwealth of Nations, Cs Cooperation Co, Co of E, Ean Bank Row(id=14668, title=u'Economy of Iraq', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n|growth          = -2.1% (2014 est.)<ref name="cia.gov"/>\n|per capita      = $7,100 (2013 est.)<ref name="cia.gov"/>\n|sectors         = agrice: 3.4% ind: 64.9% services: 31.7% (2012 est.)\n|components      =\n|inflation       = 2% (2013 est.)\n|poverty         = 25% (2008 est.)\n|gini            =\n|edbr            = 165th (2017)<ref name=" Wodrpdurp bacalacadld Bank and International Financial Corporation ">\n|labor           = 8.9 million (2010 est.)\n|occons     = agrice: 21.6%; ind: 18.7%; services: 59.8% (2008 est.)\n|loyment    = 25% (2012 est.)\n|indes      = petroleum, chemicals, textiles, leather, constrn materials, food processing, fertilizer, metal fabrication/processing\n|exports         = $83.98 billion (2014 est.)<ref name=export_import>\n|export-goods    = crude oil 84%, crude materials excl f 8%, food and live animals 5%\n|export-partners =  22.6%   21.1%   11.2%   7.8%   6.7%   6% (2015)\n|imports         = $45.2 billion (2014 est.)\n|import-goods    = food, medicine, man\n|import-partners = 20.7%   19.6%   19.2%   4.8%   4.4% (2015)\n|FDI             =\n|gross external debt = $58.13 billion (31 December 2014 est.)\n|debt            =\n|revenue         = $69.2 billion (2011 est.)\n|expenses        = $82.6 billion (2011 est.)\n|aid             =\n|credit          =\n|reserves        = $66.85 billion (31 December 2014 est.)\n|cianame         = iz\n|spelling        =\n\nIraqs economy is dominated by the oil\nsector, which has provided about 95% of foreign exchange earnings in modern times. In the 1980s, financial problems ca by massive expendit in the eight-year war with Iran and damage to oil export facilities by Iran led the government to implement aity meas, borrow heavily, and later reschedule foreign debt payments; Iraq sed economic losses of at least $80 1000000000 (n) from the war.<ref>http://www.merip.org/mer/mer243/parker_moore.html Christopher Parker and Pete W. Moore from merip.org After the end of hostilities, in 1988, oil exports grad increased with the constrn of new pipelines and restoration of damaged facilities.\n\nSince mid-2009, oil export earnings have ret to levels seen before Iraq War#2010: U.S. drawdown and Operation New Dawn and government revenues have rebo, along with global oil prices. In 2011 Baghdad probably will increase oil exports above the ct level of  per day as a result of new contracts with international oil companies, but is likely to fall short of the  per day it is forecasting in its b. Iraqs recent contracts with major oil companies have the potential to greatly expand oil revenues, but Iraq will need to de its oil processing, pipeline, and export infrastre to enable these deals to reach their potential.\n\nAn improved sec environment and an initial wave of foreign investment are helping to spur economic activity, particy in the energy, constrn, and retail sectors. Broader economic improvement, long-term fiscal health, and sned increases in the standard of living still depend on the government passing major policy reforms and on continued development of Iraqs massive oil reserves. Although foreign investors viewed Iraq with increasing interest in 2010, most are still hampered by diffics in acqg land for projects and by other regry impediments.\n\nInflation has decreased consistently since 2006 as the sec sitn has improved. However, Iraqi leaders remain hard pressed to translate macroeconomic gains into improved lives for ordinary Iraqis. Unemployment remains a problem throt the co. Red corrn and implementing reforms - such as bank restring and developing the private sector - would be important steps in this direction.\n\n\nNominal GDP grew by 213% in the 1960s, 1325% in the 1970s, 2% in the 1980s, -47% in the 1990s, and 317% in 2000s.\n\nReal GDP per capita (meas in 1990 $) increased significantly d the 1950s, 60s and 70s, which can be explained by both higher oil prodn levels as well as oil prices, which famo peaked in the 1970s due to the OPEC\u2019s oil embargo. In following two decades however, GDP per capita in Iraq dropped sntially because of mle wars, namely the 1980-88 war with Iran, the 1990-1991 Gulf War.\n\n\nPrior to the oak of the war with Iran in September 1980, Iraqs economic prospects were bright. Oil prodn had reached a level of 560,000 m\xb3 (3.5 million barrels) per day in 1979, and oil revenues were 21 billion dollars in 1979 and 27 billion in 1980 due to record oil prices. At the oak of the war, Iraq had amassed an estimated 35 billion in foreign exchange reserves.\n\nThe Iran\u2013Iraq War and the 1980s oil glut depleted Iraqs foreign exchange reserves, devastated its economy, and left the co saddled with a foreign debt of more than $40 billion. After the initial destrn of the war, oil exports grad increased with the constrn of new pipelines and the restoration of damaged facilities.\n\n\n\nIraqs seizure of Invasion of K in A 1990, s Iraq sanctions, and damage from military action by an international coalition beginning in Jan 1991, drastically red economic activity. The regime exacerbated shortages by sting large military and internal sec forces and by allocating reso to key sters of the Arab Socialist Baath Party \u2013 Iraq Region. The implementation of the United Nationss Oil for Food program in December 1996 helped improve economic conditions. For the first six six-month phases of the program, Iraq was allowed to export increasing amo of oil in exchange for food, medicine, and other htarian goods. In December 1999, the UN Sec Co aized Iraq to export as much oil as req to meet htarian needs. Per capita food imports increased sntially, while medical ses and health care services steadily improved, though per capita economic prodn and living standards were still well below their prewar level.\n\nIraq changed its oil reserve ccy from the United States dollar to the euro in 2000. However, 28% of Iraqs export revenues  the program were ded to meet UN Compensation Fund and UN administrative expenses. The drop in Gross Domestic Product in 2001 was largely the result of the global economic slowdown and lower oil prices.\n\n\n\n\nThe removal of sanctions on 24 May 2003 and World oil market chronology from 2003 in the mid-to-late 2000s led to a dog in oil prodn from a low of 1.3 mbpd d the tence of 2003 to a high of 2.6 mbpd in 2011. since 2007 have translated to real increases in living standards for Iraqis.\n\nOne of the key economic challenges was Iraqs immense foreign debt, estimated at $125 billion.  Although some of this debt was derived from normal export contracts that Iraq had failed to pay for, some was a result of military and financial st d Iraqs war with Iran.\n\nThe Je Iraq campaign argued that much of these debts were odious debt (illegitimate). However, as the concept of odious debt is not accepted, trying to deal with the debt on those terms would have embroiled Iraq in legal disp for years. Iraq decided to deal with its debt more pragmatically and approached the Paris Club of official creditors.\n\nIn a December 2006 Newsweek International article, a study by Global Insight in London was reported to show "that Civil war or not, Iraq has an economy, and\u2014mother of all sses\u2014its doing remarkably well. Real estate is booming. Constrn, retail and wholesale trade sectors are healthy, too, according to the report. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce reports 34,000 registered companies in Iraq, up from 8,000 three years ago. Sales of secondhand cars, televisions and mobile phones have all risen sharply. Estimates vary, but one from Global Insight puts GDP growth at 17 percent last year and projects 13 percent for 2006. The World Bank has it lower: at 4 percent this year. But, given all the attention paid to deteriorating sec, the startling fact is that Iraq is growing at all."\n\nBetween  and  of Iraq\u2019s declared oil prodn over the past four years could have been siphoned off through corrn or smng, according to a US Study from May 12, 2007.\n\n\n\nTraditionally, most of Iraq\u2019s man activity has been closely connected to the oil ind. The major indes in that category have been petroleum refining and the manure of chemicals and fertilizers. Before 2003, diversification was hindered by limitations on privatization and the effects of the international sanctions of the 1990s. Since 2003, sec problems have blocked efforts to establish new enterprises. The constrn ind is an exception; in 2000 cement was the only major indal product not based on hydrocarbons. The constrn ind has profited from the need to reb after Iraq\u2019s several wars. In the 1990s, the ind benefited from government fg of extensive infrastre and ho projects and elaborate palace complexes.\n\n\n\n\nHistorically, 50 to 60 percent of Iraq\u2019s arable land has been  cation. Because of ethnic politics, val farmland in Ktan territory has not contrib to the national economy, and inconsistent agrical policies  Saddam Hn discod domestic market prodn. Despite its abt land and water reso, Iraq is a net food importer. Under the UN Oil for Food program, Iraq imported large qties of grains, meat, po, and dairy prod. The government abolished its farm collectivization program in 1981, allowing a greater role for private enterprise in agrice.\n\nIraqi agrice sed sntial physical disrn from the Gulf War, and economic disrn from Economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations (A 1990).  Sanctions cled imports by cg off Iraq\u2019s petroleum exports, and embargoing those agrical prodn inputs deemed to have potential military applications.  The Iraqi government responded by monopolizing grain and oilseed marketing, imposing prodn q, and instit a P Distrib System for basic foodst.  By mid-1991 the government sed a \u201cbasket\u201d of foodst that provided about one-third of the caloric daily reqent, and cost cons about five percent of its market value.  With sies for agrical inputs diminished, the prices that the government paid to farmers failed to cover their costs.  The implicit tax on agrical prodn was estimated to reach 20 to 35 percent by the mid-1990s.  In October 1991 the Baghdad regime had withdrawn personnel from the northern region controlled by two Kh parties. Iraqi Ktan was described as \u201c. . . a market economy essentially left alone by a very weak governing stre, but heavily infld by sntial international htarian aid flows.\u201d \n\nUnder an \u201cOil for Food Program\u201d negotiated with the United Nations, in December 1996 Iraq started exporting petroleum, and  the proceeds to start importing foodst three months later.  Grain imports averaged $828 million in the years 1997-2001, an increase of over 180 percent from the previous five-year period. Due to foreign competition, Iraqi prodn declined (29 percent for wheat, 31 percent for barley, and 52 percent for maize).  Because the government had generally neglected the prodn of forage crops, fr, vegetables, and livestock other than po, those sectors had remained more traditional and market-based, and less bed by international affairs. Nevertheless, severe dro, an oak of screwworm, and an epizootic of foot-and-mouth disease devastated prodn d this period.<ref>Beer, Sam. https://books.google.ca/books?id=ty5oDQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT16&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false The United States Program for Agrice in Post-Invasion Iraq. 2016.  As the Oil for Food Program expanded to cover more agrical inputs and machinery, the prodity of Iraqi agrice stabilized around 2002.\n\nFollowing the invasion led by the United States in March 2003, with incomes of many Iraqis devastated, the market for foodst shrunk.  Seeking to re-orient Iraq\u2019s economy toward private ownership and international competitiveness, the United States had seen the dismantling of the P Distrib System as essential for a market-driven agrice.  Because of the great reliance of most Iraqis on government-sized food, this goal was never realized.  Increased prodity became the focus of much of the U.S.-f agrical reconstrn program.  Many of these projects were taken by the https://www.dai.com/our-work/projects/iraq-agrice-reconstrn-and-development-program-iraq-ardi Agrical Reconstrn and Development Iraq (ARDI) program run by Development Alternatives, Inc. (DAI) of Bethesda MD  a contract with USAID signed on October 15, 2003.  While ARDI participated in limited ways, the restoration of Iraq\u2019s irrigation systems was mostly f  USAID\u2019s contract with Bechtel International.   \n\nARDI cond demonstration trials of improved practices and varieties of many crops:  winter cereals (wheat and barley), s cereals (rice, maize, and sorghum), potatoes, and tomatoes.  Feed sments and veterinary treatments were demonstrated to increase ovon, conception, and birth weights of livestock.  Ss were cond of po growers and apple farmers.  Nies were established for date palms and grapes.  College bngs and farm tractors were reb.  ARDI had projects promoting trade associations and prod\u2019 co-ops, but also sted extension as an appropriate governmental fon.  The contract event cost over $100 million and lasted through December 2006.  Under its Comm Action Program, USAID also f an analysis of markets for sheep and wool.  It awarded a contract to the University of Hawaii to revitalize higher edon in agrice.  It awarded a contract for $120 million to the Louis Berger Group to promote Iraq\u2019s private sector, incl agrice.<ref>Beer, Sam. https://books.google.ca/books?id=ty5oDQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT16&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false The United States Program for Agrice in Post-Invasion Iraq. 2016. \n\nStarting in 2006, agrical reconstrn was also cond by Provincial Reconstrn Teams within the occg military forces.  Intended to promote goodwill and sap the inscy, \u201cPRTs\u201d allowed military commanders to identify local needs and, with few bcratic hs, to dispense up to $500,000.  Civilians from many agencies within the U. S. Department of Agrice, as well as USAID, served tours on PRTs.  Some participants criticized the absence of a national agrical strategy, or clear direction on the design of projects.  Others complained that projects emphasized \u201cAmerican-style, 21st-century agrical technologies and methodologies . . .\u201d that were inappropriate for Iraq.<ref>Bernard Carreau, ed. \u201cLessons from USDA in Iraq and Afghanistan,\u201d  Prism Vol. 1, No. 3, (September 2011): 139.\n\nAgrical prodn has not rebo noticeably from the reconstrn program.  According to the Food and Agrice Organization (FAO), between 2002 and 2013, prodn of wheat increased 11 percent and milled rice 8 percent, but barley had decreased 13 percent and maize 40 percent.  Scaled in \u201cinternational dollars\u201d (2004-2006 base eqg 100) Iraq\u2019s per capita food prodn was 135 in 2002, 96 in 2007, and 94 in 2012.  The agrical sector shed workers.  In those same years, prodn per worker was 117, 106, and 130, respectively. <ref>\u201cFAOSTAT Co Profiles:  Iraq.\u201d  http://www.fao.org/coprofiles/index/en/?iso3=IRQ FAO website  \n\nThe international Oil-for-Food program (1997\u20132003) fr red farm prodn by sing artificially priced foreign foodst. The military action of 2003 did little damage to Iraqi agrice; because of favorable weather conditions, in that year grain prodn was 22 percent higher than in 2002. Although growth continued in 2004, experts predicted that Iraq will be an importer of agrical prod for the foreseeable f. Long-term plans call for investment in agrical machinery and materials and more prolific crop varieties\u2014improvements that did not reach Iraq\u2019s farmers  the Hn regime. In 2004 the main agrical crops were wheat, barley, corn, rice, vegetables, dates, and cotton, and the main livestock os were cattle and sheep.\n\nThe Agrical Cooperative Bank of Iraq, capitalized at nearly 1 G$ - by 1984, targets its low-interest, low-collateral loans to private farmers for mechanization, po projects, and orchard development. Large modern cattle, dairy farming, and po farms are  constrn. Obstacles to agrical development include labour shortages, inadeq management and maintenance, salinization, ization, and dislocations resg from previous land reform and collectivization programs.\n\nImportation of foreign workers and increased entry of women into traditionally male labour roles have helped compensate for agrical and indal labour shortages exacerbated by the war. A disastrous attempt to drain the son marshes and introduce irrigated farming to this region merely destroyed a nat food prod area, while concentration of salts and minerals in the soil due to the draining left the land table for agrice.<ref name="MarshArabs">\n\nIn the Mada\u2019in Qada region east of Baghdad, hds of small farmers d to form the Green Mada\u2019in Association for Agrical Development, an agrical cooperative that provides its members with drip irrigation and greenhouses as well as access to credit.\n\n\nThrot the twentieth century, h exploration, shifting agrice, forest fires, and trolled grazing den large areas of Iraq\u2019s nat forests, which in 2005 were almost exclly confined to the northeastern highlands. Most of the trees found in that region are not sle for ling. In 2002 a total of 112,000 c meters of wood were harvested, nearly half of which was  as fuel.\n\nDespite its many rivers, Iraq\u2019s fishing ind has remained relatively small and based largely on marine species in the Persian Gulf. In 2001 the catch was 22,800 tons.\n\nAside from hydrocarbons, Iraq\u2019s mining ind has been confined to extraction of relatively small amo of phosphates (at Akashat), salt, and s (near Mosul). Since a prode period in the 1970s, the mining ind has been hampered by the Iran\u2013Iraq War (1980\u201388), the sanctions of the 1990s, and the economic collapse of 2003.\n\n\n\n\n\nFile:Iraq Export Treemap.jpg|thumb|350px\nAs one of the three most oil-rich coes in the world, Iraq has the reso for complete energy independence.  By world standards, prodn costs for Iraqi oil are relatively low. Three wars (Iraq-Iran War from 1980\u20131988, Gulf War 1991 and the Iraqi Invasion of 2003) in addition to the UN sanctions - which lasted for twelve years from 1991 to 2003, left the ind\u2019s infrastre in poor condition.\n\nThe lifting of sanctions in 2003 allowed repairs to begin. Since 2003 oil pipelines and installations have been sabotaged persistently. In 2004 Iraq had eight oil refineries, the largest of which were at Baiji, Iraq, Basra, and Daura.\n\nSabotage and technical problems at the refineries forced Iraq to import f, liquid petroleum gas, and other refined prod from nearby coes. In October 2004, for example, Iraq spent US$60 million for imported gasoline. In late 2004 and early 2005, reg sabotage of plants and pipelines red export and domestic distrib of oil, particy to Baghdad. Nationwide fuel shortages and power os res.\n\nIn 2004 plans called for increased domestic zation of nat gas to replace oil and for use in the petrochemical ind. However, because most of Iraq\u2019s gas o is associated with oil, o growth depends on developments in the oil ind.\n\nAs much as 90 percent of Iraq\u2019s power generating and distrib systems were destroyed in the Persian Gulf War of 1991, and full recovery never occ. In mid-2004, Iraq had an estimated 5,000 megawatts of power-generating capacity, compared with 7,500 megawatts of demand.  At that time, the transmission system incl 17,700 kilometers of line. In 2004 plans called for constrn of two new power plants and restoration of existing plants and transmission lines to ease the blackouts and economic hardship ca by this shortfall, but sabotage and looting held capacity below 6,000 megawatts. In 2004 the World Bank estimated that US$12 billion would be needed for near-term restoration, and the Ministry of Electricity estimated that US$35 billion would be necessary to reb the system f.\n\nIn 2007, hydrocarbon indes acco for well over 70 per cent of the Iraqi economy and 95 per cent of the governments revenues. Diversification of the economy into non-hydrocarbon indes remain a long-term issue.\n\n\nBetween June 2009 and Febr 2010 the Iraqi Oil Ministry tendered for the award of Service Contracts to develop Iraqs existing oil fields. The res of the tender, which was broadcast live on Iraqi television, are as follows for all major fields awarded but excl the Iraqi Ktan where Prodn Sharing Contracts have been awarded which are ctly being disp by the Baghdad government.  All contracts are awaiting final ratification of the awards by the Iraqi government. Company shares are st to change as a result of commercial negotiations between parties.\n\nIf all contracts awarded reach their stated target plateau prodn then this will increase Iraqi prodn from todays 2.5 mb/d by 9.4 mb/d to a total of 11.9 mb/d, comparable to ct Saudi declared capacity of 12.5 mb/d.\n\n{| class="wikitable"\n|-\n! The 17 private banks established d the 1990s were limited to domestic transactions and attracted few private depositors. Those banks and two main state banks were badly damaged by the international embargo of the 1990s. To fr privatize and expand the system, in 2003 the Coalition Provisional Aity removed restrictions on international bank transactions and freed the Central Bank of Iraq (CBI) from government control. In its first year of independent operation, the CBI received credit for limiting Iraq\u2019s inflation. In 2004 three foreign banks received licenses to do bss in Iraq.\n\n\nBecause of the danger posed by Iraq\u2019s ongoing inscy, the sec ind has been a ely prosperous part of the services sector. Often run by former U.S. military personnel, in 2005 at least 26 companies offered personal and instital protection, sllance, and other forms of sec.\n\n\nIn the early post-Hn period, a freewheeling retail trade in all types of commodities straddled the line between legitimate and illegitimate commerce, taking advantage of the lack of income tax and import controls.\n\n\nThe Iraq to ind, which in peaceful times has profited from Iraq\u2019s many places of cal interest (earning US$14 million in 2001), has been dormant since 2003. Despite conditions, in 2005 the Iraqi To Board maintained a staff of 2,500 and 14 regional offices. Between 2009 and 2010, 165 tos from 16 different coes entered Iraq to visit historic sites; as of Jan 2011, a U.S. State Department grant provided $2 million to help preserve Babylon, sting the re-opening of one of the sites two ms.\n\n\nD 2003-8, mobile phone siptions had expanded over hdfold to 10 million nationwide, according to the Brookings Instit.\n\n\nIn 2002 Iraq\u2019s labor force was estimated at 6.8 million people.\n\nIn 1996 some 66.4 percent of the labor force worked in services, 17.5 percent in ind, and 16.1 percent in agrice. 2004 estimates of Iraq\u2019s loyment ranged from 30 percent to 60 percent.\n\n{| class="wikitable sortable"\n|+Nationwide loyment rate since May, 2003<ref name="campbell"><ref name="icg">"Reconstrg Iraq", International Crisis Group, Report, September 2, 2004, p. 16, footnote 157.\n|-\n! width="250px" | Month\n! width="100px" | UnemploymentRate\n|-\n| 2003-5 May\n| N/A\n|-\n| 2003-6 June\n| 50-60%\n|-\n| 2003-7 July\n| N/A\n|-\n| 2003-8 A\n| 50-60%\n|-\n| 2003-9 September\n| N/A\n|-\n| 2003-10 October\n| 40-50%\n|-\n| 2003-11 November\n| N/A\n|-\n| 2003-12 December\n| 45-55%\n|-\n| 2004-01 to 05 (Jan - May)\n| 30-45%\n|-\n| 2004-06 to 11 (June - November)\n| 30-40%\n|-\n| 2004-12 December\n| 28-40%\n|-\n| 2005-01 to 10 (Jan - October)\n| 27-40%\n|-\n| 2005-11 to 12 (November - December)\n| 25-40%\n|-\n| 2006-01 to 12 (Jan - December)\n| 25-40%\n|-\n| 2007-01 to 12 (Jan - December)\n| 25-40%\n|-\n| 2008-01 to 12 (Jan - December)\n| 25-40%\n|-\n| 2009-01 (Jan)\n| 23-38%\n|-\n| 2010\n| 15-20%\n|-\n| 2012\n| 11%\n|\n\nThe CPA has referred to a 25% loyment rate, the Iraqi Ministry of Planning mentioned a 30% loyment rate, whereas the Iraqi Ministry of Social Affairs claims it to be 48%.<ref name="campbell" /> Other so are claiming a 20% loyment rate and a probably 60% -employment rate.<ref name="caffrey"> The actual figure is problematic because of high participation in black-market activities and poor sec conditions in many pop areas. In central Iraq, sec concerns discod the hiring of new workers and the reson of reg work sched. At the same time, the return of Iraqis from other coes increased the n of job seekers. In late 2004, most legitimate jobs were in the government, the army, the oil ind, and sec-related enterprises. Under Saddam Hn Hn, many of the highest-paid workers were employed by the greatly overstaffed government, whose overthrow disr the input of these people to the economy. In 2004 the U.S. Agency for International Development committed US$1 billion for a worker-training program. In early 2004, the minimum wage was US$72 per month.\n\n\nFile:2006Iraqi exports.PNG|thumb|left\nFrom the 1990s  2003, the international trade embargo restricted Iraq\u2019s export activity almost exclly to oil. In 2003 oil acco for about US$7.4 billion of Iraq\u2019s total US$7.6 billion of export value, and statistics for earlier years showed similar proportions. After the end of the trade embargo in 2003 expanded the range of exports, oil continued to occupy the dominant position: in 2004 Iraq\u2019s export income do (to US$16.5 billion), but oil acco for all but US$340 million (2 percent) of the total. In late 2004, sabotage significantly red oil o, and experts forecast that o, hence exports, would be below capacity in 2005 as well. In 2004 the chief export markets were the United States (which acco for nearly half), Italy, France, Jordan, Canada, and the Netherlands. In 2004 the value of Iraq\u2019s imports was US$21.7 billion, incg a trade deficit of about US$5.2 billion. In 2003 the main so of Iraq\u2019s imports were T, Jordan, Vietnam, the United States, Germany, and Britain. Because of Iraq\u2019s inactive man sector, the range of imports was q large, incl food, f, medicines, and man goods. By 2010, exports rose to US$50.8 billion and imports rose to US$45.2 billion.  Chief 2009 export partners were: U.S., India, Italy, South Korea, Taiwan, China, Netherlands, and Japan. Chief 2009 import partners were: T, Syria, U.S., China, Jordan, Italy, and Germany.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*http://www.ia.org Iraq Inter-Agency Information & Analysis Unit Reports, Maps and Assessments of Iraq Row(id=24400, title=u'Pair programming', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nFile:Pair programming 1.jpg|thumb|Two co-workers pair programmingPair programming is an agile software development technique in which two comp programmer work together at one workstation. One, the driver, writes So code while the other, the observer or navigator, code review each line of code as it is typed in. The two programmers switch roles freqy.\n\nWhile reviewing, the observer also considers the "strategic" direction of the work, coming up with ideas for improvements and likely f problems to address. This frees the driver to focus all of his or her attention on the "tactical" aspects of completing the ct task,  the observer as a safety net and g.\n\nPair programming increases the man-hours req to deliver code compared to programmers working individ. Experiments yielded diverse res, sting increases of between 15% and 100%.<ref name="ijhcs"/> However, the resg code has about 15% fewer defects.<ref name="costs-benefits"/> Along with code development time, other factors like field st costs and qy asse also affect the expenses. IBM reported spending about \u201c$250 million repairing and reinstalling fixes to 30,000 cer-reported problems\u201d. Pair programming significantly red these expenses by red the defects in the programs.<ref name="costs-benefits">\n\n\nA system with two programmers possesses greater potential for the generation of more diverse sols to problems for three reasons:\n\n# the programmers bring different prior experiences to the task; \n# they may access information relevant to the task in different ways; \n# they stand in different relationships to the problem by virtue of their fonal roles.\n\nIn an attempt to share goals and plans, the programmers must overtly negotiate a shared co of action when a conflict arises between them. In doing so, they consider a larger n of ways of solving the problem than a single programmer alone might do. This significantly improves the design qy of the program as it red the chances of selecting a poor method.<ref> |editor1-first=J\xfcrgen |editor1-last=Koenemann-Belliveau |editor2-first=Thomas G. |editor2-last=Moher |editor3-first=Scott P. |editor3-last=Robertson |year=1991 |title=Empirical St of Programmers: Fo Workshop |pher=Ablex |isbn=978-0-89391-856-9 \n\n\nIn an online s of pair programmers, 96% of them stated that they enjoyed their work more than when they programmed alone and 95% said that they were more confident in their sols when they pair programmed. <ref name="strengthening">\n\n\nKnowledge is constantly shared between pair programmers, whether in the ind or in a classroom, many so st that sts show higher confidence when programming in pairs,<ref name="strengthening"/> and many learn whether it be from tips on programming lang r to overall design skill.<ref name="st"> In "promisc pairing", each programmer commtes and works with all the other programmers on the team rather than pairing only with one partner, which ca knowledge of the system to spread throt the whole team.<ref name="costs-benefits"/> Pair programming allows the programmers to examine their partners code and provide feedback which is necessary to increase their own ability to develop monitoring mechanisms for their own learning activities.<ref name="st"/>\n\n\nPair programming allows team members to share problems and sols qy making them less likely to have hidden agendas from each other. This helps pair programmers to learn to commte more easily. \u201cThis raises the commtion bandwidth and freq within the project, increasing overall information flow within the team.\u201d<ref name="costs-benefits"/>\n\n\nThere are both empirical st and meta-analyses of pair programming. The empirical st tend to examine the level of prodity and the qy of the code, while meta-analyses may focus on biases introd by the process of testing and phing.\n\nA meta-analysis found pairs typically consider more design alternatives than programmers working alone, arrive at simpler more maintainable designs, and catch design defects earlier. However, it raised concerns its findings may have been infld by "signs of pation bias among phed st on pair programming". It concl that "pair programming is not rmly beneficial or effective".<ref name="hannay-meta">\n\nAlthough pair programmers may complete a task faster than a solo programmer, the total n of man-hours increases.<ref name="ijhcs"/> A manager would have to balance faster completion of the work and red testing and debg time against the higher cost of coding. The relative weight of these factors can vary by project and task.\n\nThe benefit of pairing is greatest on tasks that the programmers do not f stand before they begin: that is, challenging tasks that call for creativity and sophistication, and for novices as compared to experts.<ref name=ijhcs>  Pair programming could be helpful for attaining high qy and correctness on complex programming tasks, but it would also increase the development effort (cost) significantly.<ref name="hannay-meta"/>\n\nOn simple tasks, which the pair already f stands, pairing res in a net drop in prodity.<ref name="ijhcs"/><ref name="Arisholm 2007 65\u201386"> It may reduce the code development time but also risks red the qy of the program.<ref name="hannay-meta"/>\nProdity can also drop when novice\u2013novice pairing is  without sient availability of a mentor to coach them.\n\n\nThere are indicators that a pair is not performing well:\n* Disengagement may present as one of the members physically withdraws away from the keyboard, accesses email, or even falls asleep.\n* The "Watch the Master" phenomenon can arise if one member is more experienced than the other. In this sitn, the j member may take the observer role, deferring to the senior member of the pair for the majority of coding activity. This can easily lead to disengagement.\n* Silence immediately indicates a lack of collaboration.\n\n\n;Expert\u2013expert\n:Expert\u2013expert pairing may seem to be the obvious choice for the highest prodity and can produce great res, but it often yields little insight into new ways to solve problems, as both parties are ely to qon established practices.<ref name="ijhcs"/>\n;Expert\u2013novice\n:Expert\u2013novice pairing creates many opportes for the expert to mentor the novice. This pairing can also introduce new ideas, as the novice is more likely to qon established practices. The expert, now req to explain established practices, is also more likely to qon them. However, in this pairing, an intimidated novice may passively "watch the master" and hesitate to participate meaningf. Also, some experts may not have the patience needed to allow constre novice participation.\n;Novice\u2013novice (rsity)\n:Novice\u2013novice pairing can produce res significantly better than two novices working independently, although, this practice is generally discod.<ref name="costs-benefits" />\n\n\nRemote pair programming, also known as virtual pair programming or distrib pair programming, is pair programming in which the two programmers are in different locations, working via a collaborative real-time editor, shared desktop, or a remote pair programming Integrated development environment pl. Remote pairing introd diffics not present in face-to-face pairing, such as extra delays for coordination, depending more on "heavyweight" task-tracking tools instead of "lightweight" ones like index cards, and loss of verbal commtion resg in conf and conflicts over such things as who "has the keyboard".<ref name=jucs>\n\nTool st could be provided by:\n* Whole-screen sharing software.<ref>http://blogs.pathf.com/agileajax/2007/09/pair-programmin.html Agile Ajax: Pair Programming with VNC<!-- Bot generated title --><ref>http://weblogs.asp.net/jcogley/archive/2004/10/13/242117.aspx Pair Programming \u2013 The Ultimate Setup and the other options we tried. \u2013 Jonathan Cogleys Blog<!-- Bot generated title --><ref>http://olalindberg.com/blog/2009/07/06/comp-ergonomics-and-pair-programming/ Ola Lindberg \u203a Comp ergonomics and pair programming\n* Terminal mlexers\n* Specialized distrib editing tools\n* A chat programs or VoIP software could be helpful when the screen sharing software does not provide two-way a capability. Row(id=32783, title=u'Antisemitism and the New Testament', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\nIt has been argued that the New Testament contrib toward s antisemitism in the Christian comm.<ref name="Dunn">James Dunn (theologian) (ed.) 1992 https://books.google.com/books?id=9zCh9SBb6Y8C&pg=PA179 J. The Qon of Anti-Semitism in the New Testament Writings of the Period,  in James D.G. Dunn, \u2018Jews and Christians: the parting of the ways, CE 70 to 135. Wm. B. Eerdmans Phing, 1999. Pp.176-211 p 179. The challenge thus posed to Christian NT scholars in partic cannot therefore be d... The qon we must face, then, is whether such attit are already inseparable from the script on which they were based. ... in terms of the present inq, Does the attitude to Jews in the post-70 NT docs indicate that the final breach, the decisive parting of the ways between Christianity and (rabbinic) Jm, has already happened? The idea that the New Testament is anti-Semitic is  a controversy that has emerged with force in the aftermath of the Holocaust. It is often associated with a thesis put forward by Rosemary Rr,<ref>Rosemary Rr https://books.google.com/books?id=XNJJAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA23  Faith and Fratricide: The Theological Roots of Anti-Semitism, Wipf and Stock Phers, 1996  pp.23ff.<ref>John G. Gager, https://books.google.com/books?id=FGuCX_CwelAC&pg=PA13 The Origins of Anti-Semitism: Attit toward Jm in Pagan and Christian Antiq,  Oxford University Press, 1985 pp.13ff. and the various positions depend on how anti-Semitism is defined, and on scholarly disagreements over whether anti-Semitism has a monolithic contin history, or is an lla term gathering in many distinct kinds of hostility to Jews over time.\n\nAccording to Louis Feldman, if anti-Semitism is an irrational ok branding Jews as ely evil or inferior, such an attitude was not common in the ancient pagan world, apart from a pop form of anti-Semitism in Egypt. Technically, the proper term is, he thinks, Anti-Jm.<ref>Louis Feldman, https://books.google.com/books?id=pACJYw0bg3QC&pg=PA277 St in Hellenistic Jm, BRILL 1996 pp.277f. and n.1:Of co, the term anti-Semitism is an absy which the Jews took over from the Germans. There was no such thing in antiq, since its basis, the Machic family tree, was hardly known oe the circles of the Jews themselves,  the rise of Christianity, which could not well be hostile to the race of its savior. The more acc term would be \u201canti-Jm\u201d but the term \u201canti-Semitism\u201d is so widespread that it may seem artificial to discard it.\u2019 The distinction between anti-Jm and anti-Semitism is often made, or challenged,<ref>David Lsmeyer, https://books.google.com/books?id=0KuT2qkhtGEC&pg=PA167  pp.167-171. with regard to early Christian hostility to Jews: some, notably Gavin I. Langmuir,<ref>Avner Falk, https://books.google.com/books?id=VWL4ja2BbnEC&pg=PA8 Anti-semitism: A History and Psychoanalysis of Contemporary Hatred, ABC-CLIO, 2008 pp.6-8 prefer anti-Jm, implying theological enmity and taking anti-Semitism as anachronistic for the period,<ref>Guy Stro, \u2018From anti-Jm to antisemitism in Early Christianity,\u2019 in  Ora Limor, Guy Stro, https://books.google.com/books?id=X-yF4wPWF5EC&pg=PA5 Contra Is: Ancient and Medieval Polemics Between Christians and Jews, :de:Mohr Siebeck Verlag 1996 pp.1-26  p.5: It  obvio  makes little sense to speak of Christian anti-Semitism in the earliest stages of the new religion, since the belief in Jesus Christ was at first held within a Jewish sectarian movement . .Anti-Jm is hence perceived as inherent to Christianity, while antisemitism would represent an attitude of a rather different nature, appearing later, and elsewhere implying the sec biological race theories of modern times.<ref>Ruth Sheridan https://books.google.com/books?id=TdoyAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA38 Retelling Scripture: The Jews and the Script Citations in John 1:19-12:15, BRILL, 2012 Rev.ed. pp.38 f. Sheridan  argues the dichotomy is problematic  Peter Sch\xe4fer prefers the word Jphobia for pagan hostility to Jews, but considers the word antisemitism, even if anachronistic, synonymous with this term, while adding that  Christian anti-Jm event was cr to what later became anti-Semitism.<ref>Peter Sch\xe4fer, https://books.google.com/books?id=8jIhYBwkO80C&pg=PA7  Jhobia: Attit Toward the Jews in the Ancient World, Harvard University Press 1997 pp.6-7, p:7, pp.197ff.\u2019The only term I avoid is \u201canti-Jm\u201d thus following those scholars who restrict it to early Christian expressions of hostility towards the Jews.\xec A. Roy Eckardt has asserted that the foion of antisemitism and responsibility for the Holocaust lies ately in the New Testament.<ref name="Eckardt">A. Roy Eckhardt, https://books.google.com/books?id=LfhCAAAAIAAJ&q=A.+Roy+Eckhardt%2B+Elder+and+Yo+Brothers&dq=A.+Roy+Eckhardt%2B+Elder+and+Yo+Brothers&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y  Elder and Yo Brothers:The Enco of Jews and Christians, Scribner New York, 1967 James Dunn (theologian) argues that the various New Testament expressions of anger and hurt by a minority pd by the ref of a majority to accept their claims about Jesus the Jew  reflect inner tensions between Jewish commes not yet ed by Rabbinic Jm, and a Christianity not yet detached from Jm.<ref name ="Dunn"/>\n\nFactional agendas pin the writing of the canonical texts, and the various NT docs are windows into the conflict and debates of that period.<ref>Abel Mordechai Bibliowicz,  https://books.google.com/books?id=CM9_dUMSvukC&pg=PT129 Jews and Gentiles in the Early Jesus Movement: An Unintended Jo,  Springer, 2013 p.93. According to Timothy Johnson, m slandering among competing sects was q strong in the period when these works were composed.<ref>Lloyd Kim https://books.google.com/books?id=87RLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 Polemic in the Book of Hebrews: Anti-Jm, Anti-Semitism, Sessionism?, Wipf and Stock Phers, 2006 p.14. The  New Testament moreover is an ensemble of texts written over decades, and reflects the different milieux of composition.<ref>Guy Stro, \u2018From anti-Jm to antisemitism in Early Christianity,\u2019 p.5:I wish to recall that . . these texts were written in rather diverse milieus, and that therefore it is q meaningless to speak about a single New Testament attitude.\u2019; https://books.google.com/books?id=X-yF4wPWF5EC&pg=PA16 p.16 \u2018The context and meaning of the rejection of the Jews in the Gospel of John, . .are vastly different from Chrysostom\u2019s anti-Jewish invective. We cannot speak of a single early Christian or Patristic attitude toward Jews and Jm, or imply its existence. Both the relationship of Christianity to Jm and the Christians\u2019 perceptions of Jews were totally different at the end of the fo century than they had been three hd years previo\u2019.\n\n\n\nA. Roy Eckardt, a pioneer in the field of Jewish-Christian relations,<ref>http://hgs.oxfordjos.org/cgi/reprint/12/3/519.pdf In Memoriam: Professor A. Roy Eckardt Holocaust and Genocide St 1998 12(3):519 asserted that the foion of antisemitism and responsibility for the Holocaust lies ately in the New Testament.<ref name="Eckardt"/> Eckardt insisted that Christian repentance must include a reexamination of basic theological attit toward Jews and the New Testament in order to deal effectively with antisemitism.\n\nAccording to Rabbi Michael J. Cook, Professor of Intertestamental and Early Christian Literature at the Hebrew Union College, there are ten themes in the New Testament that are the greatest so of anxiety for Jews concerning Christian antisemitism:\n# The Jewish deicide - as such they are g of deicide\n# The tribons of the Jewish people throt history constitute Gods pment of them for killing Jesus\n# Jesus originally Matthew 10, but when Rejection of Jesus, he abandoned them for gentiles instead\n# The Children of Israel were Gods original chosen people by virtue of an ancient Covenant (biblical), but by rejecting Jesus they forfeited their chosenness - and now, by virtue of a New Covenant (or "testament"), Sessionism, the Ch having become the "People of God."\n# The Jewish Bible (the so-called "Old Testament") repeatedly portrays the opaqs and stnness of the Jewish people and their disloyalty to God.\n# The Jewish Bible contains Typology (theology) as the Messiah (or "Christ"), yet the Jews are blind to the meaning of their own Bible.\n# By the time of Ministry of Jesus, Jm had ceased to be a living faith.\n# Jms essence is a restrictive and bsome Legalism (theology).\n# Agape, while Jm maintains a balance of je, Divine retrib and love of peace.\n# Jms oppressiveness reflects the disposition of Jesus opponents called "Pharisees" (predecessors of the "rabbis"), who in their teachings and behavior were hypocrites (see Woes of the Pharisees).<ref>A. James R, https://books.google.com/books?id=kW7gAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA89 Christians & Jews\u2014Faith to Faith: Tragic History, Promising Present, Fragile F, Jewish Lights Phing, 2013 p.89.\n\nCook believes that both contemporary Jews and contemporary Christians need to reexamine the history of early Christianity, and the Split of early Christianity and Jm consisting of Jewish Christianity, to a separate religion often dependent on the tolerance of Rome while proselytizing among Gentiles loyal to the Roman empire, to stand how the story of Jesus came to be recast in an anti-Jewish form as the Gospels took their final form.\n\nSome scholars assert that critical verses in the New Testament have been  to incite prej and violence against Jewish people. Jesus was arrested and Sanhedrin Trial of Jesus. After the trial, Jesus was handed over to Pontius Pilate, who duly tried him again and, at the g of the people, had him death of Jesus.\n\nThe New Testament records that Jesus disciple J Iscariot, the Roman governor Pontius Pilate along with Roman forces and the leaders and people of Jerm were (to varying degrees) responsible for the death of Jesus.\n\n\nAccording to the Gospel of Mark, Jesus crxion was aized by Roman empire aities at the insistence of leading Jews (Js) from the Sanhedrin.\n\nPaul H. The enemies of Jesus are described collectively as "the Jews", in contradistinction to the other evangelists, who do not generally <ref>An exception is Gospel of Matthew 27:25All the people (\u03c0\u1fb6\u03c2 \u1f41 \u03bb\u03b1\u1f78\u03c2) answered, "His blood is on us and on our children!" ascribe to "the Jews" en masse calls for the death of Jesus. In John 8:37-39; Jesus says, speaking to a group of Pharisees:\n\n\nThough it has been claimed that the  modern consensus is that the term Ioi/Jews in John refers exclly to religious aities,<ref>Kierspel, https://books.google.com/books?id=68f2cdlMtfMC&pg=PA14 p.13. the basis for this claim has been challenged and Johns use of the term Jews remains a complex and debated area of biblical scholarship.<ref>BPVV, https://books.google.com/books?id=GJKgs7fiH2cC&pg=PA15 pp.15-17<ref>R Alan Cper, https://books.google.com/books?id=ecsaUUzRdEUC&pg=PA294  The Gospel and Letters of John, Abington Press 1998 p.294:The Greek term hoi Ioi can mean "the Jews," as it is ly translated, but it can also mean "the Js." In the Gospel of John the group designated by this term appears to be vario Js (as opposed to Galileans or Samaritans), the J leaders (where it is  interchangeably with "the Pharisees"), or-less freqy-Jews as opposed to Gentiles. The meaning of the term Ioi, which is  71 times in the Gospel, must therefore be determined by the context of each occce. There are places in John where the term can hardly mean "the Jews." . For example, although the crowd in Jerm at the Festival of Booths must have been predominantly Jewish, they still fear the Ioi. By translating hoi Ioi as "the Jews" in this context, the NRSV and other translations produce a reading that makes little sense. . Here it is clear that hoi Ioi refers to a much more limited group opposed to Jesus, either certain J Jews or the religious aities. The same diffics appear elsewhere in the Gospel. New Testament scholar James Dunn (theologian) writes:\n\n\nReflecting the consensus that Johns use of the term refers strictly to Jewish religious aities, some modern translations, such as Todays New International Version, remove the term "Jews" and replace it with more specific terms to avoid anti-Semitic connotations.<ref>Kierspel, https://books.google.com/books?id=68f2cdlMtfMC&pg=PA14 pp.13-14. For example, the Jesus Seminar translates this as "Js", i.e. residents of J, in contrast to residents of Galilee, a translation which has not found general acceptance.<ref>Frank Sherman and  with Sarah Henrich,Difficult Texts:Interpreting New Testament Images of Jews and Jm, , in Darrell Jodock (ed.), https://books.google.com/books?id=thWFL5KgP24C&pg=PA205 Covenantal Conversations: Christians in Dialogue with Jews and Jm , Fortress Press 2008 pp.76-90  p.205 n.13.\n\n\nSsive generations of Christians read in the Gospel of John the collective g of Jews, rsally and in all generations, in the death of Christ. Johns use of the collective expression "the Jews" is likely explained by the historical circnces in which and ace for which he wrote. With the Siege of Jerm (70), the Jewish priesthood, and thus the class of the Sadd was massacred and thus ceased to exist, due to its role in the First Jewish-Roman War. As John wrote his Gospel after these events, for a gentile ace, he spoke generically of Jews, rather than specifying a group within Jm that no longer existed and that would have been iliar to his readers.<ref name=CatholiCity101>\n\n\nPaul writes in 1 Thessalonians 2:14-16 as follows:\n\n\nThe text appears somewhat anomalous compared to the general tone of thanksgiving, in that we have a diatribe against persec identified as Jews.<ref name="Downey" /> The text appears to flagrantly contradict what Paul writes in chapters 9 to 11 of his Epistle to the Romans. This has led several scholars to qon its aticity, and st that it is an interpolation.<ref>David Lsmeyer,https://books.google.com/books?id=0KuT2qkhtGEC&pg=PA161 The Eschatology of First Thessalonians, Vandenhoeck & Rht, 2013 pp.16fff. According to Pieter Willem van der Horst, there is an instance of antisemitic statements in one of the Pa epistles;<ref name=Pieter1> David Lsmeyer maintains that it was not written with the intent to condemn all Jews, - Pauls letters reveal someone who lived his life within Jm - but did at the same time have an anti-Semitic "effect".<ref>David Lsmeyer. https://books.google.com/books?id=0KuT2qkhtGEC&pg=PA167  pp.167-171. F. F. Bruce called it an indiscriminate anti-Jewish polemic mirroring Graeco-Roman pagan attit to the Jews. Gene Green, Ernest Best,T. Holtz, Amy Downey vario argue that it resonates with Old Testament themes, plays on Jewish fears of being the "privileged people of God" and typical of an argative style shared by Greeks and Jews alike and thus, in Downeys words, exemplifying an intracal clash between Paul the Jew and  Jewish leaders opposing the propagation of Gospel ideas in both J and Thessalonia.<ref name="Downey" >Amy Karen Downey,  https://books.google.com/books?id=15VMAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61 Pauls Conm: Reconciling 1 Thessalonians 2:13-16 and Romans 9:1-5 in Light of His Calling and His Heritage, Wipf and Stock Phers, 2011 pp.61ff,66-7.\n\n\nMost scholars  consider the Epistle to the Hebrews to have been written for Christians who were tempted to return to Jm. Lillian Fren thinks that it in  trying to argue the sority of Christianity to Jm, it twisted Old Testament passages in a way that transmitted an anti-Torah antisemitism. John Gager reads it as a polemic against Jm, not the Jewish people, and regards it as the most important anti-Jing text of early Christianity. Samuel Sandmel asserts that rather than vilifying Jm, or the Jews of that age, the Epistle to the Hebrews is an arg for the sessionism notion that Christianity is the pinnacle of ancient Jm. William L. Lane dismissed the idea that it contains an anti-J polemic, its primary concern being simply to assert that the Old Testament prophecies had been fled. Those who see in its discontins anti-Semitism are wrong William Hagner argued: there may be anti-Jm, but no antagonism for Jews. While it promotes sessionism  it venerates the Hebrew saints, for Donald Bloesch, and therefore what it is exhorting is the replacement of Jewish instits, not Jews. For Timothy Johnson, Christianity had to str to se amid a majority of sects that were not Messianic, and whatever slander there is, is to be stood as the rhetoric of a marginal group against the majority of Jews. Such rhetorical vehemence was common in antiq in religious and philosophical disp.<ref>Lloyd Kim https://books.google.com/books?id=87RLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 Polemic in the Book of Hebrews: Anti-Jm, Anti-Semitism, Sessionism?, Wipf and Stock Phers, 2006 pp.11-16.\n\n\nIn Revelation 2:9 and 3:9 reference is made to a synagogue of Satan (\u03c3\u03c5\u03bd\u03b1\u03b3\u03c9\u03b3\u03ae \u03c4\u03bf\u1fe6 \u03a3\u03b1\u03c4\u03b1\u03bd\u1fb6). \u03c0\u03bf\u03b9\u03ae\u03c3\u03c9 \u03b1\u1f50\u03c4\u03bf\u1f7a\u03c2  \u1f35\u03bd\u03b1 \u1f25\u03be\u03bf\u03c5\u03c3\u03b9\u03bd \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03c0\u03c1\u03bf\u03c3\u03ba\u03c5\u03bd\u03ae\u03c3\u03bf\u03c5\u03c3\u03b9\u03bd \u1f10\u03bd\u03ce\u03c0\u03b9\u03bf\u03bd \u03c4\u1ff6\u03bd \u03c0\u03bf\u03b4\u1ff6\u03bd \u03c3\u03bf\u03c5, \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03b3\u03bd\u1ff6\u03c3\u03b9\u03bd \u1f45\u03c4\u03b9 \u1f10\u03b3\u1f7c \u1f20\u03b3\u03ac\u03c0\u03b7\u03c3\u03ac \u03c3\u03b5.</blockq>\n\nThere is no certainty about who are those claiming falsely  to be Jews:<ref>Bas Wilenga, https://books.google.com/books?id=S0npAyPMzu0C&pg=PA18  Revelation to John: T Into Songs of Moses and the Lamb,   Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge(India), 2009  pp.17 (Smyrna) pp.27 ()Philadelphia) whether they are Jews hostile to Gentiles, Christian Jews persec by a Jewish majority or Gentiles feigning to be Jews.<ref name ="Koester">Craig Koester, https://books.google.com/books?id=31VmBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA271  Revelation: A New Translation with  Introdn and Commentary,   Yale University Press 2014 pp.2711ff.pp.274-276:\u2019Synagogue members at Smyrna presy considered opposition to the ch to be consistent with Israel\u2019s tradition since they tho that Jesuss followers had departed from the tradition by making elevated claims about Jesus. From John\u2019s perspective, however, their attempt to deno Jesus followers-especially when this could lead to imprisonment and death-was incompatible with loyalty to Israels God. For John, those who deno Christians thereby deno the God to whom they bear witness, so he calls it blasphemia. Moreover, the Jews who made such dentions joined forces with civic and provincial aities-who worshiped other gods-in their efforts to have Christians arrested. For John, true Jews woiuld not have collaborated with idolators. Other interpretations are less viable. Some assume that the inatic Jews are Gentile Christians. First, some argue that these Christians keep Jewish cs and affiliate with the synagogue to avoid Roman persec. . .Second, some interpreters hold that the so-called Jews are Christians like Jezebel and Nicolaitans, who might have claimed to be part of the Jewish tradition, even though they eat what has been sacrificed to idols..Other interpretations take the so-called Jews to be non-Christians.\nThe traditional interpretation d  recently by a majority of scholars took this to denote Jews hostile to Christians, and specifically to the Jewish commes of Smyrna (2:9) and Ala\u015fehir (3:9).<ref>Robert H. Mo, https://books.google.com/books?id=lWhyCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT120  The Book of Revelation,  Wm. B. Eerdmans Phing,rev.ed. 1997 p.101.<ref>Adela Yarbro Collins,https://books.google.com/books?id=Rw9e2DfVxiEC&pg=PA85 Crisis and Catharsis: The Power of the Apocalypse,  Westminster John Knox Press, 1984 pp85ff.<ref>Steve Friesen, https://books.google.com/books?id=zHLZob88C44C&pg=PA134  \u2019Sarcasm in Revelations 2-3,\u2019 in David L. Barr (ed.),  https://books.google.com/books?id=zHLZob88C44C&pg=PA153 The Reality of Apocalypse: Rhetoric and Politics in the Book of Revelation, Society of Biblical Lit, 2006 pp.127-144 p.134.  In the Smyrna passage, according to Koester,  those claiming to be Jews probably bore in their traits the  markers of kinship, circion, dietary restriction and Sabbath observance, but  are taken  to task for denog the Christian comm to the Roman aities to get them arrested.<ref name ="Koester" />\n\nThis has recently been qoned by Elaine Pagels, David Frankf, Heinrich Kraft and  John W. Marshall. Pagels, reviewing the literature, argues that the a of Revelations, John of Patmos, was himself a Jew devoted to Christ, saw himself as a Jew, not a Christian. Unlike the other evangelists who blame Jews for Christ\u2019s death, the a of Revelations, drawing on old patterns of late Jewish eschatology, assigns responsibility for his death to Romans and  says they are abetted by an internal enemy who feign to be God\u2019s people while acting as agents of Satan, a theme also present in the literature of the Q Dead Sea Scrolls. Pagels identifies most of  these internal enemies as converts to the Paul the Apostle Pa Christianity prevailing among gentiles. Taken literally the passage at Revelations 3:9 would refer to Gentiles ging Jewish followers of Jesus, feigning to be more Jewish than Jews themselves. Paul Duff on the other hand  ass they are Jews, like John himself, but Jews who are hostile to the Jesus movement. David Frankf has revived the old arg of Ferdinand Christian Baur by endorsing the view that in fact the members of Satans synagogue are mostly Gentiles, claiming Israels legacy while rebg religious practices that are obligatory for Jews. Even those who, like David Aune, consider that the phrase indicates Jews, not Gentiles, allow that the Books of Revelations is virt devoid of traces of the polemics between Christians and Jews typical of those times. Pagels  concl that the evidence weighs in favour of reading the synagogue of Satan as referring to gentile converts to the Pa version of the Jesus movement, who denominate themselves as those of Christ/Christians, a terminology never  by John of Patmos.<ref>Elaine Pagels https://books.google.com/books?id=_1knBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA9  \u2018The Social History of Satan:John of Patmos and Ignatius of Antioch:Contrasting Visions of \u201cGod\u2019s People\u201d,\u2019 in Kirsten Stirling, Martine Hennard Dl de la Roch\xe8re   (eds.) After Satan: Essays in Honour of Neil Forsyth,  Cambridge Scholars Phing, 2010 pp.7-28 pp.9ff.pp.14ff.<ref>Paul Duff, https://books.google.com/books?id=zHLZob88C44C&pg=PA153 The \u2018Synagogue of Satan\u2019: Crisis Mongering and the Apocalypse of John,\u2019 in David L. Barr (ed.), The Reality of Apocalypse: Rhetoric and Politics in the Book of Revelation, Society of Biblical Lit, 2006 pp.147-168 p.153.<ref>Elaine Pagels, https://books.google.com/books?id=-33IVLAc6dkC&pg=PT57 Revelations: Visions, Prophecy, and Politics in the Book of Revelation,  Penguin, 2012 pp.64-65:\u2019By the time John of Patmos traveled to Asia Minor, then, he found many followers of Paul who apparently ass that even  groups consisting largely of Gentile converts had now, in effect, become Jews. No wonder, then, that when John heard of such people who \u201csay they are Jews, and are not, but are lying,\u201d he found their claims oeous. ..John reass  those who really are  Jews that Jesus has promised that when he comes back. Distressed as he was by such people, John could hardly have imagined what he might have seen as the greatest identity theft of all time: that event Gentile believers not only would call themselves Israel but would claim to be the sole rightful heirs to the legacy of God\u2019s chosen people.\u2019\n\nIt has been argued that the idea of a Jewish Antichrist developed from these verses.<ref>Walter Laq , https://books.google.com/books?id=8GHc5xtXD5UC&pg=PA47 "The Changing Face of Anti-Semitism: From Ancient Times to the Present Day, " Oxford University Press, 2006  pp.46\u201347<ref name="Timesofcrisis">Moshe Lazar, https://books.google.com/books?id=bzUTCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA45   \u2018The Lamb and the Scapegoat: The Dehzation of Jews in Medieval Propaganda,\u2019 in  Sander Gilman,  Steven T. Katz (eds.) "Anti-Semitism in Times of Crisis, " New York University Press  1991 pp.38-79 pp.45-46\n\n\nIn the decree Nostra aetate in 1965, Pope Paul VI declared that \n<blockq>"True, the Jewish aities and those who followed their lead pressed for the death of Christ; still, what happened in His passion cannot be charged against all the Jews, without distinction, then alive, nor against the Jews of today. Although the Ch is the new people of God, the Jews should not be presented as rejected or acc by God, as if this followed from the Holy Script."<ref>Jeremy Cohen, https://books.google.com/books?id=83FjAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA168 Christ Killers: the Jews and the Passion from the Bible to the Big Screen, Oxford University Press 2007 p.168.<ref>David Cymet,https://books.google.com/books?id=Pp7DZigCaDcC&pg=PA449 History Vs. Apologetics: The Holocaust, the Third Reich, and the Catholic Ch, Lexington Books 2010 p.449.</blockq>\n\nNorman Beck, professor of theology and classical lang at Texas Lan University, has proposed that Christian lectionary remove what he calls "\u2026 the specific texts identified as most problematic \u2026". Beck identifies what he deems to be offensive passages in the New Testament and indicates the instances in which these texts or portions thereof are incl in major lectionary series.\n\nDaniel Goldhagen, former Associate Professor of Political Science at Harvard University, also sted in his book A Moral Reckoning that the Roman Catholic Ch should change its doctrine and the accepted Biblical canon to excise statements he labels as antisemitic,- he co some 450 such passages in the Synoptic Gospels and Acts of the Apostles alone<ref>Lars Kierspel, \nhttps://books.google.com/books?id=68f2cdlMtfMC&pg=PA7 The Jews and the World in the Fo Gospel: Parallelism, Fon, and Context, :de:Mohr Siebeck Verlag 2006 p.5 citing D. Goldhagen,A Moral Reckoning, pp.263-265.-to indicate that "The Jews way to God is as legitimate as the Christian way".<ref name="Shoah">\n\n\n* Anti-Jm in early Christianity\n* Christian\u2013Jewish reconciliation\n* Christianity and Jm\n* Origins of Christianity\n\n\n* Fren, Lillian C.
