Row(id=38424, title=u'Bikram Yoga', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\nBikram Yoga is a system of yoga that Bikram Choy synthesized from traditional hatha yoga techniques and popzed beginning in the early 1970s.<ref>http://wiki4yoga.blogspot.com/2014/03/corporate-registration-for-bikram.html Corporate registration for "Bikram Choy Yoga, Inc." N: C2288343<ref name=Forbes> All Bikram Yoga Beginning Series classes run for 90 min and consist of the same series of 26 post, incl two breathing exercises. Bikram Yoga is a hot yoga style, and is ideally practiced in a room heated to  with a hty of 40%.<ref name="Bikram Yoga Basic"> All official Bikram classes are ta by Bikram-certified teachers, who have completed nine weeks of training endorsed by Choy. Bikram-certified teachers are ta a standardized dialogue to run the class, but are encod to develop their teaching skills the longer they teach. This res in varying deliveries and distinct teaching styles.<ref name="Bikram Yoga Basic"/>\nFile:Bikram teaching.jpg|thumb|Bikram Choy leading a class, for Bikram yoga, at the L.A. Convention Center in 2003.\n\n\nBikram Choy, fo of the Bikram Yoga system, is also the fo of the Yoga College of India. Born in Calc in 1944, Choy began practicing yoga at age four. He stated that he practiced yoga 4\u20136 hours every day. At the age of thirteen, he asserts that he won the National India Yoga Championship and was eated for the following three years and retired as the p All-India National Yoga Champion.\n . \n\nChoy later devised the 26 post seq and fo Bikrams Yoga College of India. He has also written books and sings.\n\nAs of 2006, he had 1,650 yoga st around the world.\n\n\nA 2015 review found that one randomized controlled clinical trial has been cond,  21 healthy sts with a mean age of 27; the study was too small to draw generalizations from but the people in the study arm had mildly improved strength and flexibility.\n\nA 2013 review of adverse effects from yoga found that Pranayama and Bikram were the most commonly cited styles, and found harm arising mostly in instrs who practiced intensely over a long period of time and who  advanced positions like handstands; in Bikram most of the adverse events arose from the heat and incl hyponatriaemia due to excessive water drinking and sweating.\n\n\n\n\n\nOne controversial component of Bikram Yoga pertains to the prevalence of Yoga Asana Championships, regionally and nationally. While practitioners of other forms of yoga maintain that competition contradicts the idea of peace and , Choy contends, "Competition is the foion for all democratic societies. For without Competition, there is no democracy."<ref>http://www.bikramyoga.com Official website\n\nIn India, where yoga originated, yoga competitions have been around for over a century.\n\n\n\nChoy has claimed that Bikram Yoga is  copyright and that it could not be ta or presented by anyone whom he had not aized. Choy began making those claims in 2011. In 2011 Choy started a lawsuit against Yoga to the People, a competing yoga st fo by a former st of Choys and with a location near one of the Bikram Yoga st in New York. Choy lost at first instance, and appealed the decision, with the Court of Appeal dismissing his copyright claim over yoga poses in Bikram Yoga.\n\nAs a result of that lawsuit, the United States Copyright Office issued a clarification that yoga post (asanas) could not be copyrighted in the way claimed by Choy, and that Yoga to the People and others could continue to freely teach these exercises.\n\n\nHBOs Real Sports with Bryant G aired a segment about Choy in which they showed and spoke to people about his infamous and grg teacher training programs. His behavior incl sleep deprivation, sho, name-calling, and ridic over participants weight, size or ability.\n\nSome q from their interview with him:\n\nOn Bikram Yoga and Choy\u2019s methods:\n\nBikram Choy: \u201cThis yoga worse than cocaine. Because you can get rid of cocaine, but once you  to this yoga, you can\u2019t stop. Because nothing in this world makes you feel better than this yoga.\u201d\n\nBikram Choy: \u201cI try to kill them. They don\u2019t die. I own\u2013 I torture them.\u201d\nHBO\u2019s Andrea Kremer:  \u201cAnd you have to do that? You have to torture them?\u201d\nBikram Choy: \u201cI love it.\u201d\n\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cWhat are some of the r that you have?\u201d\nBikram Choy: \u201cN one: You have to forget who you are.\u201d\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cYou\u2019ve even said something along the lines of, \u2018I implant my mind in your brain.\u2019\u201d\nBikram Choy: \u201cYes. My way or highway. You don\u2019t like it? Get the fuck out of here.\u201d\n\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cYou can be pretty harsh. You never have any regrets about any of the things that you say?\u201d\nBikram Choy: \u201cOf co not. Why should I? I have to yell, scream, shout. \u2018You fat ass. What the fuck\u2019s wrong with you? What\u2019s wrong with you? You don\u2019t listen to me. You dumb\u2013 you dumb fuck.\u2019 Because she doesn\u2019t listen.\u201d\n\nOn Bikram Yoga\u2019s near-mirac powers:\n\nBikram Choy: \u201cI cure Parkinson\u2019s disease, AIDS, cancer. Doctor knows very little about h body.\u201d\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cYou know more than doctors?\u201d\nBikram Choy: \u201cMillion times, billion times. I teach doctors. I don\u2019t go to doctors. Every doctor in the world, they come to me.\u201d\n\n\nTwo laws acc Choy of rape were filed in May 2013, in which a Jane Doe alleges sexual battery, false imprisonment, discrimination, harassment, and other co in addition to the rape allegation. It describes a cult-like atmosphere where Choys followers help him find young women to assault. "Other persons in defendant Bikram Choys inner circle, were aware of defendant Bikram Choys pattern and practice of ca, ind or persg young women to enroll in teacher training classes to become yoga instrs only so he can sex assault and/or rape them," the lawsuit claims.\n\nThe s paint a cult-like atmosphere at the training camps. Trainees were allegedly told that Choy is on the same level as Jesus Christ or Ga B, that Bikram yoga can cure cancer and that practitioners will be able to live to 100 years old. Trainees were bd and hated as well as praised, the s say, and Choy allegedly gave lect in which he disparaged gays, Americans and made ethnic slurs. Jane Doe 2 claims that Choy recr volrs from overseas who are "so in fear of defendant Bikram Choys wrath that they will travel to the US and risk violating immigration laws in order to serve him. Once in the US these volrs work for little or zero pay. "Their d include grooming him, massaging him, making his tea, bringing him food and being forced to s to sexual assa and rapes against their will," the suit alleges.\n\nMinakshi "Micki"Jafa-Bodden served as Head of Legal and International Affairs from Spring 2011 to March 13, 2013 when she claims she was "abr and f terminated" according to the court docs filed on July 12, 2013 in the Sor Court of California, Los Angeles. But perhaps the more serious matters lie within the 2 years that Jafa-Bodden worked closely with Choy, d which she claims she was victim and witness to Choys "severe, ongoing, pervasive and offensive conduct" especially to women, as well as homosex, African Americans and basically every other minority. The complaint is the fo sex-based discrimination/sexual harassment/rape related suit filed this year against Choy.\n\nBikram teacher Sarah Ba filed a sexual harassment suit in March (just before Jafa-Bodden was fired), and two other ed women filed similar s acc Choy of sexual harassment, intimidation and rape in May.  Shea Law Offices and Shegerian & Associates, the attorneys representing Ba, now represent a total of six women claiming Bikram sex assa and/or raped them.\n\nIn April 2015, the accons raised larger qons in the yoga comm, incl an article by the Washington Post "asking whether its wise to put so much faith in a guru".\n\nA 18, 2015, Petra Starke who was his attorney, President and CEO from 3/2013 to 1/2015 filed a complaint in the Sor Court of California, Co of Los Angeles (A6037-90064). This complaint alleged nine issues incl breach of contract, wrongful termination and failure to prevent discrimination and harassment.\n\nOctober 25, 2016 HBOs Real Sports with Bryant G airs an interview with Choy at one of his training programs in India. Correspondent Andrea Kremer also interviews three women who accuse him of raping them.\n\nQ from their interviews:\n\nJill Lawler: \u201cI felt so disgg, but I just did what he told me to do, which was basically, like, man jerk him off.  I hated doing it.  But I felt like I owed him, you know? I felt like I owed him for, like, my life.\u201d\n\nJill Lawler: \u201cHe hurt me, he assa me.\u201d\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cBikram forced you to have sex?\u201d\nJill Lawler: \u201cYeah.\u201d\n\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cWhat do you think made you vable to him?\u201d\nJill Lawler: \u201cLike, he was my guru. He wa\u2013 I can\u2019t even explain. Like, I really, really loved him. You know? I really, really did.\u201d\nMaggie Genthner: \u201cHe p me on the bed.  I\u2019m, like, screaming like, \u2018No. Stop.  Don\u2019t do this.  Please don\u2019t do this.\u2019  And he starts calling me an idiot, just over and over again. And then he penetrates me and I scream, \u2018You\u2019re hg me.  You\u2019re hg me.\u2019  I screamed it. And he replies, \u2018It\u2019s sed to hurt.\u2019 All of a s, like, the veil lifts, the veil of who I think this person is.\u201d\n\nSarah Ba: \u201cI wanted to kill myself. I tried several times to kill myself.\u201d\n\nSarah Ba:  \u201cHe was in charge of all of these people, all of whom just sat and listened and la and appla and regarded him as yoga god. People stand up for this person really no matter what.\u201d\n\n\nThe following are the 26 post of Bikram Yoga. These are ta in the Beginning Bikram Yoga Class. Row(id=45425, title=u'Smart growth', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nSmart growth is an   planning and transportation planning theory that concentrates growth in compact walkable  centers to avoid  sprawl. It also advocates compact, transit-oriented development, pedestrian-friendly, bicycle-friendly land use, incl neighborhood schools, complete streets, and mixed-use development with a range of ho choices.<ref name="berkeley"> The term smart growth is particy  in North America. In E and particy the UK, the terms Compact City or  intensification have often been  to describe similar concepts, which have infld government planning policies in the UK, the Netherlands and several other Ean coes.\n\nSmart growth values long-range, regional considerations of snability over a short-term focus. Its snable development goals are to achieve a e sense of comm and place; expand the range of transportation, employment, and ho choices; eqly distribute the costs and benefits of development; preserve and enhance nat and cal reso; and promote p health.\n\n\nSmart Growth is a theory of land development that accepts that growth and development will continue to occur, and so seeks to direct that growth in an intentional, comprehensive way. Its proponents include  planners, architects, developers, comm activists, and historic preservationists. The term "Smart Growth" is an attempt to reframe the conversation from "growth" versus "no growth" (or NIMBY) to good/smart growth versus bad/dumb growth. Proponents seek to disting Smart Growth from  sprawl which they claim ca most of the problems that fuel opposition to  growth, such as traffic congestion and environmental degradation.  Smart growth principles are directed at developing snable commes that provide a greater range of transportation and ho choices and prioritize infill and redevelopment in existing commes rather than development of "greenfield" farmland or nat lands. Some of the fental aims for the benefits of residents and the commes are increasing family income and wealth, providing safe walking ro to schools, fostering livable, safe and healthy places, stimng economic activity (both locally and regionally), and developing, preserving and investing in b and nat reso.\nSmart growth "principles" describe the elements of comm that are envisioned and smart growth "regons" describe the various approaches to implementation, that is, how federal, state, and mpal governments choose to fl smart growth principles. Some of these regry approaches such as Urban Growth Boy predate the use of the term Smart Growth.  One of the earliest efforts to establish smart growth forward as an explicit regry framework were put forth by the American Planning Association. In 1997, the APA introd a project called Growing Smart and phed "Growing Smart Legislative Gook: Model Stat for Planning and the Management of Change."  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency defines smart growth as \u201cdevelopment that serves the economy, the comm, and the environment. It changes the terms of the development debate away from the traditional growth/no growth qon to how and where should new development be accommodated\u201d \n\nSmart growth is related to, or may be  in combination with the following concepts:\n* New Urbanism\n* Growth management\n* New Comm Design\n* Snable Development\n* Reso Stewardship\n* Land Preservation\n* Preventing  sprawl\n* Creating sense of place\n* Development Best Practices\n* Preservation development\n* Snable transport\n* Triple Bottom Line (TBL) Accog - People, Planet, Profit\n* The Three Pillars - H, Nat, and Created Capital\n\nThe smart growth approach to development is maceted and can encompass a variety of techniques. For example, in the state of Massachs smart growth is enacted by a combination of techniques incl increasing ho density along transit nodes, conserving farm land, and mixing residential and commercial use areas. Perhaps the most descriptive term to characterize this concept is Traditional Neighborhood Development, which recognizes that smart growth and related concepts are not necessarily new, but are a response to car ce and sprawl.  Many favor the term New Urbanism, which invokes a new, but traditional way of looking at  planning.\n\nThere are a range of best practices associated with smart growth, these include: sting existing commes, redeveloping zed sites, enhancing economic competitiveness, providing more transportation choices, developing livability meas and tools, promoting eqle and affordable ho, providing a vision for snable growth, enhancing integrated planning and investment, aligning, coordinating, and leveraging government polices, redefining ho affordability and making the development process transparent.\n\nRelated, but somewhat different, are the overarching goals of smart growth, and they include: making the comm more competitive for new bsses, providing alternative places to shop, work, and play, creating a better "Sense of Place," providing jobs for residents, increasing property values, improving qy of life, expanding the tax base, preserving open space, controlling growth, and improving safety.\n\n\nThere are 10 accepted principles that define smart growth:\n# Mix land \n# Take advantage of compact bng design\n# Create a range of ho opportes and choices\n# Create walkable neighborhoods\n# Foster distinctive, attractive commes with a strong sense of place\n# Preserve open space, farmland, nat beauty, and critical environmental areas\n# Strengthen and direct development towards existing commes\n# Provide a variety of transportation choices\n# Make development decisions predictable, fair, and cost effective\n# Enco comm and stakeholder collaboration in development decisions\n\n\nTransportation and comm planners began to promote the idea of compact cities and commes and adopt many of the regry approaches associated with Smart Growth in the early 1970s. The cost and diffic of acqg land (particy in historic and/or areas designated as conservancies) to b and widen highways ca some politicians to reconsider basing transportation planning on motor vehicles.\n\nThe Congress for the New Urbanism, with architect Peter Calthorpe promoted and popzed the idea of  villages that relied on p transportation, bicycling, and walking instead of abile use. Architect Andr\xe9s D promoted changing design codes to promote a sense of comm, and to disco driving. Colin Ban and Stephen Plowden helped to lead the debate in the United Kingdom.\n\nThe Local Government Commission which presents the annual New Partners for Smart Growth conference adopted the original Ahwahnee Principles in 1991 which artics many of the major principles now generally accepted as part of smart growth movement such as Transit oriented development, a focus on walking distance, greenbelts and wildlife corridors, and infill and redevelopment. The doc was co-aed by several of the fos of the New Urbanist movement. The Local Government Commission has been co-sponsoring Smart Growth related conferences since 1997. The New Partners for Smart Growth Conference started  that name circa 2002.<ref name="newpartners.org">http://www.newpartners.org/about/about-the-event\n\nSmart Growth America, an organization devoted to the promoting Smart Growth in the United States, was fo in 2002. This organization leads an evolving coalition of  national and regional organizations most of which predated its fog such as 1000 Friends of Oregon fo in 1975 and the Congress for the New Urbanism fo in 1993. The EPA lad its smart growth program in 1995.<ref name="newpartners.org"/>\n\n\nSmart growth is an alternative to  sprawl, traffic congestion, disconnected neighborhoods, and  decay. Its principles challenge old assons in  planning, such as the value of detached ho and abile use.\n\n\nEnvironmentalists promote smart growth by advocating -growth boies, or Green belts, as they have been termed in England since the 1930s.\n\n\nTransit-oriented development can improve the qy of life and enco a healthier, pedestrian-based lifestyle with less poll. The United States Environmental Protection Agency sts Smart growth to reduce air poll.\n\n\nSmart Growth advocates claim that much of the  sprawl of the 19th Century was due to government sies for infrastre that redistribute the true costs of sprawl. Examples include sies for highway bng, fossil f, and electricity.\n\n\nWith electricity, there is a cost associated with extending and maintaining the service delivery system, as with water and sewage, but there also is a loss in the commodity being delivered. The farther from the generator, the more power is lost in distrib. According to the United States Department of Energys (DOE) Energy Information Administration (EIA), 9 percent of energy is lost in transmission.\n\nCt average cost pricing, where cers pay the same price per  of power regardless of the true cost of their service, sizes sprawl development. With electricity deregon, some states now charge cers/developers fees for extending distrib to new locations rather than rolling such costs into ty rates.<ref>http://www.ornl.gov/sci/btc/apps/Restring/tm2003_152.pdf ornl.gov\n\nNew Jersey, for example, has implemented a plan that divides the state into five planning areas, some of which are designated for growth, while others are protected. The state is developing a series of incentives to coax local governments into changing zoning laws that will be compatible with the state plan. The New Jersey Board of P Utilities recently proposed a revised rule that presents a tiered approach to ty financing. In areas not designated for growth, ties and their ratepayers are forbidden to cover the costs of extending ty lines to new developments\u2014and developers will be req to pay the full cost of p ty infrastre. In designated growth areas that have local smart plans endorsed by the State Planning Commission, developers will be ref the cost of extending ty lines to new developments at two times the rate of the revenue received by developers in smart growth areas that do not have approved plans.<ref>http://www.nj.gov/dca/osg/ nj.gov\n\n\nGrowth is "smart growth", to the extent that it incl the elements listed below.<ref name="berkeley"/><ref>http://www.smartgrowth.org/about/default.asp smartgrowth.org<ref>http://www.epa.gov/smartgrowth/about_sg.htm epa.gov\n\n\nCompact, livable  neighborhoods attract more people and bss.  Creating such neighborhoods is a critical element of red  sprawl and protecting the climate. Such a tactic incl adopting redevelopment strategies and zoning policies that channel ho and job growth into  centers and neighborhood bss districts, to create compact, walkable, and bike- and transit-friendly hubs. This sometimes req local governmental bodies to implement code changes that allow increased height and density downtown and regons that not only eliminate minimum parking reqents for new development but establish a maximum n of allowed spaces. Other topics fall  this concept:\n* mixed-use development\n* incl of affordable ho\n* restrictions or limitations on san design forms (e.g., house on individual lots, strip malls and se parking lots)\n* incl of parks and recreation areas\n\nIn snable architecture the recent movements of New Urbanism and New Classical Architecture promote a snable approach towards constrn, that appreciates and develops smart growth, Vernac architecture and Classical architecture.<ref>http://www.cnu.org/charter Charter of the New Urbanism This in contrast to Modern architecture and International Style (architecture) architecture, as well as leaning against solitary ho estates and Urban sprawl.<ref>http://www.aia.org/SiteObjects/files/smartgrowth05.pdf Issue Brief: Smart-Growth: Bng Livable Commes. American Institute of Architects. Retrieved on 2014-03-23. Both trends started in the 1980s.\n\n\nTransit-oriented development (TOD) is a residential or commercial area designed to maximize access to p transport, and mixed-use/compact neighborhoods tend to use transit at all times of the day.\n Many cities striving to implement better TOD strategies seek to secure fg to create new p transportation infrastre and improve existing services. Other meas might include regional cooperation to increase efficiency and expand services, and moving b and trains more freqy through high-use areas. Other topics fall  this concept:\n* Transportation Demand Management meas\n* road pricing system (tolling)\n* commercial parking taxes\n\n\nBiking and walking instead of driving can reduce emissions, save money on fuel and maintenance, and foster a healthier popon. Pedestrian- and bicycle-friendly improvements include bike lanes on main streets, an  bike-trail system, bike parking, pedestrian crossings, and associated master plans. The most pedestrian- and bike-friendly variant of smart growth and New Urbanism is New Pedestrianism because motor vehicles are on a separate grid.\n\n\n* preserving open space and critical habitat, re land, and protecting water ses and air qy\n* transparency (hties), predictable, fair and cost-effective r for development\n* historic preservation\n* Setting aside large areas where development is prohibited, nature is able to run its co, providing fresh air and clean water.\n* Expansion around already existing areas allows p services to be located where people are living without taking away from the core city neighborhoods in large  areas.\n* Developing around preexisting areas decreases the socioeconomic segregation allowing society to fon more eqly, generating a tax base for ho, edonal and employment programs.\n\n\n\n\nThe most widely  tool for achieving smart growth is modification of local zoning laws. Zoning laws are applicable to most cities and cos in the United States. Smart Growth advocates often seek to modify zoning ordinances to increase the density of development and redevelopment allowed in or near existing towns and neighborhoods and/or restrict new development in ong or environmentally sensitive areas. Additional density incentives can be offered for development of brownfield land and greyfield land or for providing amenities such as parks and open space. Zoning ordinances typically include minimum parking reqents. Redns in or elimination of parking minimums or imposition of parking maximums can also reduce the amount of parking b with new development increasing land available for parks and other comm amenities.\n\n\nRelated to zoning ordinances, an Urban Growth Boy (UGB) is a tool that  in some U.S. cities to contain high density development to certain areas. The first  growth boy in the United States was established in 1958 in Kent. Sy,  growth boies were established in Oregon in the 1970s and Florida in 1980s.  Some believe that UGBs contrib to the escalation of ho prices from 2000 to 2006, as they limited the s of developable land.<ref>http://econjwatch.org/articles/constraints-on-ho-s-nat-and-regry/ Cox, Wendell. "Constraints on Ho S: Nat and Regry," Econ Jo Watch 8(1), 13-27. However, this is not completely sntiated because prices continued to rise even after mpalities expanded their growth boies.\n\n\n\nTransfer of development rights systems are intended to allow property owners in areas deemed desirable for growth (such as infill and brownfield sites) to pse the right to b at higher densities from owners of properties in areas deemed irable for growth such as environmental lands, farmlands or lands oe of an  growth boy. Areas that have implemented transfer of development rights include several cos in Maryland (as early as 1978) and St. L Co.\n\n\nSystematic provision of infrastre such as schools, libraries, sporting facilities and comm facilities is an integral component of smart growth commes. This is commonly known as social infrastre or comm infrastre. In Alia, for example, most new san developments are master planned, and key social infrastre is planned at the o.\n\n\nOne pop approach to assist in smart growth in democratic coes is for lawmakers to req prospective developers to prepare environmental impact assessments of their plans as a condition for state and/or local governments to give them bng permit to b their bngs. These reports often indicate how significant impacts generated by the development will be Environmental mitigation, the cost of which is ly paid by the developer. These assessments are freqy controversial. Conservationists, neighborhood advocacy groups and NIMBYs are often skeptical about such impact reports, even when they are prepared by independent agencies and sy approved by the decision makers rather than the promoters. Conversely, developers will sometimes strongly resist being req to implement the mitigation meas req by the local government as they may be q costly.\n\nIn commes practicing these smart growth policies, developers comply with local codes and reqents. Conseqy, developer compliance b comm trust because it demonstrates a gen interest in the environmental qy of the comm.\n\n\n\n\nThe United States Environmental Protection Agency<ref name=epa>http://www.epa.gov/smartgrowth/awards.htm epa.gov has recognized these cities for implementing smart growth principles:\n* Arlington, Virginia<ref name=epa/>\n* Minneapolis and Saint Paul, Minnesota, Minnesota<ref name=epa/>\n* Davidson, North Carolina<ref name=epa/>\n* Denver, Colorado<ref name=epa/>\n\nThe smart growth Network has recognized these U.S. cities for implementing smart growth principles:<ref>http://www.smartgrowthonlinea.org/pdf/TISG_2006_8-5x11.pdf smartgrowthonlinea.org\n* The Kentlands; Gaithersburg, Maryland (for live-work )\n* East Liberty (Pittsb); Pittsb, Pennsylvania (establishing downtown retail)\n* Moore Sq Ms Magnet Middle School; Raleigh, North Carolina (for being located downtown)\n* Garfield Park; Chicago, Illinois(retaining transit options)\n* M Park; St. Louis, Missouri (bringing the feat of san living to the city)\n* Pine Barrens (New Jersey), Son New Jersey (for transfer of development rights away from eloped land)\n* Chesterfield Township, New Jersey (for township wide transfer of development rights away from forest and farmland and development of the several hd acre New Urbanism comm of Old York Village.\n\nIn July 2011, The Atlantic magazine called the BeltLine, a series of ho, trail, and transit projects along a 22-mile (35-km) long dis rail corridor snding the core of  Atlanta, the United States "most ambitious smart growth project".<ref>https://www.theatlantic.com/life/archive/2011/07/the-cos-most-ambitious-smart-growth-project/242549/ Kaid Benfield, "The Cos Most Ambitious Smart Growth Project", The Atlantic, July 26, 2011\n\nIn Savannah, Georgia (US) the historic Oglethorpe Plan has been shown to contain most of the elements of smart growth in its network of wards, each of which has a central civic sq.  The plan has demonstrated its resilience to changing conditions, and the city is  the plan as a model for growth in newer areas.\n\nIn Melbo, Alia, almost all new o-san developments are master planned, g by the principles of smart growth.\n\n\nWhether smart growth (or the Compact City) does or can reduce problems of abile dependency associated with  sprawl have been fiercely contested issues over several decades. A 2007 meta-study by Keith Barthomomew of the University of Utah found that redns in driving associated with compact development scenarios averaged 8 percent ranging up to 31.7 percent with the variation being explained by degree of land use mixing and density. An inflal study in 1989 by Peter Newman (environmental scientist) and Jeff Kenworthy compared 32 cities across North America, Alia, E and Asia.<ref>:File:Petrol use  density.svg  The study has been criticised for its methodology  but the main finding that denser cities, particy in Asia, have lower car use than sprawling cities, particy in North America, has been largely accepted \u2014 although the relationship is clearer at the extremes across continents than it is within coes where conditions are more similar.\n\nWithin cities st from across many coes (mainly in the developed world) have shown that denser  areas with greater mixture of land use and better p transport tend to have lower car use than less dense san and ex- residential areas.  This ly holds true even after controlling for socio-economic factors such as differences in hold composition and income.  This does not necessarily imply that san sprawl ca high car use, however.  One confog factor, which has been the st of many st, is residential self-selection:<ref>http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/title~db=all~content=g910669635 Transport Reviews Volume 29 Issue 3 (2009) was entirely devoted to this issue people who prefer to drive tend to move towards low density ss, whereas people who prefer to walk, cycle or use transit tend to move towards higher density  areas, better served by p transport.  Some st have found that, when self-selection is controlled for, the b environment has no significant effect on travel behaviour.\n\n\nReviewing the evidence on  intensification, smart growth and their effects on travel behaviour Melia et al. (2011) found st for the args of both sters and opponents of smart growth.  Planning policies which increase popon densities in  areas do tend to reduce car use, but the effect is a weak one, so dog the popon density of a partic area will not halve the freq or distance of car use.\n\nFor example, Portland, Oregon a U.S. city which has pd smart growth policies, sntially increased its popon density between 1990 and 2000 when other US cities of a similar size were red in density.  As predicted by the paradox, traffic vol and congestion both increased more rapidly than in the other cities, despite a sntial increase in transit use.\n\nThese findings led them to propose the paradox of intensification, which states "Ceteris paribus,  intensification which increases popon density will reduce per capita car use, with benefits to the global environment, but will also increase concentrations of motor traffic, worsening the local environment in those locations where it occurs".\n\nAt the citywide level it may be possible, through a range of positive meas to coact the increases in traffic and congestion which would otherwise result from increasing popon densities: Freiburg im Breisgau in Germany is one example of a city which has been more ssful in this respect.\n\nThis study also reviewed evidence on the local effects of bng at higher densities.  At the level of the neighbod or individual development positive meas (e.g. improvements to p transport) will ly be insient to coact the traffic effect of increasing popon density.  This leaves policy-makers with four choices: intensify and accept the local conseqs, sprawl and accept the wider conseqs, a compromise with some element of both, or intensify accompanied by more radical meas such as parking restrictions, closing roads to traffic and carfree zones.  Where possible, this is the as preferred option.\n\nIn contrast the City of Cambridge, Massachs reported that its Kendall Sq Neighborhood saw a 40% increase in commercial space attended by a traffic decrease of 14%.\n\nA report by CEOs for Cities report, "Driven Apart," showed that while denser cities in the United States may have more congested comm they are also shorter on average in both time and distance. This is in contrast to cities where comm face less congestion but drive longer distances resg in comm that take as long or longer.\n\n\n* Edward L. Glaeser<ref>http://www.hks.harvard.edu/var/ezp_site/storage/fckeditor/file/pdfs/centers-programs/centers/ta/skilledcities.pdf<ref>http://www.planetizen.com/node/56661<ref>http://crankyhermit.blogspot.ca/2012/03/will-zappos-tarnish-their-ce-with.html\n* Rollin Stanley\n\n\nRobert Brnn, professor of art history, architecture, and  planning at the University of Illinois at Chicago and a of Sprawl: A Compact History, stated that historical attempts to combat  sprawl have failed, and that the high popon density of Los Angeles, ctly the most dense  area in the United States, "lies at the root of many of the woes experienced by L.A. today."\n\nWendell Cox is a vocal opponent of smart growth policies. He argued before the United States Senate Committee on Environment and P Works that, "smart growth strategies tend to intensify the very problems they are pted to solve."<ref>Wendell Cox,  http://www.heritage.org/Research/SmartGrowth/Test051502.cfm Dangers of Smart Growth Planning, Testimony before the Senate Committee on Environment and P Works, The Heritage Foion, May 15, 2002  Cox and Joshua Utt analyzed smart growth and sprawl, and argued that:<ref>Wendell Cox and Joshua Utt, http://www.heritage.org/Research/SmartGrowth/bg1770.cfm The Costs of Sprawl Reconsidered: What the Data Really Show, Heritage Foion Backgro #1770, The Heritage Foion, June 25, 2004\n\n<blockq>Our analysis indicates that the Ct Urban Planning Assons are of virt no value in predicting local government expendit per capita. The lowest local government expendit per capita are not in the higher density, slower growing, and older mpalities.\n\nOn the contrary, the actual data indicate that the lowest expendit per capita tend to be in medium- and lower-density mpalities (though not the lowest density); medium- and faster-growing mpalities; and newer mpalities. This is after 50 years of cedented  decentralization, which seems to be more than enough time to have developed the pted  sprawl-related higher local government expendit. It seems ely that the higher expendit that did not develop due to sprawl in the last 50 years will evolve in the next 20 year, despite predictions to the contrary in The Costs of Sprawl 2000 research.\n\nIt seems much more likely that the differences in mpal expendit per capita are the result of political, rather than economic factors, especially the infl of special interests.</blockq>\n\nThe phrase "smart growth" implies that other growth and development theories are not "smart". There is debate about whether transit-proximate development constit smart growth when it is not transit-oriented. The National Motorists Association does not object to smart growth as a whole, but strongly objects to traffic calming, which is intended to reduce abile accidents and fatalities,\n\nIn 2002 the National Center for P Policy Research, a self-described Conservatism in the United States think tank, phed an economic study entitled "Smart Growth and Its Effects on Ho Markets: The New Segregation" which termed smart growth "restricted growth" and sted that smart growth policies disfavor minorities and the poor by driving up ho prices.<ref>Randall J. Pozdena,  http://www.nationalcenter.org/NewSegregation.pdf Smart Growth and its Effects on Ho Markets: The New Segregation, QEcon, Inc., phed by the National Center for P Policy Research, November 2002\n\nSome Libertarianism groups, such as the Cato Institute, criticize smart growth on the gro that it leads to greatly increased land values, and people with average incomes can no longer afford to buy ho.<ref>Randal OToole, http://www.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/serials/files/regon/2001/10/otoole.pdf "The Folly of "Smart Growth"", Regon (magazine), Fall 2001\n\nA n of Ecological economics claim that indal civilization has already "overshot" the carrying capacity of the Earth, and "smart growth" is mostly an ill.  Instead, a steady state economy would be needed to bring h societies back into a necessary balance with the ability of the ecosystem to sn h (and other species).<ref>http://www.permatopia.com/growth.html permatopia.com\n\nA study released in November 2009 characterized the smart-growth policies in the U.S. state of Maryland as a failure, concl that "there is no evidence after ten years that smart-growth laws have had any effect on development patterns."<ref name="Rein 11-2-2009">Lisa Rein, http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/11/01/AR2009110102470.html?hpid=moreheadlines Study calls Md. smart growth a flop, The Washington Post, November 2, 2009<ref>Rebecca Lewis, Gerrit-Jan Knaap, and Jl Sohn, http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/metro/pdf/smart_growth_study.pdf "Managing Growth With Priority Fg Areas: A Good Idea Whose Time Has Yet to Come," Jo of the American Planning Association, 75:4,457 \u2014 478, Online Pation Date: September 1, 2009,  Factors include a lack of incentives for brs to redevelop older neighborhoods and limits on the ability of state planners to force local jictions to approve high-density developments in "smart-growth" areas.<ref name="Rein 11-2-2009"/>  B demand low-density development and because voters tend to oppose high density developments near them.<ref name="Rein 11-2-2009"/>\n\nBeginning in 2010, groups generally associated with the Tea Party movement began to identify Smart Growth as an owth of the United Nations Agenda 21 which they viewed as an attempt by international interests to force a "snable" lifestyle on the United States. In addition the word "snable development" as  in the Agenda 21 report is often misread to mean real estate development when it typically refers to the much broader concept of H development (hty) in the United Nations and foreign aid context which addresses a broader slate of economic, health, poverty, and edon issues.\n\n\nRelated topics\n* New Urbanism\n* Comm Preservation Act\n* Garden city
