Row(id=101659, title=u'Ulu\u1e5fu-Kata Tju\u1e6fa National Park', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n\n| established           = \n| established_footnotes = <ref name="CAPAD2012NTSum"/>\n| visitation_num        = \n| visitation_year       = \n| visitation_footnotes  = \n| managing_aities  = \n| url                   = http://www.deh.gov.au/parks// Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park\n| footnotes = \n\nUlu\u1e5fu-Kata Tju\u1e6fa National Park is a national park located in Northern Territory, Alia. The park is home to both Uluru and Kata Tjuta. It is located 1431 kilometres south of Darwin, Northern Territory by road and  south-west of Alice Springs along the St and Lasseter Highways. The park covers  and incl the feat it is named after: Uluru and,  to its west, Kata Tjuta. The location is listed with UNESCO World Heritage sites.\n\n\nUluru is Alia\u2019s most recognizable nat icon and has become a focal point for Alia and the worlds acknowledgement of Alian indigenous ce.   The sandstone monolith stands 348 metres high with most of its bulk below the ground.   To Anangu (local indigenous people), Uluru is a place name and this "Rock" has a n of different landmarks where many ancestral beings have interacted with the landscape and/or each other, some even believed to still reside here. Kata Tjuta, meaning \u2018many heads\u2019, is a sacred place relating to knowledge that is considered very powerful and dangerous, only sle for initiated men.  It is made up of a group of 36 conglomerate rock domes that date back 500 million years.\n\nAnangu are the traditional Indigenous Alian owners of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park. They believe that their ce was created at the beginning of time by ancestral beings. Uluru and Kata Tjuta provide physical evidence of feats performed d the creation period.  They often lead walking tours to inform  visitors about the local flora and fauna, bush foods and the Aboriginal Dreamtime stories of the area.\n\nThe Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act was passed in 1976, meaning that after many years Aboriginal law and land rights were finally recognised in Alian law. Nine years later in 1985 the traditional owners were presented with the freehold title deeds for the park, who, in turn, leased the land back to the Alian Government through the Director of National Parks (formerly the Alian National Parks and Wildlife Service) for 99 years. The Director is assisted by Parks Alia (a division of the Department of the Environment and Water Reso). Since hand-back, Anangu and Parks Alia staff have worked together to manage the park. This process of working together is known as joint management.\n\n\n\nEans came to the Western Desert (Alia) of Alia in the 1870s. Uluru and Kata Tjuta were first mapped by Eans d the expeditionary period made possible by the constrn of the Overland Telegraph in 1872.\n\nIn separate expeditions, William Ernest Powell Giles and William Christie Gosse were the first Ean explorers to this area. In 1872 while exploring the area, Ernest Giles sighted Kata Tjuta from near Kings Canyon (Northern Territory) and called it Mount Olga, while the following year Gosse saw Uluru and named it Ayers Rock after Sir Henry Ayers, the Chief Secretary of South Alia. Fr explorations followed with the aim of establishing the possibilities of the area for pastoralism.\n\nIn the late 19th century, pastoralists attempted to re-establish themselves in areas adjoining the South-Western/Petermann Reserve and interaction between Anangu and white people became more freq and more violent. Due to the effects of grazing and dro, bush food stores were depleted. Competition for these reso created conflict between pastoralists and Anangu. As a result, police patrols became more freq. \nFile:Uluru 2.JPG|thumb|left\nBetween 1918 and 1921 large adjoining areas of South Alia, Western Alia and the Northern Territory were declared as Indigenous Alian, as sancts for a nomadic people who had virt no contact with white people. In 1920, part of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park was declared an Aboriginal Reserve (commonly known as the South-Western or Petermann Reserve) by the Alian Government  the Aboriginals Ordinance (NT).\n\nD the depression in the 1930s, Anangu became involved in dingo scalping with \u2018doggers\u2019 who introd Anangu to Ean foods and ways. The first tos visited the Uluru area in 1936.\n\n<blockq>\n"From the 1940s the two main reasons for permanent and sntial Ean settlement in the area were Aboriginal welfare policy and the promotion of to at Uluru."<ref name="Ul">Uluru \u2013 Kata Tjuta Board of Management and Parks Alia (2000) Fo Uluru \u2013 Kata Tjuta National Park Plan of Management. Commonwealth of Alia. Canberra. Page 7.</blockq>\n\n<blockq>\n"In 1948 the first vehic track to Uluru was constr, responding to increasing to interest in the region. Tour bus services began in the early 1950s."<ref name="Ul"/></blockq>\n\n<blockq>\nIn 1958, in response to press to st to enterprises, the area that is now the park was excised from the Petermann Aboriginal Reserve to be managed by the Northern Territory Reserves Board as the Ayers Rock \u2013 Mt Olga National Park. The first ranger was the legendary central Alian figure, William Edward Harney<ref name="Ul"/></blockq>\n\nBy 1959 the first motel leases had been granted and Eddie Connellan had constr an airstrip close to the northern side of Uluru.\n\n\n\n\nFile:Schema Kata Tjuta Uluru.png|Geologic cross-section.|thumb|right|Geologic cross-section of the national park. <br /><small>This image presents ds facts, compare http://www.environment.gov.au/topics/national-parks/-kata-tjuta-national-park/nat-environment/geology Website of www.environment.gov.au "Formation of Uluru-Kata Tjuta" see also Talk:Ulu\u1e5fu-Kata Tju\u1e6fa National Park</small>\nFile:TreesUpUluru.JPG|Close-up view of Uluru.|thumb|right\nThese domed rock formations are composed of Conglomerate (geology), a sedimentary rock consisting of cobbles and bos of varying rock types incl granite and basalt, cemented by a matrix of sandstone. The crevasses are due to erosion, primarily by water.  Although it is a dry region, the large area of these domes collects a lot of rainwater, which runs off in steep waterfalls d rain.\n\n\nThe park receives an average rainfall of 307.7 millimeters per year. Temperature extremes in the park have been\nrecorded at 45&nbsp;\xb0C (113&nbsp;\xb0F) d the s and -5&nbsp;\xb0C (23&nbsp;\xb0F) d winter nights. UV readings on\nmost extreme s days reach between 11 and 15.<ref name="Welcome">Welcome to Aboriginal land: Uluru-Kata Tjuta\nNational Park; visitor g and maps, Colemans Printing, Darwin, Jan 2006. While the Central Alian environment may at first seem stark \u2013 a barren landscape sting spectac rock formations \u2013 closer inspection reveals it as a complex ecosystem, full of life.\n\nPlant and animal life have adapted to the areas extreme conditions and it sy sts some of the most al flora and fauna on the planet. Many of these have long been a val so of bush t and medicine for local Indigenous Alian people.\nFile:Alian bush t, Alice Springs.jpg|thumb|left|Bush t (bush foods) harvested at Alice Springs Desert Park.\n\nThe Aboriginal Alians recognise six seasons:\n# Piryakatu (A/September) \u2013 Animals breed and food plants flower\n# Wiyaringk (October/November) \u2013 The really hot season when food becomes scarce\n# Itanju- (Jan/Febr) Sporadic storms can roll in sly\n# Wanitjai (March) \u2013 Cooler weather\n# Tjpa (April/May) \u2013 Clouds roll in from the south\n# Wari (June/July) \u2013 Cold season bringing morning frosts\n\nFrom a geological point of view, analysis of Uluru-Kata Tjuta and Watarrka National Parks reveals an awe-inspiring history. 500 million years ago, the entire area was covered by an inland sea and over many cent, sand and mud fell to the bottom of the sea, creating rock and sandstone. Kata Tjutas domes are the eroded remains of sedimentary rock from the seabed, while Uluru is a relict of the coarse grained, mineral-rich sandstone called arkose.\n\n\nFile:Ul 2003-11-21.jpg|An aerial view of Uluru.|thumb|right\nThe park is ranked as one of the most significant arid land ecosystems in the world. As a Biosphere Reserve  the UNESCO Man and the Biosphere Program, it joins at least 11 other reserves in Alia and an international network aiming to preserve the worlds major ecosystem types.\n\n\n\n\nFile:Wildflowers1218.jpg|thumb\nUluru-Kata Tjuta National Park flora represents a large portion of plants found in Central Alia. A n of these species are considered rare and restricted in the park or the immediate region. There are many rare and endemism plants at Uluru and Kata Tjuta. A n of other species, while found elsewhere in central Alia, may be endangered within the park.\n\nThe desert flora has adapted to the harsh conditions. The growth and reprodn of plant commes rely on irreg rainfall. Some plants are able to se fire and some are dependent on it to reproduce. Plants are an important part of Tja, and there are ceremonies for each of the major plant foods. Many plants are associated with ancestral beings. Collection of plant foods remains a cally important activity, reinforcing traditional links with co and Tja.\n\nFlora in Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park can be broken into the following categories:\n* Punu \u2013 trees\n* Puti \u2013 shrubs\n* Tj-tjpa \u2013 flowers\n* Ukiri \u2013 grasses\n\nFile:Desert Oaks3484.jpg|thumb\nTrees such as the Acacia aneura and centralian bloodwood are  to make tools such as spearheads, boomerangs and bowls. The red sap of the bloodwood is  as a disinfectant and an inhalant for co and colds.\n\nOthers such as the river red gum and Dia like grevillea and hakeas are a so of food themselves. The white flaky crust from river red gum leaves can be rolled into balls and eaten like a lolly and the nectar from the flowers of the corkwood trees can produce a sweet drink.\n\nThe witchetty bush looks like a shr m with broad round-ended leaves. Witchetty grubs are found in the roots of this tree.\nAsteraceae and other ground flowers bloom after rain and d the winter. Others such as the wattles bloom as spring approaches. Anangu collect wattle seed, crush and mix it with water to make an edible paste which they eat raw. To make damper (food), the seeds are parched with hot sand so their skins can be removed before they are ground for flour.\nFile:Spinifex grass.jpg|thumb\nThe prickly hard Triodia (plant genus) hks have enormous root systems that prevent desert sands shifting. The hk roots spread ground beyond the prickly clump and deeply into the soil, forming an immense cone. Anangu use a resin gathered from the g spinifex to make Spinifex resin. They thresh the spinifex  the resin particles fall free. These particles are heated  they fuse together to form a moldable black tar which Anangu work while warm. The gum is  for hg and working implements, and to mend breaks in stone and wooden implements.\n\nThe naked woolybutt and native millet have seeds that are important Anangu foods. Women rub the seedheads from their stalks and then separate the seeds from the chaff by skilful winnowing. Using grinding stones, they then grind the seeds to flour for damper.\n\nThere are several rare and endangered species in the park. Most of them like adders tongue ferns (Ophioglossaceae sp.) are restricted to the moist areas at the base of the monoliths, which are areas of high visitor use and st to erosion.\n\nSince the first Eans arrived, 34 exotic plant species have been recorded in the park, representing about 6.4% of the total park flora. Some such as perennial b grass (Cenchrus ciliaris) were introd to rehabilitate areas damaged by erosion. It is the most threatening weed in the park and has spread to invade water and nnt rich drainage lines. Where infestation is dense, it prevents the growth of native grasses \u2013 a so of food for animals and h. A few others such as bass were bro in accidentally, carried on cars and people.\n\n\nFile:Black-footed Rock-wallaby(small).jpg|ht|thumb\nHistorically 46 species of native mammal are known to have been living in the Uluru region; there are ctly 21 according to recent ss. Anangu allege that a decrease in the n has implications for the condition and health of the landscape. Moves are sted for the reintrodn of locally extinct animals such as mallee fowl, Briled possum, r hare wallaby or R hare-wallaby, bilby, bing bettong and the black-footed rock wallaby\n\nThe ma, the only mammal listed as vable, is mostly restricted to the transitional sandplain area, a narrow band of co that stretches from the vicinity of Uluru, to the northern boy of the park, and into Ayers Rock Resort. This very important area also contains the mars mole, woma python, or k, and great desert skink.\n\nFile:Bril possum.jpg|thumb|left\nFile:Perentie Lizard Perth Zoo SMC Spet 2005.jpg|thumb\n\nThe bat popon of the park comprises at least seven species that depend on day roosting sites within caves and crevices of Uluru and Kata Tjuta. Most of the bats forage for aerial prey within an airspace extending only 100&nbsp;m or so from the rock face.\n\nThe park has a very rich reptile fauna of high conservation significance, with 73 species having been reliably recorded. Four species of frog are Abce (ecology) at the base of Uluru and Kata Tjuta following s rains. The great desert skink is listed as Vable species.\n\nAnangu continue to hunt and gather animal species in remote areas of the park and on Anangu land elsewhere. Hg is largely confined to the red kangaroo, Alian bd, emu and lizard such as the sand goanna and perentie.\n\nThe press exerted by introd predators and herbivores on the original mammalian fauna of Central Alia were a major factor in the extinction of about 40% of the native species.\n\nOf the 27 mammal species found in the park, six are introd: the house mouse; camel; fox; cat; dog; and rabbit. These species are distrib throt the park but their densities are greatest in the rich water run-off areas of Uluru and Kata Tjuta. Large ns of rabbits led to the introdn of a rabbit control program in 1989. This has res in a great redn of the rabbit popon, a noticeable vegetation recovery and a redn in predator ns. Camels have been implicated in the redn of plant species, particy the more sent species such as the qng. The house mouse is a ssful invader of dist environments and habitats that have lost native rodents. Stive estimates of cat and fox ns have been collected in association with the rabbit control program. The national threat abatement programs may provide the framework for controlling them. Anangu knowledge and tracking skills are inval in the management of these introd animals. The park regons prohibit visitors bringing animals into the park s they are a g dog for the blind or deaf, or a permit is granted by the Director of National Parks.\n\nIconic birds of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park include the pied brbird, black breasted bd, black-faced woodswallow and crimson chat.\n\n\nFires have been a part of central desert land management for thos of years and have shaped the landscape, habitats, sal of animals and patterns of vegetation. Controlled bg ly takes place d the winter months due to the cooler weather while nat fires mostly occur in the early s months. They are ly started by the lightning strikes of dry electrical storms from the north west. When the storms arrive the weather is ly hot, dry and windy \u2013 conditions ideal for raging fires. Damage can be severe and widespread. Destre bres b much of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park and l accommodation at the Ayers Rock Resort was destroyed in 2002-03.\n\nTraditional bg of the Uluru area stopped when Anangu were driven from the region d the 1930s. D the 1940s rainfall was good and vegetation floed. The 1950 fire, fed by the fuel grown d the previous 20 years, wiped out about one third of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Parks vegetation. The pattern repeated itself and in 1976 two fires b 76% of the park. Over the same period more species of medium-sized mammals became extinct around Uluru and Kata Tjuta. Today most fires in the park are lit following land management patterns traditionally practiced by Anangu. Traditional fire and land management skills enable Anangu to burn in a way that will give the desired result. These skills are vital for the preservation of the central Alian ecology.\n\n\n\n\nFile:Cal Centre Ul55.jpg|ht|thumb\n\nThe park is open year round from se to s. These times will vary depending on the season. Occasionally parts of the park may be temporarily closed for cal reasons.\n\nThe park entrance fee for Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park is $25 per person 16 years of age and over. This fee is valid for 3 consec days and helps to maintain the park. One qr goes back to Anangu, the\nIndigenous Alian, to help them maintain their families and the Mulu comm.\n\nThe Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park Cal Centre, located inside the park on the main road to Uluru, provides an introdn to Tja (law, knowledge, religion, philosophy), Anangu art, Anangu way of life (traditional and ct), history, lang, wildlife and joint management of the park. There are also Aboriginal art and craft demonstrations, bush t sessions, plants walks and cal presentations.\n\nThere are displays feat photo collages, oral history sound panels, Pitjantjatjara lang learning interactives, soapes, videos and artefacts. Explanations are provided in Pitjantjatjara, English, Italian, Japanese, German and French. A touch wall for vis impaired people ens that the messages are accessible to everyone. Entry to the Cal Centre is free.\n\nThe Walkatjara Art Centre is owned and operated by the local Aboriginal artists from the Mulu Comm. Most weekdays the Walkatjara Artists come to paint and work in the Art Room and receive a percentage of sales.\n\n\nFile:Lasseter Highway1437.jpg|thumb|Driving \u2013 Lasseter Highway to Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park\nThe development of to infrastre adjacent to the base of Uluru that began in the 1950s soon prod adverse environmental impacts. It was decided in the early 1970s to remove all accommodation-related to facilities and re-establish them oe the park. In 1975 a reservation of 104 sq kilometres of land beyond the parks northern boy, 15 kilometres from Uluru, was approved for the development of a to facility and an associated airport, to be known as Y. The campground within the park was closed in 1983 and the motels finally closed in late 1984, coinciding with the opening of the Y resort. In 1992 the majority interest in the Y Resort held by the Northern Territory Government was sold and the resort was renamed Ayers Rock Resort.\nFile:Mala Walk1178.jpg|thumb|left|Mala people Walk Uluru\nThe listing of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park ens the park remains a world-class destination for both its Cal heritage and nat heritage. Visitors will continue to have a e cal experience at the park and leave knowing that the park is managed according to cal practices that date back tens of thos of years.\n\nSince the park was listed as a World Heritage Site, annual visitor ns have risen to over 400,000 visitors in the year 2000. Increased to provides regional and national economic benefits. It also presents an ongoing challenge to balance conservation of cal values and visitor needs.<ref>http://www.tont.com.au To NTTo NT (www.tont.com.au)\n\nThere are a n of walks that visitors can take around the major attractions of the park. The Base Walk is one of the best ways to see Uluru. Other walks snding Uluru include the Liru Walk, Mala Walk and K walk, while the se and s viewing areas provide great photo opportes.<ref>http://www.travelnt.com/en/explore// To Information SiteTo Information Site (www.travelnt.com.com.au)\n\nThe border of the national park is also home to the Longitude 131\xb0 Eco resort.\n\n\nFile:Ulrning.jpg|ht|thumb\nThe Uluru climb is the traditional route taken by ancestral Mala men  their arrival to Uluru. Anangu do not climb Uluru because of its great spiritual significance, though they have not closed the climb. They prefer that visitors \u2013 out of edon and standing \u2013 choose to respect their law and ce by not climbing. The Cal Centre in the park has information on this for visitors.\n\nThe Valley of the Winds walk is an alternative to climbing Uluru and offers views of the landscape from two lookout points along the track. The walk is sometimes steep, rocky and difficult. For safety reasons this walk is closed  certain circnces incl heat, darkness and d rescue.<ref>http://www.environment.gov.au/parks/ Nt GovernmentDepartment of Environment and water reso (www.environment.gov.au/parks/)\n\n\nFile:Anangu ranger at Uluru.png|thumb\nThe Indigenous Alian comm of Mulu, Northern Territory is inside the park area, but tos must stay at the resorts in Y, Northern Territory, just oe the national park.  Ayers Rock Resort in Y offers a range of accommodation from camp sites to five-star l.  There are also several dining options, a sarket and a range of tour operators. The national park and town are served by Ayers Rock Airport.\n\nSlightly fr afield is the l tented accommodation at Longitude 131, with views of Uluru from the tents.\n\nCamping is not permitted in the park.\n\n\n* Kata Tjuta\n* Protected areas of the Northern Territory (Alia)\n* List of national parks of Alia\n* Tony Tjamiwa\n*List of biosphere reserves in Alia\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Row(id=118771, title=u'Lathrup Village, Michigan', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n<!-- Infobox begins -->\n\n|popon_footnotes     = <ref name ="FactFinder"/>\n|popon_total         = 4075\n|popon_density_km2   = 1048.9\n|popon_density_sq_mi = 2716.7\n|popon_note          =\n|popon_metro         =\n|popon_density_metro_km2     =\n|popon_density_metro_sq_mi   =\n|popon_                 =\n|popon_density__km2     =\n|popon_density__sq_mi   =\n|popon_blank1_title          =\n|popon_blank1                =\n|popon_density_blank1_km2    =\n|popon_density_blank1_sq_mi  =\n|timezone                 = Eastern Standard Time Zone\n|utc_offset               = -5\n|timezone_DST             = Eastern Daylight Time\n|utc_offset_DST           = -4\n|coordinates              = \n|elevation_footnotes      = <!--for references: use  tags-->\n|elevation_m              = 215\n|elevation_ft             = 705\n|postal_code_type         = ZIP Code\n|postal_code              = 48076\n|area_code                = 248\n|blank_name               = Federal Information Processing Standard\n|blank_info               = 26-46320<ref name="GR2">\n|blank1_name              = Geographic Names Information System feature ID\n|blank1_info              = 0630184\n|website                  = http://www.lathrlage.org/ City of Lathrup Village\n|footnotes                =\n\n<!-- Infobox ends -->\n\nLathrup Village ( ) is a city in Oakland Co, Michigan in the U.S. state of Michigan. The popon was 4,075 at the 2010 United States Census.<ref name="Census 2010">  This city is snded by the city of Soeld, Michigan.  The I-696 / Re Freeway goes through nearly the east-west center of town, and Soeld Road goes nearly through the north-south center.  The Soeld Town Center, formerly known as the Prial Town Center, is within walking distance of the sost corner of the city.\n\n\nAccording to the United States Census B, the city has a total area of , all land.<ref name="Gazetteer files">\n\n\n\n|footnote=<center>U.S. Decennial Census<ref name="DecennialCensus"></center>\n\n\n\nAs of the census<ref name ="FactFinder"> of 2010, there were 4,075 people, 1,610 holds, and 1,157 families residing in the city. The popon density was . There were 1,698 ho  at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 34.6% White (U.S. Census), 61.2% African American (U.S. Census), 0.1% Native American (U.S. Census), 0.6% Asian (U.S. Census), 0.5% from Race (U.S. Census), and 3.1% from two or more races. Hispanic (U.S. Census) or Latino (U.S. Census) of any race were 1.5% of the popon.\n\nThere were 1,610 holds of which 30.4% had children  the age of 18 living with them, 55.1% were Marriage living together, 13.3% had a female holder with no hd present, 3.5% had a male holder with no wife present, and 28.1% were non-families. 22.4% of all holds were made up of individ and 8.4% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average hold size was 2.53 and the average family size was 2.99.\n\nThe median age in the city was 45.8 years. 20.9% of residents were  the age of 18; 6.4% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 21.2% were from 25 to 44; 36.1% were from 45 to 64; and 15.3% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.0% male and 52.0% female.\n\n\nAs of the census<ref name="GR2" /> of 2000, there were 4,236 people, 1,621 holds, and 1,207 families residing in the city.  The popon density was 2,806.1 per sq mile (1,083.1/km\xb2).  There were 1,647 ho  at an average density of 1,091.0 per sq mile (421.1/km\xb2).  The racial makeup of the city was 49.81% African American (U.S. Census), 47.03% White (U.S. Census), 0.09% Native American (U.S. Census), 0.61% Asian (U.S. Census), 0.21% from Race (United States Census), and 2.24% from two or more races. Hispanic (U.S. Census) or Latino (U.S. Census) of any race were 0.94% of the popon.\n\nThere were 1,621 holds out of which 33.6% had children  the age of 18 living with them, 60.9% were Marriage living together, 9.9% had a female holder with no hd present, and 25.5% were non-families. 21.5% of all holds were made up of individ and 8.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average hold size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.05.\n\nIn the city, the popon was spread out with 24.6%  the age of 18, 5.4% from 18 to 24, 28.8% from 25 to 44, 29.0% from 45 to 64, and 12.2% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females there were 95.8 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.6 males.\n\nThe median income for a hold in the city was $89,303, and the median income for a family was $98,213. Males had a median income of $65,641 versus $49,375 for females. The per capita income for the city was $35,998.  About 1.5% of families and 2.7% of the popon were below the poverty line, incl 3.8% of those  age 18 and none of those age 65 or over.\n\n\nThe city is within Soeld P School District. Soeld High School for the Arts & Technology is in the city.\n\n\n\nThe city of Lathrup Village is an owth of the development known as Lathrup Townsite, the dream of its developer Lo Lathrup Kelley. In 1923 she psed a tract of  in Soeld Township, in son Oakland Co, and proceeded to plat a residential neighborhood that encompasses the city of . Lathrup Townsite was conceived as a controlled comm with rigorous standards, incl ho b only of masonry constrn; early integration of attached garages; as well as established minimums for constrn cost to ensure qy (so: City of Lathrup Village). As the comm developed, Mrs. Kelley implemented nus innovative directives, incl operating a sh service to local shopping areas, and allowing the financing of abiles as part of the financing of ho, which created a stronger connection between the relatively isolated townsite and more established ss, as well as the city of Detroit. Mr. Charles Kelley, who had been a real estate writer for the Detroit News, assisted his wife in bringing talented architects to the comm to design many of the c homes that are feat of the comm.\n\nThe City of Lathrup Village was incorporated in 1953 as the first incorporated comm in Soeld Township. The residents thwarted an attempt by township residents to include Lathrup Townsite in their planned incorporation of the city of Soeld, resg in Soeld\u2019s incorporation being delayed  1958. Lo Lathrup Kelley played an active role in the new city  her death in 1963, after which her remaining real estate holdings in the city were sold and developed.\n\n\nIn 1998 much of Lathrup Village was incl in the Lathrup Village Historic District on the National Register of Historic Places (http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natregsearchresult.do?fsult=true&recordid=0). The district incl approximately 1,200 properties, primarily residential, that reflect characteristic ho styles from the first half of the 20th century. These include Colonial Revival, T and ranch ho. The district is also considered significant due to its planning: \u201cThe district possesses a strong geometric street pattern integrated with cinear patterns that provide a r character. This layering of patterns prod octagonal, circ and semi-circ focal points and a series of small triang parks scattered throt the district. It also creates e and changing perspectives, as views of significant bngs sly appear at ssing moments. Likewise, at the ely config intersections of many streets, one is met with a new perspective as sly several sections of the district become visible.\u201d (so: Michigan State Historic Preservation Office) Another significant aspect of the district is its pioneering developer, Lo Lathrup Kelley: \u201cAs a woman acting as developer starting in the 1920s, she was essentially alone, however her dogged persistence and insistence on qy res in a e comm that was the sion of her career.\u201d (so: Michigan State Historic Preservation Office)\n\nResidential side streets that once permitted vehicle traffic to leave the city and proceed to snding neighborhoods in the city of Soeld have been blocked with lawns and posts to create dead-end streets. Pedestrians and bicyclists can  still pass through.\n\nThe layout of residential side streets in Lathrup Village makes it nearly impossible for motorists to cut through from crowded thorores d heavy traffic periods on Soeld Road, Twelve Mile Road and the I-696/Re Freeway service drive. While a map or GPS would make it easy, drivers or cyclists without those tools would likely get lost. Very few streets proceed in a straight line. This makes many lot sizes and shapes varied and interesting.\n\nNeighborhoods are typically q, well-kept and interesting due to the wide variety of home styles b over a span from the late 1930s to the early 1970s. A very few apartments and townho have been b in recent years on narrow properties alongside major streets and freeway service drives.\n\nHomes have an attached garage, a fireplace in the basement and a second fireplace in a first-floor living room as specified in original deed reqents. Another deed restriction, that property not be sold to anyone of "Mediterranean descent" ssf excl citizens with African, Italian, Jewish or Arabic heritage from owning property in Lathrup Village. When Civil Rights laws were passed in the early 1960s, those restrictions became orceable. Though archaic, that lang remains in deeds as req by law to show lineage.\n\nQ access to I-696/Re Freeway, I-75/Chrysler Freeway, the Soeld Freeway and M-10/Lodge Freeway are ideal for easy comm. There are no bars, no chain or fast-food restas (there is a Panera Bread store) and no shopping centers, although those amenities are not far away. Lathrup Village is overwhelmingly a residential area. There are local split-level office bngs on Soeld Road and 12 Mile Road, and a local Post Office.\n\nThe City Hall ho offices and a local Police Department. The small park behind City Hall has a gazebo, and reg m concerts take place there d s months.  A colorful Childrens Garden is near the gazebo, where local yoers are encod to plant, water and maintain a manageable flower plot with gce from volr ad.\n\nAn annual Flower Walk prompts a loosely g tour of the beal plantings oe specified local homes, and awards are given for the finest each year.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.lathrlage.org City website\n\n\n\n\nCategory:Cities in Oakland Co, Row(id=124684, title=u'West Hattiesburg, Mississippi', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n|postal_code_type         = \n|postal_code              = \n|area_code                = \n|blank_name               = Federal Information Processing Standard\n|blank_info               = 28-78890\n|blank1_name = Geographic Names Information System feature ID\n|blank1_info = 2403004<ref name=GNIS1>\n|website                  = \n|footnotes                = \n\nWest Hattiesburg is a census-designated place  west of the city of Hattiesburg, Mississippi and east of the comm of Oak Grove, Mississippi. It is part of the Hattiesburg metropolitan area. It had a decline in  popon from 6,305 at the 2000 United States Census to 5,909 at the 2010 United States Census.\n\n\n\nAccording to the United States Census B, the CDP has a total area of , of which,  is land and  is water. The total area is 1.39% water.\n\n\nAs of the census<ref name="GR2"> of 2000, there were 6,305 people, 4,464 holds, and 2,601 families residing in the CDP. The popon density was 892.0 people per sq mile (377.3/km\xb2). There were 2,633 ho  at an average density of 372.5/sq&nbsp;mi (143.8/km\xb2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 74.88% White (U.S. Census), 22.11% African American (U.S. Census), 0.06% Native American (U.S. Census), 1.63% Asian (U.S. Census), 0.29% from Race (United States Census), and 1.03% from two or more races. Hispanic (U.S. Census) or Latino (U.S. Census) of any race were 1.38% of the popon.\n\nThere were 2,464 holds out of which 32.9% had children  the age of 18 living with them, 47.3% were Marriage living together, 14.0% had a female holder with no hd present, and 35.0% were non-families. 24.0% of all holds were made up of individ and 6.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average hold size was 2.50 and the average family size was 3.00.\n\nIn the CDP, the popon was spread out with 25.5%  the age of 18, 15.7% from 18 to 24, 30.8% from 25 to 44, 19.2% from 45 to 64, and 8.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 30 years. For every 100 females there were 91.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 87.2 males.\n\nThe median income for a hold in the CDP was $44,663, and the median income for a family was $68,287. Males had a median income of $49,552 versus $43,873 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $38,988. None of the families and none of the popon were living below the poverty line, incl no  eighteens and none of those over 64.\n\n\nA movement for Mpal incorporation has been attempted repeatedly over the years, but the co have never r on the snce of it. The issues involve getting articles of incorporation which all would agree to, as well as who wants incorporation (who will profit, who will end up paying more in taxes).\n\nProponents say incorporation will benefit all residents, but the opposition says it will only benefit the persons who hold that property which is yet to be f developed within the real estate market over the next few years. Another arg against incorporation is that the proposal and its b oe didnt f account for the additional expendit and costs of rg the new city. Proponents co that the overall cost will be lower, because of a more distrib risk amongst homeowners, who would essentially bear about 80% of the additional taxes to st this city.\n\nhttp://www.hattiesberican.com has extensive archives about this issue, incl opinion col aed by the actual people engaged in the debate both pro and con. It is a good case study in local politics.\n\n\nWest Hattiesburg was a rarely  term by residents, and was first popzed by out of towners whom saw the area listed on Google Maps with that name. Residents of the area are grad picking up the term.\n\nWest Hattiesburg should not be conf with Oak Grove, Mississippi which is directly to the west close but considered its own area. This can be complicated because (as of 2016) West Hattiesburg p school sts are still edd in the Oak Grove school system.\n\n\nWest Hattiesburg is served by an interstate highway, I-59, and a major U.S. Highway, 98. Highway 98 serves as the CDPs main thorore, on it is the majority of the commercial area in West Hattiesburg. It also serves as the main route for morning and evening comm. Due to recent popon growth and migration the area (and Lamar Co) the traffic has gotten worse on Highway 98, which has led to Highway 98 being widened from 4 to 6 lanes and recently 4 to 8 lanes (only near Interstate 59) in the area. Three major roads parallel U.S. Highway 98 (4th Street, Oak Grove Road, and Lincoln Road) have also been victim to large inflows of traffic due to the large amount of motorists trying to avoid major traffic on 98.\n\n\n\n\nThe Lamar Co School District serves West Hattiesburg with neighboring Oak Groves school system. There have been calls, however, for the district to b West Hattiesburg its own schools due to overpopon.\n\nOak Grove schools are among the Top 10 in Mississippi. They have been listed in the following:\n\n\n* Oak Grove High School (Hattiesburg, Mississippi) (Grades 9-12)\n\n\n* Oak Grove Middle School (Grades 6-8)\n\n\n* Oak Grove Upper Elementary School (Grades 4-5)\n* Oak Grove Lower Elementary School (Grades 2-3)\n* Long Leaf Elementary School (Grades K-5)\n* Oak Grove Primary School (Grades K-1)\n\n\n<references Row(id=216590, title=u'Female homicides in Ciudad Ju\xe1rez', text_clean=u'\n\n\n or  -->\n| venue                    =\n| location                 =Ci Ju\xe1rez, Chih\n| coordinates              = <!--  -->\n| also_known_as            =\n| type                     =\n| theme                    =\n| cause                    =robbery, gang wars, rape\n| first_reporter           =\n| filmed_by                =\n| participants             =\n| oe                  =\n| cases1              =\n| cases2              =\n| cases3              =\n| reported deaths          =More than 370\n| reported inj        =\n| reported missing         =\n| reported property damage =\n| b                   =\n| inqs                =\n| inq                  =\n| coroner                  =\n| arrests                  =\n| sts                 =\n| acc                  =\n| convicted                =\n| charges                  =\n| trial                    =\n| verdict                  =\n| convictions              =\n| sentence                 =\n| pation_bans         =\n| litigation               =\n| awards                   =\n| url                      =\n| blank_label              = <!-- or |blank_data= -->\n| blank1_label             = <!-- or |blank1_data= -->\n| blank2_label             = <!-- or |blank2_data= -->\n| website                  = <!--  -->\n| notes                    =\n\n\nFile:Location Ci J.png|thumb|350px|The location of Ci Ju\xe1rez\n\nThe phenomenon of the female homicides in Ci Ju\xe1rez, called in Spanish (lang) feminicidio ("feminicide") involves the violent deaths of hds of women and girls since 1993 in the northern Mexico region of Ci Ju\xe1rez, Chih (state), a border city across the Rio Grande from the United States city of El Paso, Texas. As of Febr 27, 2005, the n of med women in Ci Ju\xe1rez since 1993 is estimated to be more than 370.<ref name=Amnesty>\n\nAfter sing 155 killings out of 340 doced between 1993 and 2003, a government committee found that ro half were prompted by motives like robbery and gang wars, while a little more than a third involved sexual assault.\n\nThe ms of women and girls in Ci Ju\xe1rez since 1993 have received international attention, primarily due to perceived government inaction in preventing violence against women and girls and bringing perpetrators to je.<ref name=Widyono>\n\n\nEvidence sts that a specific group of women and girls are being targeted in Ci Ju\xe1rez.<ref name=Simmons /><ref name=Livingston /> The victims share common characteristics, and there are many similarities in the violent crimes committed against them.<ref name=Simmons><ref name=Simmons /><ref name=Livingston /> Most of the victims are young women who come from impoverished backgro and work in maqoras, as factory workers, in other sectors of the informal economy, or are sts.<ref name=Simmons /><ref name=Livingston />\n\nIn addition, many victims share common physical attrib, incl dark skin, slender physique, and dark, sho-length hair.<ref name=Livingston> In terms of the crimes, similarities across cases include the rape, torture, mtion, and m of the victims.<ref name=Simmons /><ref name=Livingston /><ref name="Fragoso 2"><ref name=Pantaleo><ref name=Pantaleo /><ref name="Amnesty 4">\n\n\nThere are various media reports with different ns ranging from hds to thos of female homicides in the Ci Ju\xe1rez region. For this reason, Amnesty International reports, "Inadeq official data on the crimes committed in Chih City, particy acc fig on the exact n of ms and abdns of girls and women, has led to disp around the issues that obscure the q for je."<ref name=Amnesty />\n\nAccording to Amnesty International, as of Febr 2005, more than 370 young women and girls had been med in the cities of Ci Ju\xe1rez and Chih.<ref name=Amnesty /> More recently, prosec from the state of Chih reported that in 2010, 270 women were killed within the state, of these ms 247 occ in Ju\xe1rez.<ref name="El Paso Times">  In 2011, Chihs Attorney General, Carlos Manuel Salas, anno d a briefing in A 2011 that 222 women had been killed in Chih since Jan of that year.<ref name="El Paso Times" /> Of these 222 ms, 130 of them occ in Ci J.<ref name="El Paso Times" /> In total, more than 300 women were med in the city in 2011.<ref name="Amnesty 3" />\n\nA study was cond in 2008 on the Feminicide Database 1993\u20132007 at the Colegio de la Frontera Norte which doced incidents of feminicide that occ in Ci Ju\xe1rez from 1993\u20132007. Of the various different kinds of ms that were analyzed, the study found two common patterns in the data which were classified as intimate feminicide and systemic sexual feminicide.<ref name=Fragoso>  Intimate feminicide refers to women who were killed by men that were close to them.<ref name=Fragoso /> According to the study, intimate feminicide acco for 30.4% of the ms of women and girls in J from 1993\u20132007. Systematic sexual feminicide refers to systematic patterns in the killing of women and children incl kidnapping, sexual violence, torture, and body abandonment in areas such as desert areas, garbage d, and sewage ditches among others.<ref name=Fragoso /> According to the study, systemic sexual feminicide acco for 31.8% of the ms of women in J from 1993\u20132007.\n\nFile:Cd J m rate chart 1.png|thumb|450px\n\nAccording to Molly Molloy, a research librarian and professor at New Mexico State University (also fo and maintainer of "Frontera List", a long-rg mailing list dedicated to information and discn about issues in the U.S.-Mexico border),<ref name="TO">Q&A with Molly Molloy: The Story of the J Femicides is a \u2018Myth\u2019, Texas Observer, Jan 9, 2014. http://www.texasobserver.org/qa-molly-molloy-story-j-femicides-myth/  the sitn in Ju\xe1rez is one of "imp regardless of gender".<ref name="grassroots">Grassroots Press, May 12, 2010, http://www.grass-roots-press.com/2010/05/12/3615/ She states that "female m victims have never comprised more than 18 percent of the overall n of m victims in Ci J, and in the last two decades that figure averages at less than 10 percent. That\u2019s less than in the United States, where about 20 to 25 percent of the people who are med in a given year are women".<ref name="TO" />\n\nOther scholars also state that femicide rates in Ci Ju\xe1rez are lower than in American cities such as Ho and Ensenada, and as a share of overall homicide rates they are typically lower than in other cities.\n\n\n\nThe tainty about the characteristics of the perpetrators, their relationships to the victims, or their motives is primarily due to the dysfon of the Mexican je system as most cases have been inadeqy investigated and doced.<ref name=Olivera /> While in many of the cases in Ci Ju\xe1rez it has yet to be determined who exactly has committed the ms, much of the literature on this issue pts that patriarchal backlash against working women may be a potential motive for the killings.<ref name=Pantaleo />\n\nIt is believed that the femicide in Ci Ju\xe1rez may be related to organized crime (like prostit rings) given the presence of the powerful drug cartels in the region.<ref name=Olivera /> Fr, criminal gangs have become a permanent threat particy to women on the border. Gang activity creates high risk for women especially due to very little instital protection.<ref name=Olivera />\n\nThis patriarchal backlash may indeed be the result of lack of employment opportes for men and more women entering the workforce which has altered traditional gender dynamics and created a sitn of conflict between the sexes.<ref name=Olivera /> Other researchers attribute the ms to Mexicos stral crisis incl increasing poverty, loyment, the disintegration of the peasant economy, migration, and a dysfonal je system.<ref name=Olivera> Overall, in considering the potential motives for gendered violence against women, academic Mercedes Olivera has argued that femicide is a mechanism of domination, control, oppression, and power over women.<ref name=Olivera />\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn examining femicide in Ci Ju\xe1rez, it is important to consider the impact of the drug trade.<ref name=Pantaleo /> Ju\xe1rez is the seat of the Mexican drug cartel which has res in high levels of violence that have been directed at the Mexican popon.<ref name="Fragoso 2" /><ref name=Pantaleo /> It is believed that the femicide in Ci Ju\xe1rez may be related to the powerful drug cartels along the border.<ref name=Olivera /> Fr, gangs have become a permanent threat particy to women on the border. Gang activity creates high risk for women especially due to very little instital protection.<ref name=Olivera />\n\nOften, misogyny is a common trait of gang activity.<ref name=Olivera /> According to a study cond in 2008  the Feminicide Database 1993\u20132007 at the Colegio de la Frontera Norte, which doced incidents of feminicide that occ in Ci Ju\xe1rez from 1993\u20132007, 9.1% of the ms of women were attrib to organized crime and drug trafficking activities.<ref name=Fragoso />\n\n\n\n\nMaqoras are widely known for their cheap labor and their exploitative conditions, such as regy violating basic h rights, that often target women.<ref name=Pantaleo /> Women and girls often migrate from villages or r areas in other parts of Mexico in search of work in the maq.<ref name=Livingston /> According to Livingston, this migration of women created, "a new phenomenon of mobile, independent and vable working women," in cities like Ci Ju\xe1rez.<ref name=Livingston />  Women and girls are often fed to work in areas that req lower edon, and pay lower wages.<ref name=Pantaleo />\n\nMaqoras construct their female workforce  the notion that female workers are temporary workers, therefore jying lower wages and creating a high ter rate of laborers.<ref name=Livingston /><ref name=Pantaleo /> According to Monarrez Fragoso, "the practices of the maqora ind towards the workers reveal a consume and dispose cycle."<ref name="Fragoso 2" />  This consume and dispose cycle represents how the maq ind creates "disposable" women referencing the devaln and expendable nature of their labor.<ref name="Fragoso 2" />\n\nMany of the m victims in Ci Ju\xe1rez have been maqora employees.<ref name=Pantaleo /> Despite the expansion of the maq ind, J still remained a relatively poor and eloped city lacking infrastre in some parts such as electricity and paved roads.<ref name=Pantaleo /> As a part of their daily commute, many women maq workers walk through such areas to and from company b creating vability to be victimized.<ref name=Livingston /><ref name=Pantaleo /> In addition, the increased involvement of women in the labor force may also be a contrib factor to the victimization of women and girls because of the competition for economic reso in decades in which male loyment has been high.<ref name=Livingston /><ref name=Pantaleo />\n\n\n\nThe implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994 res in the expansion of the maqora ind and created new opportes for employment for women oe of the home and in the factories.<ref name=Pantaleo /> The availability of cheap labor was attractive for bss owners to open factories in Mexico and the availability of employment attracted many, especially women, to border towns such as Ci Ju\xe1rez. Research has shown correlations between economic and political issues and violence against women along the border.<ref name=Pantaleo />\n\nAcademic Katherine Pantaleo has argued that, "NAFTA, as a capitalist approach, has directly created a devaln of women and an increase in gendered violence."<ref name=Pantaleo /> Fr, according to Wright, in the time period between the implementation of NAFTA in 1994 and 2001, "the homicide rate for men increased by 300 percent, while for women it increased by 600 percent."<ref name=Wright>  Such st indicate the importance of exploring the effects of NAFTA when considering the possible ca of the m of women and girls in Ci Ju\xe1rez.<ref name=Pantaleo /> Conseqy, it has been sted that amendments be made to NAFTA that include h rights provisions.<ref name=Pantaleo />\n\n\n\n\nSociocal factors in relation to traditional gender roles have impacted violence against women in Mexico.<ref name=Pantaleo /> According to Pantaleo, "Under the view of patriarchy, two expressions are commonly  in Mexico to show the difference in status of males and females; these expressions are machismo and marianismo."<ref name=Pantaleo /> Machismo is characterized by male power and aggression; while marianismo is characterized by sination and domestic Gender role.<ref name=Pantaleo /> As part of the marianismo ideology, women are expected to fl domestic roles as wives and mothers and to refrain from paid labor oe of the home.<ref name=Pantaleo />\n\nWomen who leave their homes to seek employment in the maq ind directly challenge the marianismo ideal of womanhood.<ref name=Livingston /> Olivera sts that this changed sitn challenges hypermascty, in which aggressive aspects of male identity are exaggerated in order to preserve their identity.<ref name=Olivera/> According to Livingston, gender-directed violence in Ci Ju\xe1rez may be a negative reaction as women "gain greater personal amy and independence while men lose ground."<ref name=Livingston />\n\n\nThe m of women in Ju\xe1rez have attracted global attention since 1993 given sted police and government inaction to prevent the ms and bring perpetrators to je.<ref name=Widyono /> There have been several international rs against Mexico for its inadeq response to the increasing violence against women.<ref name=Livingston /><ref name=CEDAW /><ref name="Amnesty 2" /> Police and government officials have been acc of responding with indifference to the crimes against women as well as exhibiting tolerance for such crimes, condg inadeq and negligent investigations, ineffectively responding to the crimes, and failing to prevent and protect women from violence.<ref name=Livingston /><ref name=CEDAW /><ref name="Amnesty 2" />\n\nAs a result of international attention, police and government officials have been politically press to respond to the ms.<ref name="Amnesty 4" />  Conseqy, due to political pressure for je, police have been acc of rg to make arrests and solve cases while the crimes continue to occur.<ref name=Livingston />  Fr, out of hds of cases, only three convictions have ever been made and there is much skepticism involving the integrity of the convictions.<ref name=Simmons />\n\nThe methodology and integrity of police investigations has been qoned due to allegations of torture and h rights violations of alleged sts.<ref name=Simmons /><ref name="Amnesty 4" /> Amnesty International reports, "The government has failed to take effective meas to investigate and bring to je those responsible for the abdn and killing of three women in Ci Ju\xe1rez... or to combat the ongoing pattern of violence against women and discrimination in the city.<ref name="Amnesty 3">\n\n\nAccording to Pantaleo, "While around 400 girls and women have been abd and med, few arrests and convictions have res."<ref name="Pantaleo 2"> For convictions that have been made, there is a great deal of controversy that snds them.<ref name="Pantaleo 2" />  Police have been acc of condg r investigations with qonable methodology and integrity.<ref name=Simmons />  Fr, sts that have been apprehended have claimed that they were tort into confessing.<ref name=Simmons /><ref name="Pantaleo 2" /> This has ca tainty of the legitimacy of both investigations and convictions.<ref name=Simmons /><ref name="Pantaleo 2" />\n\nIn 1996, an Egyptian national, Omar Sharif Latif or Abdul Latif Sharif was convicted of 3 ms and sentenced to a 30-year prison term.<ref name=Simmons />  After his arrest in 1995, the ms continued and aities claimed that Sharif directed members of the "Los Rebeldes" gang to continue the ms while he was incarcerated.<ref name="Fragoso 2" /> These members were indicted and convicted as a result of this connection.<ref name=Simmons /> The gang members acc of carrying out ms  Sharifs orders claimed they were tort while in police cy.<ref name="Fragoso 2" /> According to Monarrez Fragoso, "In the year 2000, it was known that the body of Elizabeth Castro Garcia, whose m was attrib to Omar Sharif Latif, does not belong to her."<ref name="Fragoso 2" /> His conviction is ctly  appeal.<ref name=Simmons />\n\nIn 2001, Victor Garcia Uribe and Go Gonzalez Meza were apprehended for eight ms.<ref name=Simmons /> Go Gonzalez Mesa died sio while in police cy.<ref name=Simmons /> In 2004, Victor Garcia Uribe, a bus driver, was convicted of eight ms that took place in 2001.<ref name=Simmons />  He confessed to these ms but claimed that he was tort into confessing by police.<ref name=Simmons/>\n\nIn 2008, 16-year-old Ruby Frayre Escobedo was med by Sergio Barraza Bocanegra who  was acqd at  his first  trial  for lack  of evidence. Following  two  years of activism, a retrial  convicted Bocanegra who  remained on  the run. In  2010, Rubys mother, Marisela Escobedo Ortiz, was assassinated by  a shot  to  the head at  point  blank  range while demonstrating  for je in  front  of the Governors Palace in Chih (state).<ref name="icm"><ref name="EU">\n\n\nThere have been several international rs against Mexico for its inadeq response to the increasing violence against women.<ref name=CEDAW /><ref name="Amnesty 2" /> According to Livingston, "In 1998 the National Commission for H Rights issued a report charging gross irregties and general negligence in state investigations, incl the misidentification of corpses, failure to obtain expert tests on forensic evidence, failure to conduct aies or obtain semen analysis...  failure to file written reports, and incompetence in keeping records of the rising tide of women ms."<ref name=Livingston />\n\nIn 2004,  the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) cond an inq into the allegations that hds of ms of women and girls had taken place in the area of Ci J since 1993 at the g of several NGOs.<ref name=CEDAW /> In order for the inq to take place it was req that there was reliable evidence that showed that Mexico was in violation of rights established by CEDAW.<ref name=CEDAW /> The Committee analyzed the gender-based crimes occg in Ci Ju\xe1rez and found the two common forms were m and disappearances. The Committee also analyzed the response of the government and found that their initial response was indifference and that the government exhibited tolerance of these crimes for years.<ref name=CEDAW>\n\nFr, the Committee concl that the meas taken by the Mexican State in response to gendered violence against women leading up to the time of their inq were, "few and ineffective at all levels of the State".<ref name=CEDAW /> The Committee made several recommendations for Mexico to adhere to. Although these recommendations were not legally binding, they were inflal in the p sphere.<ref name=CEDAW />\n\nAccording to Amnesty International, "In 2009, the Inter-American Court of H Rights r on the \u201ccotton field\u201d (Campo Algodonero in Cd. J) case that Mexico was g of discrimination and of failing to protect three young women med in 2001 in Ci Ju\xe1rez or to ensure an effective investigation into their abdn and m."<ref name="Amnesty 2"> The Court ordered Mexico to conduct a new investigation of the ms, create a national memorial for the victims, pay reparations to the families of the victims, and to improve meas which prevent and adeqy investigate the m of women and girls.<ref name="El Paso Times" /><ref name="Amnesty 2" />\n\n\n\n\nAccording to Simmons, "The ms in Ju\xe1rez would not have drawn such national and international attention if it were not for the heroic efforts of the victims families and other women."<ref name=Simmons /> There have been nus local and international organizations that have helped draw attention to the issue of the m of women in J which has helped to create pressure for the Mexican government to agree to fr its efforts to respond to violence against women.<ref name=Amnesty /> Fr, the work of political leaders, activists, artists, academics, and joists combined have also been instral in bringing international attention to the m of women in Ju\xe1rez and the issues that snd them.<ref name=Wright />\n\nIn 1999, a group of feminist activists fo Casa Amiga, Ju\xe1rezs first rape crisis and sexual assault center.<ref name="Wright 2"> The center works to provide women in Ju\xe1rez with a refuge against violence, therapy, legal co, and medical attention.<ref name="Wright 2" /> Casa Amiga also works to raise p awareness both locally and internationally regarding the exploitation and dehzation of women in Ju\xe1rez.\n\nIn 2002, a social je movement named Ni Una Mas, which in Spanish means "not one more," was formed to raise international awareness to violence against women in Ju\xe1rez.<ref name=Wright /> The movement consists of a variety of domestic and international organizations and individual activists.<ref name=Wright /> Ni Una Mas participants demand that the Mexican state implement strategies that prevent violence against women incl m and kidnappings and that the state conduct competent investigations on crimes already committed.<ref name=Wright />\n\nIn addition to Casa Amiga and Ni Una Mas, family st groups such as Nas Hijas de Regreso a Casa A.C., which in Spanish means "Our Dars Back Home," have also formed in response to the violence against women in Ju\xe1rez.<ref name="Wright 2" /> Nas Hijas de Regreso a Casa A.C. has also worked to bring domestic and international media attention to the violence against women in Ju\xe1rez.<ref name=Lorenzo>\n\n\n\n\n* The American television series The Bridge (2013 TV series) (2013)  the disappearance of the girls of Ju\xe1rez as part of the backdrop to a series of ms.\n\n\n*The film Blood Rising (2013) directed by Mark McLon, docary which examines the phenomenon of femicide in Ju\xe1rez through the work of an artist, Brian Mag.\n*The film Backyard: El Traspatio (2009), directed by Carlos Carrera, is based on these events.\n*The film Bordertown (2006 film) (2006), starring Jennifer Lopez and Antonio Banderas, is loosely based on these ms.\n*The film Se\xf1orita Extraviada/Missing Young Woman (2001) by Lo Portillo, is a docary following the femicides of Ju\xe1rez.\n*The film Sicario (2015 film) (2015) is about a principled FBI agent who is enlisted by a government task force to help bring down the leader of a powerful and br Mexican drug cartel.\n*The docary film Equal Means Equal (2016) directed by Kamala Lopez feat a segment on the women of Ju\xe1rez. \n\n\n*Tori Amos wrote a song about these incidents titled "Ju\xe1rez", for her album To Venus and Back (1999-2000), after reading about them.\n*At the Drive-Ins song "Invalid Litter Dept." In the lyrics, the incidents are referred to as femicides.\n* The World Is a Beal Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Dies song "Jan 10th, 2014" is about the ms and the vigilante je that took place in (2005), addresses this topic.\n* "Each and Her" (2010) by Valerie Martinez is a book-length poem that addresses the ms in the context of politics, gender oppression, mythology, art, and more.\n* "If I Row(id=309525, title=u'Midwest Christian Outreach', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nMidwest Christian Och, Inc (MCOI), is a non-denominational, conservative evangelicalism organization.<ref name="anerated1">http://www.midwestoch.org/01-AboutUs/01-PeopleAndPe/MissionCaseVisionStatements.html Mission, Case and Vision Statements of Midwest Christian Och<!-- Bot generated title -->  It is a Chicago st group that encos people to leave c or groups they deem cult-like\n\nIt has branches in Lohrville, Iowa; Salisbury, North Carolina; Scranton, Kansas; and Spring Hill, Florida.<ref>http://www.midwestoch.org/01-AboutUs/01-PeopleAndPe/01-BranchOffices/index.html Branch Offices of Midwest Christian Och<!-- Bot generated title --> \n\nIts mission statement: "Midwest Christian Och, Inc., is a non-denominational, evangelical organization that exists to defend the Gospel of Jesus Christ, especially to those who conscio reject it due to what MCO deems "false beliefs", and to challenge and equip believing Christians to do the same.<ref name="anerated1" />\n \nMCOI is headed by Don Veinot, who is a former atheist, who acts as president.  His wife and three others serve as board members of the organization.<ref>http://www.midwestoch.org/01-AboutUs/01-PeopleAndPe/BoardOfDirectors.html Board of Directors, Midwest Christian Och<!-- Bot generated title --> \n\nSince 1995, MCOI has prod a self-phed jo which is mailed out three to four times a year with a circon of  2,000. It is also available online in Adobe PDF format called the Midwest Christian Och Jo.  The jo consists of three or four articles each issue, with either Don Veinot or his wife writing at least one article each time, and a small group of other like-minded conservatives that are freq contrib.<ref>http://www.midwestoch.org/02-Information/02-OnlineReference/04-Etc/01-TheJo/index.html The Midwest Christian Och Jo<!-- Bot generated title --> \n\nMidwest Christian Och is based in Row(id=314174, title=u'Kajukenbo', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n Territory of Hawaii\n| creator      = Adriano Emperado, Peter Young Yil Choo, Joe Holck, Frank Ordonez, George Chang\n| parenthood   = Kara-Ho Kempo, Danzan-ryu, Judo, Shotokan Karate, Tang Soo Do, Chuan Fa, Boxing, Eskrima<ref name="auto"/>\n| famous_pract = John Hackleman, Sage Northcutt, David Betlewski, Chuck Liddell\n| olympic      = No\n| website      =\n\nKajo (Japanese lang: \u30ab\u30b8\u30e5\u30b1\u30f3\u30dc Kajo) is a hybrid martial arts from Hawaii. The name Kajo is a portmanteau of the various arts from which its style is derived: KA for Karate, JU for Judo and Ju, KEN for Kenpo and BO for Boxing.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="Emperado">\n\nIt was developed in the late 1940s and fo in 1947 in the Palama Settlement of Oahu, Hawaii. The art was created through the cooperative efforts of five martial artists, each with a different specialty: Peter Choo, Frank Ordonez, Joe Holck, George Chang and Adriano Emperado.<ref name="emperado">\n\nKajo training incorporates a blend of Strike (attack), kicking, throwing, takedown (grappling), joint locks and weapon disarmament.<ref name="auto">\n\nToday, Kajo is practiced all over the world in many different branches. In contrast to many traditional martial arts, sts are not req to mimic their teacher, but are encod to develop their own "expression" of the art.\n\n\n"Through this fist style one gains long life and happiness."<ref name="Usadojo">\n\n\nKajo was fo in 1947 in the Palama Settlement on Oahu, Hawaii. In the late 1940s, the Palama Settlement was a violent area. Due to this environment, five martial artists from varying backgro came together with the goal of developing an art that would be practical and effective on the street. These fos so to develop one style that would complement each of their individual styles and yet allow for effective fighting at a greater variety of ranges and speeds.\n\nThe five fog members of Kajo were:<ref name="Emperado"/>\n* Adriano Directo Emperado \u2014 Kara-Ho Kempo and Eskrima\n* Joseph Holck \u2014 Judo\n* Peter Young Yil Choo \u2014 Tang Soo Do, Shotokan Karate and Boxing\n* Frank F. Ordonez \u2014 Danzan-ry\u016b\n* George Chang \u2014 Chuan Fa\n\nIn its conception, the fos followed a simple rule, if a technique worked consistently on the street (or against one another), then it stayed in the system, if it did not, it was discarded.  This allowed the style to maintain its self-defense focus, while covering limitations found within each of their traditional arts.\n\n\n*  Korean karate / Tang Soo Do\n*  Judo\n*  Kara-Ho Kempo\n*  Siu Lum Pai Gung Fu / Chinese Boxing\n*  Danzan-ry\u016b\n*  Chuan Fa\n*  Eskrima\n\n\nFile:Kajo-crest2.png|thumb|150px|right\nShortly after its conception, the Korean War broke out, and with it Joe Holck, Peter Choo, Frank Ordonez, and Clarence Chang left Hawaii on active military service, leaving only Adriano Emperado to continue teaching the system.\n\nEmperado and his brother Joe introd Kajo to the p by opening the Palama Settlement School in 1950. They called the school the Kajo Self Defense Institute (K.S.D.I.). The training there was notorio br. Their goal was to be invincible on the street, thus the sts sparred with full contact. Emperado had a motto, "The workout isnt over  I see blood on the floor". He also said "the best teacher is pain". His philosophy was that if someone was afraid of pain they would be defeated the first time they were hit. Those who remained developed into tough fighters with a repon for employing their art in street fights with little provocation.\n\nIn 1959,  Emperado continued to add more Kung Fu into Kajo, shifting the art to a more fluid combination of hard and soft techniques. Since then, Kajo has proved to be an improvement-based, continy evolving and open form. John Leoning, also helped bring out the "bo" of Kajo by pointing out that there should be no wasted motion.\n\nThe art slowly began to grow in popty, and soon Emperado had 12 Kajo schools in Hawaii, making it the second largest string of schools at the time. Joe Halbuna, Charles Gaylord, Tony Ramos and Aleju Reyes, who all earned a black belt from Emperado, bro Kajo to the U.S. mainland in 1960. They each opened Kajo schools in California. In 1969, Tony Ramos trained with and exchanged ideas and methods with Bruce Lee. Tonys version of Kajo became known as the "Ramos Method" and is kept alive by nus instrs.\n\nIn a 1991 interview with Black Belt Magazine, Emperado was asked who some of the Kajo toent stars were and said  According to Chuck Norris, in his book Against All Odds: My Story,  he won the middleweight title in 1967, at the Long Beach Internationals; then defeated Carlos B who had won the lightweight title.\n\n\n\nKajo continues to evolve with each generation and maintains its primary focus on realism and practicality. There are ly martial arts schools that will change along with time to fit into the days society. It is generally tho that "r" moves, such as strikes to the eyes or groin, are perfectly acceptable, as is whatever else the practitioner feels is necessary to get home that day.\n\nTraining workouts emphasize cardio conditioning and fonal strength. While individual schools may show variation, it would not be al to train with sandbags or boxing gloves. There are core self-defense techniques at the heart of Kajo and Kajo schools eschew impractical and flashy moves. Most kajo cula feature co-attacks to ps, kicks, grabs, as well as  knives, sticks and guns to co back. While this base of common knowledge will keep schools styles similar, there is plenty of room for variation. This openness tends to enco schools to incorporate other arts into their practice.  The primary concentration of all Kajo schools remains real world self-defense, because protecting ones self in a street-fighting sitn is primary.\n\nInnovation is what Kajo represents.  In each generation and legacies that are passed on from teacher to sts; there are changes that are inevitable.  Kokoro Healing and Empowerment is a concept derived from the Kajo Martial Arts.  Sigung Donna Ramos-B has taken Kajo and has incorporated Yoga/Pilates and Meditation to this fine art.  Targeted to women, she has helped many realize their empowerment through this program.  She was recognized by the State of California as an Innovative Finalist 2.0, a reward that recognizes healthier lifestyle living by exercising ors.  She continues to teach this to the Marin City comm and does "Empowering" workshops in Universities throt California.<ref>http://www.hphpbayarea.org/program/kokoro-healing-empowerment-program-0\n\n\n{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; text-align:center;"\n|+Traditional Belt Colors\n| | White ||  File:Judo white belt.svg\n|-\n| | Yellow ||  File:Judo yellow belt.svg\n|-\n| | Orange || File:Judo orange belt.svg\n|-\n| | P || File:Judo p belt.svg\n|-\n| | Blue ||  File:Judo blue belt.svg\n|-\n| | Green|| File:Judo green belt.svg\n|-\n| | Brown ||  File:Judo brown belt.svg\n|-\n| | Black || File:Judo black belt.svg\n|\nRanking hierarchies vary widely from school to school.\n\nTraditional Japanese martial art ranking is often followed.  One common belt order is as follows: white, yellow, orange, p, blue, green, brown, black. followed by the other various degrees of black belt. The schools have second and third stripe belts that feature a white for second or black for third stripe rg down the center of the belt.\n\nBlack belt rankings and titles can also vary, with most schools adopting either Chinese or Japanese titles.\n\n\n\n\nKenpo "Adriano Emperado Method" or "Traditional Hard Style".\n\n\nThe original style of Tum Pai might have been put together by Adriano D. Emperado, Al Dacascos and Al Dela Cruz in the early 60s to create an advanced style for the Kajo system. In the mid-60s the developments that made up Tum Pai became incorporated into what was called "Chuan Fa". In 1971 Jon A. Loren started incorporating the concepts of Tai-Chi and Son Sil-lum into his Kajo classes. This was called Northern Kajo  1976. In 1976, while staying with  Adriano Emperado in Hawaii, he demonstrated his concepts and techniques and asked if he could call it Tum Pai and bring the name back to life. Adriano Emperado granted permission with the acknowledgment that the original Tum Pai followed a different path than the revised Tum Pai soft style. The name Tum Pai, which means "central way", fits the Tai-Chi concept blended into the Kajo format.\n\n\nIn Hawaii d the early 1960s  Adriano Emperado, along with sts Al Dacascos and Al Dela Cruz, incorporated innovations of the style Tum Pai and other martial arts into their Kajo training. Later it became obvious that they were no longer doing Tum Pai and it would have to be named something else. In the mid 60s Al Dacascos moved to Northern California and continued training in the Northern and Son styles of Sil-lum Kung Fu to enhance his Kajo training. It was in 1965 that the name Chuan Fa was introd.\n\n\nWun Hop Kuen Do was fo by Al Dacascos, in Cantonese Chinese Wun Hop Kuen Do means "combination fist art style" Wun Hop Kuen Do techniques identify with, and are based on, the Kajo system. This martial arts style incorporates techniques from many different styles incl Northern and Son Kung Fu systems and Escrima. Since this style is always being developed it is not a fixed system. This means that practitioners of the style are always striving to improve it by the incorporation and improvement of l methods or techniques. In addition the philosophy of remaining "ed" also applies to the defense techniques, in that there is no defined response to a given sitn, and they attempt to fit the sitn as it arises. This idea leads to self-defense that is creative and allows one to think about what is the best response. This is one of the primary things that sets this style apart from most others, it is a martial art that asks you to think for yof and use your own common sense to act see what you should do next.  There are many drills to allow practice of this type of fly and creativity that lead to the ability to respond reflexively to any sitn \u2014 which is in contrast to many other training methods where one is sed to mimic techniques which are often not practical, except  very defined circnces.\n\n\nIn 1967 Charles Gaylord, along with other accomplished Kajo practitioners Aleju Reyes, Joe Halbuna, Tony Ramos, and Al Dacascos formed the Kajo Association of America (KAA.) The KAA organization lasted  the early 1970s, but it was bro back in 1980  the leadership of Charles Gaylord who had recently received his 9th degree black belt  fo Adrian Emperado. Fifteen years later in September 1995, the KAA\u2019s black belts promoted Charles Gaylord to the honorary rank of 10th degree black belt. Grandmaster Gaylords traditional Kajo c continues to be ta by his chief instrs who operate Kajo schools in Hawaii and other parts of the United States.<ref name="Usadojo"/>\n\n\nDeveloped by Prof. Vincent Holck, the son of Joseph Holck and nephew of Peter YY Choo, Ma Prof. Holck, Matsuno professes his teachings of Kajo  two systems.\n\nThe first system of Kajo is the Matsuno Ryu Goshinj. This system dedicates the introdn of Danzan Ryu Ju, by his father, into the Kajo system.\n\nThe second system of Kajo is the Matsuno Kajo Kai which dedicates the introdn of kickboxing into the Kajo system by his Uncle, Prof. Peter Choo.\n\n\n\nThe 1982 childrens book A B of Sticks by Pat Rhoads Ma, is the story of a fifth-grade boy Ben Tyler, who is being bd by a much larger boy named Boyd Bradshaw. One day Ben comes home from school with a badly br nose, so Bens parents decide to enroll him in a Kajo martial arts school. Ben reltly agrees to attend the school because his mother has already paid the instr who is known only as Sifu. At first Ben thinks he will not enjoy Kajo, but he event discovers how val his training is when he ssf defends himself from Boyd.\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.koamartialarts.com Kajo Ohana Association\n*
