Row(id=326141, title=u'Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n|feast_day= 3 May\n|venerated_in= Eastern Orthodox ch\n|image= Nikolaj-Velimirovi\u0107.jpg\n|imagesize= 220px\n|caption=\n|birth_place= Leli\u0107, Valjevo, Principality of Serbia\n|death_place= South Canaan Township, Wayne Co, Pennsylvania, U.S.\n|titles= Holy bishop\n|beatified_date=\n|beatified_place=\n|beatified_by=\n|canonized_date= 24 May 2003\n|canonized_place=\n|canonized_by= Serbian Orthodox Ch\n|attrib= Vested as a bishop\n|patronage=\n|major_shrine= Leli\u0107 monastery, Serbia\n\n\nSaint Nikolai Velimirovich of Ohrid and \u017di\u010da or Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 (Serbian Cyrillic: \u041d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u043b\u0430\u0458 \u0412\u0435\u043b\u0438\u043c\u0438\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0438\u045b; &nbsp;\u2013 ) was bishop of the eparchies of Ohrid and Eparchy of \u017di\u010da|\u017di\u010da (1920-1956) in the Serbian Orthodox Ch, an inflal theological writer and a highly gifted orator, known as The New Chrysostom.<ref name="orthodoxinfo">\n\nHis birth name was Nikola. As a young man, he came close to dying of dysentery, and decided that he would dedicate his life to God if he sed. Se he did, and was tonsured as a monk  the name Nikolaj. He was ordained into the clergy, and qy became an important leader and spokesperson for the Serbian Orthodox Ch, especially in its relations with the West. When the Nazi Germany occ Yavia in World War II, Velimirovi\u0107 was imprisoned and event taken to Dachau concentration camp in Germany.\n\nAfter being liberated by the Allies of World War II at the end of the war, he chose not to return to Yavia (which had a Socialist Federal Rep of Yavia by that time). He moved to the United States in 1946, where he remained  his death in 1956. He strongly sted the  of all Eastern Orthodox Ch and established particy good relationships with the Anglican and Episcopal Ch (United States).\n\n\n\n\nNikola Velimirovi\u0107 was born in the small village of Leli\u0107, Valjevo, Serbia, on the day of the feast of Saint Naum of Ohrid, whose monastery would later be his episcopal see. He was the first of nine children born to the family of pious farmers. Being very weak, he was baptised soon after his birth in the \u0106elije monastery, where his relics are now resting. He was given the name Nikola because Saint Nicholas was the familys patron saint.\n\nThe first lessons about God, Jesus Christ, the lives of the saints and the holy days of the Ch year were provided to him by his mother, who also regy took him to the \u0106elije monastery for prayer and Holy Comm.\n\n\n\nFile:St. Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 as a st.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Velimirovi\u0107 as a st\nHis formal edon also began in the \u0106elije monastery and continued in Valjevo. He applied for admission into the Military Academy, but was ref because he didnt pass the physical exam. He was admitted to the Seminary of Saint Sava in Belgrade, where he \u2014 apart from the standard sts \u2014 explored a significant n of writings of both Eastern and Western theological as. He grad in 1902.\n\nAs an onding st, he was chosen to continue his st in R and Western E. He had a gift for lang and soon possessed a good knowledge of Rn, French and German. From St. Petersburg he went to Switzerland and obtained his doctorate of divinity from the Old Catholic Theological Fac at the University of Berne. He received his doctorate in Theology in 1908, with the dissertation entitled Faith in the Restion of Christ as the Foion of the Dogmas of the Apostolic Ch. This original work was written in German and phed in Switzerland in 1910, and later translated into Serbian. The dissertation for his Doctorate in philosophy was prepared at Oxford and defended in Geneva, in French. The title was Berkeleys Philosophy.\n\n\n\nIn the a of 1909, Nikola ret home and became serio ill with dysentery. He decided to become a monk and devote his life to God if he stayed alive. At the end of 1909 his health got better and he was tons a monk, receiving the name Nikolaj. He was soon ordained a hieromonk and then elevated to the rank of Archimandrite.\n\n\n\nArchimandrite Nikolaj was chosen to be a professor in the Seminary of St. Sava in Belgrade. It was decided that he needed to accomplish Orthodox st before becoming a teacher. As was the c in those days, he was sent to Imperial R to continue his st. After his return to Belgrade in 1911, when he was thirty-one years old, he was appointed to the University of Belgrades Academy of Theology, teaching philosophy, logic, history and foreign lang. His talks and sermons were read avidly throt Serbia. This was partly because his exposition of the Christian faith was inspired by the life of St. Sava, the national patron saint of Serbia. In the Ch itself he had only the aity of his words and personality: he was just a monk, but even so he seemed destined to exert great infl. It was not ssing that in 1915 he was entr with a mission to Great Britain in order to gain the co-operation of the Ch of England in edng the young sts who had been evac when the Aan, German and Bian forces threatened to overwhelm the co. One of his sts in Belgrade was J Popovi\u0107.\n\n\n\nIn his lifetime, Father Nikolaj visited the United States four times. He visited England in 1910. He st English and was capable of addressing an ace and making a strong impression on the listeners. Shortly after the oak of World War I this contrib to his appointment by the Serbian government to a mission in the United States. In 1915, as an wn Serbian monk, he to most of the major U.S. cities, where he held nus lect, fighting for the  of the Serbs and South Slavic peoples. This mission gained gro: America sent over 20,000 volrs to E, most of whom later fo on the Salonika Front. D Velimirovi\u0107s US-campaign occ the great retreat of the Serbian Army through the mons of Albania. He embarked home in 1916; as his co was now in enemy hands, he went to England instead. His eloq and character made him an icial spokesman of his people. His ss was such that not only did he fl his mission, but he was also awarded a Doctor of Divinity honoris causa from the University of Cambridge.\n\nHe gave a series of notable lect at St. Margarets, Westminster, and preached in St. Pauls Cathedral as well as in other cathedrals and chs throt the land. He also preached in the Episcopal chapel, where his practical disco attracted many hearers. Velimirovi\u0107 became celebrated. At the same time he was active in the promotion of the Serbian Relief Fund and was ssful in obtaining a rsity edon for Serb sts, several of whom, incl Bishop Irinej of Dalmatia, took their degrees before they ret to their own co after the war. In 1918, Velimirovi\u0107 ret to the United States for a second visit, but as a celebrity who was to address the American people as a whole on behalf of Serbian relief. In 1919 he received another Honorary Doctorate of Divinity from the University of Glasgow. From Glasgow his repute as a theological scholar and preacher spread throt the United Kingdom. After the war, he ret to Belgrade in April 1919.\n\n\n\nIn 1919, Archimandrite Nikolaj was consecrated Bishop of \u017di\u010da but did not remain long in that diocese, being asked to take over the office of Bishop in the Eparchy of Ohrid (1920-1931) and Eparchy of Ohrid and Bitola (1931-1936) in son parts of Kingdom of Yavia. Whether that was his own wish is not clear. It was in a way a mission post for the people of the lately recovered Serbian territory were backward and there were still vestiges of the Ottoman days still prevailing in habit, pagan stition and even black magic.\n\nThe percentage of illiteracy was very high and the popon was for the most part very poor. He had many diffics there but a great n of h folk became attached to him and felt that even to touch his hand was to receive a blessing. For many years his seat was the ancient monastery of Sveti Naum at the south end of the Lake Ohrid. It was there that he wrote Ohridski Prologue. In 1920, for the third time, he joed again to the United States, this time on a mission to organize the Serbian Orthodox Diocese of North America.\nThe Ok Magazine carried an interesting story about Bishop Nikolaj after visiting the United States in their 23 Febr 1921 issue (pp.&nbsp;285\u201386):<blockq>"He is Bishop of Ohrid, near the Albanian border, and is a pop and beloved leader of the Serbian Orthodox Ch.  Last s an American accompanied him on a jo into the mons, where he was to preach in a remote village ch. They found the roads lined for twenty-five miles with men, women and children, who had joed far on foot to greet him, and in the mon ch the densely packed people had been standing all through the night...."</blockq>\n\nFinally, in 1927, he came to the U.S. once more, to speak before the Institute of Politics in Williamstown, Massachs. A reporter covering the event, wrote:<blockq>"His black monks robe, his long black beard, and his dark, living eyes, set in an oval Slavic face, gave him an appearance which contrasted as strongly with that of conventionally dressed professors and diplomats as did his views of the common problems of world peace contrast with theirs. His charm and ity of manner, the completeness of his grasp  international problems only emphasized the difference in his tho....Bishop Nikolaj, speaking from the point of view of a civilization in which men still are more important than instits, points out that peace or war is a matter of the way men think and feel toward each other, and that all other things are only owths of this. The greatest force for affecting mens attit toward each other he believes would be a red Christian Ch" (Living Age, Vol. 335-36, 1928-29).</blockq>\n\nIn 1935, he reconstr the cemetery of the fallen German soldiers from World War I in Bitola. D the Milan Stojadinovi\u0107 administration when the Patriarchate became vacant (after the poisoning of Patriarch Varnava and the failed attempt at ratifying a Concordat with the Holy See) he was reportedly an obvious choice but allegedly too greatly identified with the democratic idealism of England and the United States of America (places he freqy visited) while Stojadinovi\u0107 leaned towards Germany and Italy.\n\nStill, except for his ering opposition to Comm, there was very little that could be labelled "political" in Velimirovi\u0107s ministrations and writings. The most that could be said was that he strove to keep Serbia alive after it had been merged into the larger state of Yavia. He started a movement for the renewal and care of the old chs, shrines and cemeteries in Macedonia. It had been at his stion that the large illted volume South Slav Mons was compiled and then phed in London, and when he was made Bishop of Ohrid he began that work of restoration which still continues to this day.\n\n\n\nIn 1936, he finally res his original office of Bishop in the Eparchy of \u017di\u010da, retg to the Monastery of \u017di\u010da not far distant from Valjevo and Leli\u0107, where he was born. At \u017di\u010da he started a movement for the revival of the Serb Ch, evoking the inspiration of its patron saint Saint Sava. He seldom gave a sermon without mentioning the saints name. Event in exile he wrote the only sntial biography of St. Sava which we have. In the years preceding the oak of World War II, Velimirovi\u0107, contin his campaign for a Serb revival, instit what may be called a Society of Prayer and renewed the ancient c of Christians gathering together to visit a friends house for prayer, in that way making Christianity social rather than individtic and solitary. This social prayer extended over a large area and drew national attention. It was described in the newspapers, and pict of the benign and now almost apostolic coance of Bishop Nikolaj appeared in S editions.\n\n\n\nD World War II, in 1941, as soon as the German forces occ Yavia, Bishop Nikolaj was arrested by the Nazis in the Monastery of \u017di\u010da, after which he was confined in the Monastery of Ljinja. Later he was transferred to the Monastery of Vojlovica Monastery (near Pan\u010devo) in which he was confined together with the Serbian Patriarch Gavrilo V  the end of 1944. On 15 September 1944, both Serbian Patriarch Gavrilo V (Do\u017ei\u0107) and Bishop Nikolaj were sent to Dachau concentration camp, which was at that time the main Dachau concentration camp#priests arrested by the Nazis. Both Velimirovi\u0107 and Do\u017ei\u0107 were held as special prisoners (Ehrenh\xe4ftlinge) imprisoned in the so-called Ehrenb (or Prominentenb) separated from the work camp area, together with high-ranking Nazi enemy officers and other prominent prisoners whose arrests had been dictated by Hitler directly.<ref>Leisner, Karl. Priesterweihe und Primiz im KZ Dachau, pg. 183, LIT Verlag Berlin-Hamburg-M\xfcnster, 2004; ISBN 3825872777, 9783825872779\n\nIn A 1943 German general Hermann Neer became special emissary of the German Foreign Office for Sostern E. From 11 September 1943, he was also made responsible for Albania. In December 1944, Velimirovi\u0107 and Do\u017ei\u0107 were transferred from Dachau to Slovenia, together with Milan Nedi\u0107, the Serbian collaborationist PM, as the Nazis attempted to make use of Patriarch Gavrilos and Nikolajs aity among the Serbs in order to gain allies in the anti-Comm movements. Contrary to claims of torture and abuse at the camp, Patriarch Do\u017ei\u0107 testified himself that both he and Velimirovi\u0107 were treated normally.<ref>Glasnik Pravoslavne Crkve, July 1946, pp 66-67. Also in Do\u017ei\u0107 G., Memoari patrijarha srpskog Gavrila (Beograd: Sfairos 1990), entries for December 1944.\n\nLater, Velimirovi\u0107 and Patriarch Gavrilo (Do\u017ei\u0107) were moved to Aa, and were finally liberated by the US 36th Infantry Division (United States) in Tyrol (state) in 1945. He was physically weakened by these vicissit. He was bro to England. Velimirovi\u0107 and Do\u017ei\u0107 were at Westminster Abbey at the baptism of King Peter II of Yavias son and heir, Crown Prince Alexander of Yavia. Velimirovi\u0107 preached a very moving sermon at the Serb chapel in the house in Egerton Gardens. But there was no place for him in England such as there had been d the First World War. Patriarch Gavrilo, being old and ill, ret to what then came to be known as the Socialist Federal Rep of Yavia, where he died soon after his arrival. Velimirovi\u0107 opted to emigrate to the United States.\n\nHe was allowed to spend the last years of his life in the United States, only retg once to England when he came to consecrate the Ch of St Sava in 1952, an occasion when Serbs in the thos rallied from the mines and factories of England to the walls of the great ch in Ladbroke Grove. The sacred edifice was packed and the overflow crowd streamed all the way to the London Underground, with Velimirovi\u0107s voice sog through the air on loakers.\n\n\nAfter the war he never ret to the Socialist Federal Rep of Yavia, but after spending some time in E, he finally immigrated as a ref to the United States in 1946. There, in spite of his health problems, he continued his missionary work, for which he is considered An Apostle and Missionary of the New Continent (q by Fr. Alexander Schmemann), and has also been enlisted as an American Saint\n\nHe ta at several Eastern Orthodox Ch seminary such as St. Savas Seminary (Libertyville, Illinois), Saint Tikhons Orthodox Theological Seminary and Monastery (South Canaan, Pennsylvania), and St. Vladimirs Orthodox Theological Seminary (now in Crestwood, New York).\n\n\n\nVelimirovi\u0107 died on 18 March 1956, while in prayer at the foot of his bed before the Lit, at the Rn Orthodox Monastery of St. Tikhon in South Canaan Township, Wayne Co, Pennsylvania in the United States. He was b near the tomb of poet Jovan Du\u010di\u0107 at the Monastery of St. Sava at Libertyville, Illinois. After the fall of comm, his remains were ately re-b in his home town of Leli\u0107 on 12 May 1991, next to his parents and his nephew, Bishop Jovan Velimirovi\u0107. On 19 May 2003, the Holy Assembly of Bishops of the Serbian Orthodox Ch recognized Bishop Nikolaj (Velimirovi\u0107) of Ohrid and \u017di\u010da as a saint and decided to include him into the calendar of saints of Holy Orthodox Ch (18 March and 3 May).\n\n\n\nSeveral of Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107\u2019s writings and p speeches have been identified by historians as containing Antisemitism rhetoric and/or hate speech directed at Jews.\n\nNotably, the first written record of Velimirovi\u0107s antisemitic beliefs comes over a decade before the start of World War II and his stay at the Dachau concentration camp. In fact, the first chronicled case of Velimirovi\u0107 expressing antisemitic beliefs dates back to a 1927 sermon delivered in the United States.<ref name=":0">\n\nFrom the 1927 sermon titled \u201cA Story about the Wolf and the Lamb,\u201d Velimirovi\u0107\u2019s proclamations are sized by social psychologist Jovan Byford: <blockq>\u201cIn his take on the well known Christian parable about the wolf and the lamb, Velimirovi\u0107 referred to \u201cJewish leaders in Jerm\u201d at the time of the crxion as \u201cwolves,\u201d whose thirst for blood of the Lamb of God was motivated by their \u201cgod-hating nationalism.\u201d<ref name=":0" /></blockq>Byfords sy of Velimirovi\u0107s "A Story about the Wolf and the Lamb" is significant for it serves as evidence that Velimirovi\u0107 may have zed biblical tones and Christian parable as a means of validating his antisemitic statements to his followers. An interview that Jovan Byford cond with Mladen Obradovi\u0107 (leader of Serbian far-right political organization Obraz (organization)) may st that this explanation still persists among some members of Serbian Orthodox Ch society. A contemporary defender of Velimirovi\u0107s repon and saint status, Obradovi\u0107 defends the antisemitic writings of Velimimirovi\u0107 by stating that Velimirovi\u0107s words only echo what had been written in early Christian texts:<ref name=":1">  <blockq>\u201cYou have the very words of the Lord Jesus Christ when he says to the Pharisees that they are a \u201cbrood of vipers\u201d or that their father is the Devil; Bishop Nikolaj merely q the Gospels."<ref name=":1" /></blockq>In a speech delivered in 1936 at the \u017dica Monastery in Serbia, Velimirovi\u0107 spoke out against what he perceived to be a Jewish threat to Christianity in front of a distingd ace that incl Yavian Prime Minister Milan Stojadinovi\u0107. Velimirovi\u0107  specific lines of this speech to accuse Jews of leading a secretive, coordinated effort against Christianity and "faith in real God".<ref name=":2">\n\nVelimirovi\u0107s writing in Words to the Serbian People Through the Prison Window is generally seen as the strongest evidence of the Canonization Bishop holding antisemitic beliefs. Notably, many proponents of Velimirovi\u0107s ideology st that the work is not definitive evidence of the Bishops true ideology and beliefs about Jews and Jm because they claim that it was written  d d his time at Dachau concentration camp. The excerpts from Velimirovi\u0107s Words to the Serbian People Through the Prison Window that attract the most attention from scholars stg antisemitism are q in Jovan Byfords Denial and Repression of Antisemitism: Post-Comm Remembrance of the Serbian Bishop Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 as follows:<blockq>"The Devil teaches them Jews; the Devil ta them how to stand against the son of God, Jesus Christ. The Devil ta them through the cent how to fight against the sons of Christ, against the children of light, against the followers of the Gospel and eternal life Christians. ...<ref name=":2" /></blockq><blockq>"E knows nothing other than what Jews serve up as knowledge. It believes nothing other than what Jews order it to believe. It knows the value of nothing  Jews impose their own measure of values \u2026 all modern ideas incl democracy, and strikes, and socialism, and atheism, and religious tolerance, and pacifism, and global revol, and capitalism, and comm are the inventions of Jews, or rather their father, the Devil.<ref name=":3"></blockq>Additionally, Jovan Byford identifies the antisemitic ideology of Velimirovi\u0107 in the work, Indian Letters in which the figure of a Jewish woman portrays Satan.<ref name=":3" /> Notably, this example of Velimirovi\u0107s antisemitic portrayal is again linked to Conspiracy theory as Velimirovi\u0107 describes the woman as standing for, "all destre and secret associations plotting against Christianity, religion, and the state."<ref name=":3" />\n\nDespite accons of antisemitism, it is recorded that Velimirovi\u0107 protected a Jewish family by facilitating their escape from Nazi-occ Serbia. Ela Trif\u0107 (Ela Nayhaus), wrote to the Serbian Orthodox Ch in 2001, claiming that she had spent 18 months hiding in the Ljinja monastery to which she was smd by Velimirovi\u0107, gd and later helped move on with false papers.<ref>\u0421\u0432\u0435\u0442\u0438 \u0412\u043b\u0430\u0434\u0438\u043a\u0430 \u041d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u043b\u0430\u0458 \u041e\u0445\u0440\u0438\u0434\u0441\u043a\u0438 \u0438 \u0416\u0438\u0447\u043a\u0438, (Holy Bishop Nikolaj of Ohrid and \u017di\u010da)(\u017di\u010da Monastery, Kraljevo 2003), p. 179 Historians inclined to side with views that Velimirovi\u0107s writings prove that he held antisemitic beliefs note that this one incidence of the Bishop saving a Jewish family is commonly exaggerated by pro-Velimirovi\u0107 groups as evidence of his rsal kindness and selflessness against the several confirmed antisemitic writings tied to Velimirovi\u0107.\n\n===Velimirovi\u0107 and Hitler===\nAdolf Hitler decorated Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 in 1935 for his contribs to the restoration of a German military cemetery in Bitola in 1926.<ref>Byford, J., "Denial and Repression of Antisemitism: Post-comm Remembrance of the Serbian Bishop Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107" (CEU Press, 2008), p. 47.<!--ISSN/ISBN needed--> Some claim that the order was ret in protest at German aggression in 1941.<ref>See letter "Poveli ste se za mi\u0161ljenjem Filipa Koena" in Danas, 27 July 2002.\n\nIn a treatise on St. Sava in 1935, he sted Hitlers treatment of the German national ch<ref>Radi\u0107, R. Dr\u017eava i verske zajednice 1945-1970 (Institut za noviju istoriju Srbije; Beegrad 1970), p. 80 and is q as saying:<blockq>"However, a due respect is to be to the ct German Leader, who being a simple craftsman and a man from the people, realized that nationalism without faith is an anomaly, a cold and insecure mechanism. And so, in the XX century, he came to the idea of Saint Sava, and as a layman took among his people that most important work, befitting a saint, a genius and a hero. And for us that work has been accomplished by Saint Sava, the first among the saints, the first among the geni and the first among the heroes in our history. He accomplished it perfectly, he accomplished it without fight and without blood, and he accomplished it not yesterday or the day before, but 700 years ago."<ref>See "Nationalism of Saint Sava", in Collected Works of Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 (Vladimir Maksimovi\u0107: Belgrade 1996), page 36.<!--ISSN/ISBN needed--></blockq>\n\n===Velimirovi\u0107 and Ljoti\u0107===\nVelimirovi\u0107 had a high opinion of Dimitrije Ljoti\u0107, a Serbian fascist politician and German collaborationist.<ref>Sc, D., Episkop Nikolaj i Pravoslavni Bogomoljacki Pokret (Nova Iskra, beograd 1996), p. 195 et al. Also Byford, J, "Potiskivanje i poricanje antisemtizma", Helsin\u0161ki odbor za lj prava, Beograd, Ogledi, Br. 6, p. 33 and Marti\u0107, M., 1980, "Dimitrije Ljoti\u0107 and the Yav National Movement Zbor, 1935-1945" in "East Ean Qrly," Vol. 16, No. 2, pp. 219-39.\n\nIn an interview given in the United States in 1953, Velimirovi\u0107 claimed that he was the spiritual gray eminence behind the nationalist and collaborating extreme-right ZBOR organization.<ref>Popov, N. (1993) Srpski popm od marginalne do dominantne pojave. (Serbian pop from a marginal to a dominant phenomenon). Vreme 133:1\u201335. More on Velimirovi\u0107 and Ljoti\u0107 also in Cohen, P., Riesman, D, Serbias Secret War: Propaganda and the Deceit of History (Texas A&M University Press 1997), Chapter I, page 21 (also note 95), page 26, page 59 The military arm of that organization (SDK - Srpski Dobrovolja\u010dki Korpus - Serbian Volr Corps (World War II)) was fighting against both Yav Partisans and Chetniks in World War II and was responsible for nus civilian execs in Serbia of both Serbs and other nationals (Jews, Roma, etc.) When the leader of ZBOR, Dimitrije Ljoti\u0107, was arrested in 1940 by the Kingdom of Yavia government, Velimirovi\u0107 protested in a letter to the PM, Dragi\u0161a Cvetkovi\u0107.<ref>Jankovi\u0107, M., Vladika Nikolaj: \u017eivot, misao i delo, (Bishop Nikolaj: his life, tho and work). 3 vols. (Valjevo: Eparhija \u0160aba\u010dko\u2013Valjevska 2002) Velimirovi\u0107 attended Ljoti\u0107s fl in 1945 and spoke very positively of him even though it was already known that Ljoti\u0107 was collaborating with the Germans. He spoke of Ljoti\u0107 as an "ideologue of Serbian nationalism".<ref>Kosti\u0107, B. (1991). Za Istoriju Na\u0161ih Dana: Odlomci iz zapisa za vreme okje (For the history of our days: extracts from a diary at the time of the occon). Beograd: Nova Iskra and S\u0107, D. (1993). Pravoslavlje izme\u0111u Istoka i Zapada u bogoslovnoj misli Nikolaja Velimirovi\u0107a i Ja Popovi\u0107a Orthodoxy between East and West in the religious tho of Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 and J Popovi\u0107. In \u010covek i Crkva u Vrtlogu Krize: \u0160ta nam nudi pravoslavlje danas? Man and Ch in the vortex of crisis: What can Orthodoxy offer us today?, ed. G. \u017divkovi\u0107. Valjevo: Glas Crkve.<!--page(s), ISSN/ISBN needed-->\n\n===Velimirovi\u0107 and Germans===\nIn spite of accons of collaboration leveled d Comm times, some of Velimirovi\u0107s actions and writings were directed against the Germans who got sious of him when he sted the coup in April 1941.<ref>Jevti\u0107, A., "Kosovska misao i opredeljenje Episkopa Nikolaja", Glas crkve, 1988, No. 3, p. 24<!--ISSN/ISBN needed--> They sted him of collaborating with the Chetniks and formally arrested him and kept him first in Ljinja Monastery in 1941 and then in 1944 in Dachau concentration camp.\n\nIn Dachau, he was imprisoned in Ehrenb, together with other clergy and high-ranking Nazi enemy officers, and was allowed to wear his own religious clothes, having access to the officers canteen. It is claimed that he was never tort and had access to officers medical services. Contrary to the reports that Velimirovi\u0107 was liberated when the Americans 36th Division reached Dachau, both he and Patriarch Do\u017ei\u0107 were act released in December 1944, having spent three months in the camp. They travelled to Slovenia, from where Velimirovic continued first to Aa then to United States.<ref>"Sve\u0161tenici u koncentracionom logoru Dahau", Glasnik Srpske pravoslavne crkve - Serbian Orthodox Ch Official Gazette, volume XXXVII, July 1946, p. 66-67. See also Serbias Secret War: Propaganda and the Deceit of History (Texas A&M University Press 1997), pp. 58-60, 105-107.<ISSN/ISBN needed--> However, there is doced evidence, incl photographs of Bishop Nikolaj (Velimirovi\u0107) and Patriarch Gavrilo (Do\u017ei\u0107) present at the baptismal of Prince Alexander (Kara\u0111or\u0111evi\u0107) in London, England, in 1945 before Nikolaj emigrated in 1946 to the U.S. and Patriarch Gavrilo ret home.\n\n\nAmfilohije Radovi\u0107  points out that part of his ss lies in his high edon and ability to write well and his standing of Ean ce.<ref>Radvovic, A. "Bogocovjecanski etos Valdike Nikolaja" in Jevtic, A., Sveti Valdika Nikolaj Ohridski i Zicki (Kraljevo, \u017di\u010da 2003)\n\nVelimirovi\u0107 is viewed as less original by non-theologians. Literary critic Milan Bogdanovi\u0107 claims that everything Velimirovi\u0107 wrote after his Ohrid years did nothing more than paraphrase Orthodox canon and dogma. Bogdanovi\u0107 views him as a conservative who glorified the Ch and its ceremonies as an instit. This, however, is explained by true Orthodox tho, because, as Saint John of Damascus writes, "It is for that reason that I say (teach) nothing of what is mine. I briefly express the tho and words passed down by Godly and wise men."\n\n\n*http://www.rastko.org.rs/svecovek/dost/vlnikolaj/vlnikolaj-boka.html \u041c\u043e\u0458\u0435 \u0443\u0441\u043f\u043e\u043c\u0435\u043d\u0435 \u0438\u0437 \u0411\u043e\u043a\u0435 (1904) (My memories from Boka)\n*http://www.gerg.org/etext/15891 Franz\xf6sisch-slavische K\xe4mpfe in der Bocca di Cattaro (1910)\n*Beyond Sin and Death (1914)\n*http://www.gerg.org/etext/13301 The New Ideal in Edon (1916)\n*http://www.gerg.org/etext/13388 The Religious Spirit of the Slavs (1916)\n*The Spiritual Rebirth of E (1917)\n*Orations on the Universal Man (1920)\n*http://www.rastko.org.rs/svecovek/dost/vlnikolaj/vlnikolaj_molitva.html \u041c\u043e\u043b\u0438\u0442\u0432\u0435 \u043d\u0430 \u0458\u0435\u0437\u0435\u0440\u0443 (1922)\n*Tho on Good and Evil (1923)\n*Homilias, vol I and II (1925)\n*http://www.rastko.org.rs/istorija/sv_jovan_vladimir_c.html \u0427\u0438\u0442\u0430\u043d\u043a\u0430 \u043e \u0421\u0432\u0435\u0442\u043e\u043c\u0435 \u043a\u0440\u0430\u0459\u0443 \u0408\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0443 \u0412\u043b\u0430\u0434\u0438\u043c\u0438\u0440\u0443 ()\n*http://www.westsrbdio.org/prolog/my.html? Row(id=362048, title=u'Consequences of Nazism', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNazism and the acts of the Nazi Germany profo affected many coes, commes and people before, d and after World War II. While the attempt of the regime to exterminate several nations viewed as Untermensch by Nazi ideology was event stopped by the Allies of World War II, Nazi aggression nevertheless led to the deaths of millions of Jews and the ruin of several states.\n\n\n\nOf the worlds 15 million Jews in 1939, more than a third were killed in the Holocaust. Of the three million Jews in Poland, the heartland of Ean Jewish ce, fewer than 350,000 sed. Most of the remaining Jews in Eastern E and Central E were destitute refs who were e or ling to return to coes that became Eastern Bloc, or coes they felt had betrayed them to the Nazis.\n\n\nFile:Destroyed Warsaw, capital of Poland, Jan 1945.jpg|thumb|200px|D World War II Planned destrn of Warsaw.\nThe Nazis intended to destroy the Polish people completely. In 1941, the Nazi leadership decided that Poland was to be f cleared of ethnic Poles within 10 to 20 years and settled by German colonists.<ref name="Volk">Volker R. Berghahn "Germans and Poles 1871\u20131945" in "Germany and Eastern E: Cal Identities and Cal Differences", Rodopi 1999 From the beginning of the occon, Germanys policy was to pl and exploit Polish territory, tg it into a giant concentration camp for Poles who were to be event exterminated as "Untermenschen".<ref name="Volk"/> The policy of pl and exploitation inflicted material losses to Polish ind, agrice, infrastre and cal landmarks, with the cost of the destrn by Germans alone estimated at approximately \u20ac525 billion or $640 billion.<ref>http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,1324630,00.html Poles Vote to Seek War Reparations, Dee Welle, 11 September 2004 The remaining ind was largely destroyed or transported to R by Soviet occon forces following the war.\n\nThe official Polish government report of war losses prepared in 1947 reported 6,028,000 war victims out of a popon of 27,007,000 ethnic Poles and Jews alone. For political reasons the report excl the losses to the Soviet Union and the losses among Polish citizens of Ukrainians and Belars origin.\n\nPolands eastern border was significantly moved westwards to the C Line. The resg territorial loss of 188,000&nbsp;km\xb2 (formerly popd by 5.3 million ethnic Poles) was to be compensated by the addition of 111,000&nbsp;km\xb2 of former German territory east of the Oder\u2013Neisse line (formerly popd by 11.4 million ethnic Germans<ref>http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.cgi?path=260621074909720 The Expn of Germans from Poland, Revisited, H-Net Review). Kidnapping of Polish children by Germany also took place, in which children who were believed to hold German blood were taken away; 20,000\u2013200,000<ref>A. Dirk Moses, Genocide and Settler Society: Frontier Violence and Stolen Indigenous Children in Alian History, https://books.google.com/books?id=5zHAGNPTkqIC&pg=PA260&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children&ei=t24wR9WvDYPU7QLL5OjsCQ&sig=mBzLuS86EO-HWkxMzZA4oERSW5U Google Print, p.260 Polish children were taken away from their parents. Out of the abd only 10\u201315% ret home.<ref>Tadeusz Piotrowski, Polands Holocaust: Ethnic Strife, Collaboration with Occg Forces and Genocide in the Second Rep, 1918\u20131947, https://books.google.com/books?id=A4FlatJCro4C&pg=PA22&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children%22&ei=WIcwR4bxIoia7AKX1KHXCQ&sig=sWXkGcyu7JESf94H4kGH1KzW03k Google Print, p.22 Polish elites were decimated and over half of the Polish intelligentsia were med. Some professions lost 20\u201350% of their members, for example 58% of Polish lawyers, 38% of medical doctors and 28% of rsity workers were exterminated by the Nazis. The Polish capital Warsaw was razed by German forces and most of its old and newly acq cities lay in r (e.g. Wroc\u0142aw) or lost to the Soviet Union (e.g. Lviv|Lw\xf3w). In addition Poland became a Soviet satellite state, remaining  a Soviet-controlled comm government  1989. Rn troops did not withdraw from Poland  1993.\n\n\n*Expn of Poles by Germany\n*Generalplan Ost\n*German AB-Aktion in Poland\n*Holocaust in Poland\n*Operation Tannenberg\n*Chronicles of Terror\n\n\n\nAs a conseq of the war and especially Soviet occon, Central Ean coes found themselves  the "Soviet sphere of infl" (as agreed  at the Yalta Conference).  Immediately following the war, Soviet style totalitarianism  were established in all of these coes and any forms of liberal democracy that existed before the war were erased.  For the coes of Central E installation of Stalinism meant the decline of their economies and more significantly, a loss of national sovereignty and e global identity  the collapse of the Warsaw Pact in 1989 (see also "the Velvet Revol").\n\n\nMore than 26 million Soviet citizens had been killed as a result of the Operation Barbarossa, incl Eastern Front (World War II) who died in list of battles against Hitlers armies or died in POW camps. Millions of civilians also died from starvation, exposure, atrocities, and List of massacres#1939 to 1945 - World War II, and a huge area of the Soviet Union from the ss of Moscow and the Volga River to the western border had been destroyed, depopd, and red to r. The mass death and destrn there badly damaged the Soviet economy, society, and national psyche.  The death toll incl c.a. 1.5 million Soviet Jews killed by the German invaders.<ref>Zvi Gitelman, http://hgs.oxfordjos.org/cgi/content/abstract/5/1/23 History, Memory and Politics: The Holocaust in the Soviet Union The mass destrn and mass m was one of the reasons why the Soviet Union installed satellite states in Central E; as the government hoped to use the coes as a b zone against any new invasions from the West. This helped break down the wartime alliance between the Soviet Union and the Western Allies, setting the stage for the Cold War, which lasted  1989, two years before the dissol of the Soviet Union in 1991. Soviet ce in the 1950s was defined by res of the Great Patriotic War.\n\nClose to 60% of the Ean war dead were from the Soviet Union. Rn historian Vadim Erlikman has detailed Soviet losses totaling 26.5 million war related deaths. Military losses of 10.6 million include 7.6 million killed or missing in action and 2.6 million POW dead, plus 400,000 paramilitary and Soviet Soviet partisans losses. Civilian deaths totaled 15.9 million which incl 1.5 million from military actions. 7.1 million victims of Nazi genocide and reprisals; 1.8 million deported to Germany for forced labor; and 5.5 million famine and disease deaths. Additional famine deaths which totaled 1 million d 1946\u201347 are not incl here. These losses are for the entire territory of the USSR incl territories annexed in 1939\u201340.<ref>http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3955/is_n4_v46/ai_15654726 Soviet deaths in the Great Patriotic War: a note \u2013 World War II\n\nTo the north, the Germans reached Leningrad (Saint Petersburg) in A 1941. The city was snded on 8 September, beginning Siege of Leningrad d which about 1.2 million citizens perished.\n\nOf the 5.7 million Soviet prisoners of war capt by the Germans, more than 3.5 million had died while in German captivity by the end of the war. On 11 Febr 1945, at the concl of the Yalta Conference, the United States and United Kingdom signed a Repatriation Agreement with the USSR.<ref>The United States and Forced Repatriation of Soviet Citizens, 1944\u201347 by Mark Elliott Political Science Qrly, Vol. 88, No. 2 (Jun., 1973), pp. 253\u2013275 The interpretation of this Agreement res in the Operation Keelhaul of all Soviets regardless of their wishes. Millions of Soviet POWs and History of slavery#Modern E transported to Germany are believed to have been treated as traitors, cowards and deserters on their return to the USSR(see Order No. 270) .<ref>http://www.stsg.de/main/zeithain/geschichte/gedenken/index_en.php Remembrance (Zeithain Memorial Grove)  Statistical data from Soviet archives, that became available after Perestroika, attest that the overall increase of the G popon was minimal d 1945\u201346.\n\n\nBelarus lost a qr of its pre-war popon, incl practically all its intellectual elite and 90% of the co\u2019s History of the Jews in Belarus popon. Following bloody encirclement battles, all of the present-day Belarus territory was occ by the Germans by the end of A 1941. The Nazis imposed a br regime, deporting some 380,000 young people for slave labour, and killing hds of thos of other civilians. At least 5,295 Belar settlements were destroyed by the Nazis and some or all their inhabitants killed (out of 9,200 settlements that were b or otherwise destroyed in Belarus d World War II). More than 600 villages like Khatyn were b with their entire popon. More than 209 cities and towns (out of 270 total) were destroyed. Heinrich Himmler had prono a plan according to which 3/4 of Belar popon was designated for "eradication" and 1/4 of racially cleaner popon (blue eyes, light hair) would be allowed to serve Germans as e labour (Ostarbeiter).\n\nSome recent estimates raise the n of Belars who perished in War to "3 million 650 tho people, e the former 2.2 million. That is to say not every fo inhabitant but about 40% of the pre-war Belar popon perished (considering the present-day borders of Belarus)." This compares to 15% of Polands post war borders and 19% of Ukrainian popon in post war border and comparing to 2% of Czechoslovakian popon that perished in post war borders.\n\n\nEstimates on popon losses in Ukraine range from 7 million to 11 million. More than 700 cities and towns and 28,000 villages were destroyed.\n\n\n*Forced settlements in the Soviet Union\n*Generalplan Ost\n*H Plan\n*Occon of Belarus by Nazi Germany\n*Operation Keelhaul\n*World War II cases\n\n\nFile:Serbs expelled from Croatia, July 1941.jpg|thumb|300px|Due to their strong opposition to Nazism, Serbs were considered enemies of Nazi Germany. Alongside Jews, Serbs were killed and expelled in wartime Yavia.\n\nIt is estimated that 1,700,000 people were killed d World War II in Yavia from 1941 to 1945. Very high losses were among Serbs who lived in Bosnia (region) and Croatia, as well as Jewish and Romani people minorities, with losses also high among all other non-collaborationism popons. In the s of 1941, the Serbian ing came at the time of the German invasion of the USSR. The Nazi response was the exec of 100 Serbian civilians for every killed soldier and 50 Serbian civilians for every wo soldier. The Yav Partisans fo both a glla campaign against the Axis powers of World War II occs and a civil war against the Chetniks. The Independent State of Croatia was established as a Nazi p-state, r by the fascist militia known as the Usta\u0161e. D this time the Independent State of Croatia created extermination camps for anti-fascists, comms, Serbs, Ms, Gypsies and Jews, one of the most infamous being the Jasenovac concentration camp. A large n of men, women and children, mostly Serbs, were med in these camps. In 1945, the Federal Peoples Rep of Yavia was created as a totalitarian one party state.\n\n\n\nBritish Empire and France were on the side of the victors, but they were exha and bankr by the war, and Britain never recovered its status as a sower. With Germany and Japan in r as well, the world was left with two dominant powers, the United States and the Soviet Union. Economic and political reality in Western E would soon force the dismantling of the Ean colonialism, especially in Africa and Asia.\n\nOne of the most important political conseqs of the Nazi experience in Western E was the establishment of new, political alliances which event became the Ean Union and an international military alliance of Ean coes known as North Atlantic Treaty Organization to cobalance the Soviets Warsaw Pact and  comm rule in Eastern E ended in the late 1980s.\n\nThe Comms emerged from the war sharing the vast prestige of the victorious Soviet armed forces, and for a while it looked as though they might take power in France, Italy and Greece. The West qy acted to prevent this from happening, hence the Cold War.\n\n\n\nIn Greece the Axis Occon of Greece (April 1941 \u2013 October 1944) destroyed the economy through war reparations, pling of the cos reso and hyper-inflation. In addition, the Germans left most of the cos infrastre in r as they withdrew in 1944. As a result of an Allied blockade and German indifference to local needs, the first winter of the occon was marked by widespread famine in the main  centres, with as many as 300,000 civilians dead from starvation. Although these levels of starvation were not repeated in the following years, malnoment was common throt the occon. In addition, thos more were exec by German forces as reprisals for partisan activities. As part of the Holocaust, Greeces Jewish comm was almost wiped out, especially the large Sephardi comm of Thessaloniki, which had earned the city the sobriquet "Mother of Israel" and had first settled there in the early 16th century at the invitation of the then-r Ottoman Empire. In total, at least 81% (ca. 60,000) of Greeces total pre-war Jewish popon perished.\n\nThe bitterest and longest-lasting legacy of the German occon was the social val it wro. The old political elites were sidelined, and the Greek Resistance against the Axis bro to the fore the leftist National Liberation Front (Greece) (EAM), arg the cos first true mass-movement, where the Comms played a central role. In an effort to oppose its growing infl, the Germans encod the pre-war conservative establishment to confront it, and allowed the creation of Sec Battalions. As elsewhere in Eastern E, in the last year of the occon, conditions in Greece often approximated a civil war between EAM and everyone else. The rift would become permanent in December 1944, when EAM and the British-backed government clashed in Athens, and again in a f fledged Greek Civil War|civil war from 1946\u20131949.\n\n\nMore than 7 million Germans, incl almost 2 million civilians, died d World War II (see World War II cases). After the end of the war in E additional cases were inc d the Allied occon and also d the popon expns that followed.\n\nAfter the war, the German people were often viewed with contempt because they were blamed by other Eans for Nazi crimes. Germans visiting abroad, particy in the 1950s and 1960s, attracted ins from locals, and from foreigners who may have lost their families or friends in the atrocities. Today in E and worldwide (particy in coes that fo against the Axis), Germans may be scorned by elderly people who were alive to experience the atrocities committed by Nazi Germans d World War II. This res in a feeling of controversy for many Germans, ca nus discns and rows among scholars and politicians in Post-War West Germany (for example, the "Historikerstreit" historians arg in the 1980s) and after German recation. Here, the discn was mainly about the role that the ed Germany should play in the world and in E. Bernard Schlinks novel The Reader concerns how post-war Germans dealt with the issue.\n\nFollowing World War II, the Allies embarked on a program of denazification, but as the Cold War intensified these efforts were cled in the west.\n\nGermany itself and the German economy were devastated, with great parts of most major cities destroyed by the bombings of the Allied forces, sovereignty taken away by the Allies of World War II and the territory filled with millions of refs from the former eastern provinces which the Allies had decided were to be annexed by the Soviet Union and Poland, moving the eastern German border westwards to the Oder-Neisse line and effectively red Germany in size by ro 25% (see also Potsdam Conference). The remaining parts of Germany were divided among the Allies and occ by British (the north-west), French (the south-west), American (the south) and Soviet Union (the east) troops.\n\nFile:Deland Besatzonen - 1945 1946.svg|thumb|200px\nThe expns of Germans from the lost areas in the east (see also Former eastern territories of Germany), the Snland, and elsewhere in eastern E went on for several years. The n of Expn of Germans after World War II totaled ro 15,000,000. Estimates of n of deaths in connection with expn of Germans after WWII range from  500,000  to 3 million.\n\nAfter a short time the Allies Cold War (Comm versus Capitalism), and thus both sides established their own spheres of infl, creating a previo non-existent division in Germany between East and West (although the division largely followed the borders of states which had existed in Germany before Otto von Bismarcks cation less than 100 years before).\n\nA constit for East Germany was drafted on 30 May 1949. Wilhelm Pieck, a leader of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED) party (which was created by a forced merger of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD) and Comm Party of Germany (KPD) in the Soviet sector), was elected first President of the German Democratic Rep.\n\nWest Germany, (officially: Federal Rep of Germany, FRG \u2013 this is still the official name of the ed Germany today) received (de facto) semi-sovereignty in 1949, as well as a constit, called the Grsetz (Basic Law). The doc was not called a Constit officially, as at this point, it was still hoped that the two German states would be red in the near f.\n\nThe first free elections in West Germany were held in 1949, which were won by the Christian Democratic Party of Germany (Christian Democratic Union (Germany)) (conservatives) by a slight margin. Konrad Adenauer, a member of the CDU, was the first Bkanzler (Chancellor) of West Germany.\n\nBoth German states introd, in 1948, their own money, colloqy called West-Mark and Ost-Mark (Western Mark (money) and Eastern Mark).\n\nForeign troops still remain in Germany today, for example Ramstein Air Base, but the majority of troops left following the end of the Cold War (By 1994 for Soviet troops, mandated  the terms of the Treaty on the Final Settlement With Respect to Germany and in the mid-1990s for Western forces). The George W. Bush administration in the United States in 2004 stated intentions to withdraw most of the remaining American troops out of Germany in the coming years. D the years 1950\u20132000 more than 10,000,000 U.S. military personnel were stationed in Germany.<ref>Tim Kane, PhD., http://www.heritage.org/Research/NationalSec/cda04-11.cfm Global U.S. Troop Deployment, 1950\u20132003, Heritage Foion 27 October 2004\n\nThe West German economy was by the mid 1950s reb thanks to the abandonment in mid-1947 of some of the last vestiges of the Morgenthau Plan and to fewer war reparations imposed on West Germany (see also Wirtschaftsw). After lobbying by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Generals L D. Clay and George Marshall, the Tr administration realized that economic recovery in E could not go forward without the reconstrn of the German indal base on which it previo had been dependent.<ref name="jennings">http://www..org/pubs/peaceworks/pwks49.pdf Ray Salvatore Jennings "The Road Ahead: Lessons in Nation Bng from Japan, Germany, and Afghanistan for Postwar Iraq  May 2003,  Peaceworks No. 49  pg.15\nIn July 1947, President Harry S. Tr rescinded on "national sec gro"<ref name="jennings"/> the pve JCS 1067, which had directed the U.S. forces of occon in Germany to "take no steps looking toward the economic rehabilitation of Germany." It was replaced by JCS 1779, which instead stressed that "an orderly, prosperous E req the economic contribs of a stable and prode Germany."<ref>http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,887417,00.html Pas de Pagaille! Time Magazine 28 July 1947.\n\nThe dismantling of factories in the western zones, for fr transport to the Soviet Union as reparations, was in time halted as frictions grew between East and West. Limits were placed on permitted levels of German prodn in order to prevent resce of German militarism, part of which incl severely restricting German steel prodn and affected the rest of the German economy very negatively (see "The indal plans for Germany"). Dismantling of factories by France and Great Britain as reparations and for the pe of lowering German war and economic potential  the  "level of ind plans" took place (halted in 1951), but to nowhere near the scale of the dismantling and transport to the Soviet Union of factories in the eastern zone of occon. The Eastern Block did not accept the Marshall Plan, denog it as American economic imperialism, and thus it (East Germany incl) recovered much more slowly than their Western coparts. German political and economic control of its main remaining centers of ind was red, the Ruhr area was  international control. The Ruhr Agreement was imposed on the Germans as a condition for permitting them to establish the Federal Rep of Germany.<ref>Amos Yoder, "The Ruhr Aity and the German Problem", The Review of Politics, Vol. 17, No. 3 (Jul., 1955), pp. 345\u2013358 (see also the International Aity for the Ruhr (IAR)). In the end, the beginning of the Cold War led to increased German control of the area, although permanently limited by the pooling of German coal and steel into a mational comm in 1951 (see Ean Coal and Steel Comm). The neighboring Saar (protectorate), containing much of Germanys remaining coal deposits, handed over by the U. S. to French economic administration as a protectorate in 1947 and did not politically return to Germany  Jan 1957, with economic reintegration occg a few years later. (see also the Monnet Plan). Upper Silesia, Germanys second largest center of mining and ind, had been handed over to Poland at the Potsdam Conference, and its popon expelled.\n\nThe Allies confiscated intellectual property of great value, all German patents, both in Germany and abroad, and  them to strengthen their own indal competitiveness by licensing them to Allied companies.<ref>C. Lester Walker http://www.scientistsandfriends.com/files/secrets.doc "Secrets By The Thos", Harpers Magazine. October 1946  Beginning immediately after the German sder and contin for the next two years the U.S. pd a vigorous program to harvest all technological and scientific know-how as well as all patents in Germany. John Gimbel comes to the concl, in his book "Science Technology and Reparations: Exploitation and Pl in Postwar Germany", that the "intellectual reparations" taken by the U.S. and the UK amo to close to $10 1000000000 (n).<ref>The $10 billion compares to the total Marshall plan expenditure (1948\u20131952) of $13 billion, of which Germany received $1.4 billion (partly as loans). D the more than two years that this policy was in place, no indal research in Germany could take place, as any res would have been atically available to overseas competitors who were encod by the occon aities to access all records and facilities. Meanwhile, thos of the best German researchers were being put to work in the Soviet Union and in the U.S. (see also Operation Paperclip)\n\nFor several years following the sder German nional levels were very low, resg in very high mortality rates. Throt all of 1945 the U.S. forces of occon ens that no international aid reached ethnic Germans.<ref name="wiggers">Steven Bela Vardy and T. Hunt Tooley, eds. Ethnic Cleansing in Twentieth-Century E ISBN 0-88033-995-0. stion by Richard Dominic Wiggers, "The United States and the Ref to Feed German Civilians after World War II"  It was directed that all relief went to non-German displaced persons, liberated Allied POWs, and concentration camp inmates.<ref name="wiggers"/> D 1945 it was estimated that the average German civilian in the US and UK occon zones received 1200 calories a day.<ref name="wiggers"/> Meanwhile, non-German displaced persons were receiving 2300 calories through emergency food imports and Red Cross help.<ref name="wiggers"/> In early October 1945 the UK government privately acknowledged in a cabinet meeting that German civilian adult death rates had risen to 4 times the pre-war levels and death rates amongst the German children had risen by 10 times the pre-war levels.<ref name="wiggers"/> The German Red Cross was dissolved, and the International Red Cross and the few other allowed international relief agencies were kept from helping Germans through strict controls on ses and travel.<ref name="wiggers"/> The few agencies permitted to help Germans, such as the indigenous Caritasverband, were not allowed to use imported ses. When the Holy See attempted to transmit food ses from Chile to German infants the US State Department forbade it.<ref name="wiggers"/> The German food sitn reached its worst d the very cold winter of 1946\u20131947 when German calorie intake ranged from 1,000\u20131,500 calories per day, a sitn made worse by severe lack of fuel for heating.<ref name="wiggers"/> Meanwhile, the Allies were well fed, average adult calorie intake was; U.S. 3200\u20133300; UK 2900; U.S. Army 4000.<ref name="wiggers"/> German infant mortality rate was twice that of other nations in Western E  the close of 1948.<ref name="wiggers"/>\n\nAs agreed by the Allies at the Yalta conference Germans were  as forced labor as part of the reparations to be extracted to the coes r by Nazi aggression. By 1947 it is estimated that 4,000,000 Germans (both civilians and POWs) were being  as forced labor by the U.S., France, the UK and the Soviet Union. German prisoners were for example forced to clear minefields in France and the low coes. By December 1945 it was estimated by French aities that 2,000 German prisoners were being killed or maimed each month in accidents.<ref>S. P. MacKenzie  "The Treatment of Prisoners of War in World War II" The Jo of Modern History, Vol. 66, No. 3. (Sep., 1994), pp. 487\u2013520. In Norway the last available cas record, from 29 A 1945, shows that by that time a total of 275 German soldiers died while clearing mines, while 392 had been maimed.<ref>Jonas Tjersland, http://www.vg.no/pub/vgart.hbs?artid=166207 Tyske soldater brukt som mineryddere, Verdens Gang, 8 April 2006 Death rates for the German civilians doing forced labor in the Soviet Union ranged between 19% and 39%, depending on category. (see also Forced labor of Germans in the Soviet Union).\n\nNorman Naimark writes in "The Rns in Germany: A History of the Soviet Zone of Occon, 1945\u20131949." that although the exact n of women and girls who were raped by members of the Red Army in the months preceding and years following the capiton will never be known, their ns are likely in the hds of thos, q possibly as high as the 2,000,000 victims estimate made by Barbara Johr, in "Befreier und Befreite". Many of these victims were raped repeatedly. Naimark states that not only had each victim to carry the trauma with her for the rest of her days, it inflicted a massive collective trauma on the East German nation (the German Democratic Rep). Naimark concl "The social psychology of women and men in the soviet zone of occon was marked by the crime of rape from the first days of occon, through the fog of the GDR in the fall of 1949,  - one could argue - the present."<ref>Norman M. Naimark. The Rns in Germany: A History of the Soviet Zone of Occon, 1945\u20131949. Harvard University Press, 1995. ISBN 0-674-78405-7 pp. 132,133\n\nThe post-war hostility shown to the German people is exemplified in the fate of the War children, sired by German soldiers with women from the local popon in nations such as Norway where the children and their mothers after the war had to endure many years of abuse. In the case of Denmark the hostility felt towards all things German also showed itself in the treatment of German ref d the years 1945 to 1949. D 1945 alone 7000 German children  the age of 5 died as a result of being denied sient food and denied medical attention by Danish doctors who were afraid that rendering aid to the children of the former enemy would be seen as an riotic act. Many children died of easily treatable ailments. As a conseq "more German ref died in Danish camps, "than Danes did d the entire war.""<ref>http://www.cphpost.dk/get/87301.html Children were starved in war aftermath, Copenhagen Post, 15 April 2005<ref>Manfred Ertel, http://www.spiegel.de/international/0,1518,355772,00.html Denmarks Myths Shattered: A Legacy of Dead German Children, Der Spiegel, 16 May 2005<ref>Andrew Osborn, http://observer.gan.co.uk/international/story/0,6903,891930,00.html  Docary forces Danes to confront past, The Observer, 9 Febr 2003<ref>http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,1564,1545676,00.html Danish Study Says German Children Ab, Dee Welle, 10 April 2005\n\nD the Cold War, it was difficult for West Germans to visit East German relatives and friends and impossible vice versa. For East Germans, especially after the bng of the Berlin Wall on 13 A 1961 and  Hy opened up its border to the West in the late 1980s, thus allowing hds of thos of vacationing East Germans to flee into Western E, it was only possible to get to West Germany by illegally fleeing across Inner German border.\n\n44 years after the end of World War II, the Berlin Wall fell on 9 November 1989. The East and West parts of Germany were red on 3 October 1990.\n\nEconomic and social divisions between East and West Germany continue to play a major role in politics and society in Germany at present. It is likely the contrast between the generally well-off and economically diverse West and the weaker, heavy-ind reliant East will continue at least into the foreseeable f.\n\n\n* Berlin Wall\n* Cold War\n* German recation\n* Germany\n** East Germany\n** West Germany\n* History of Germany since 1945\n* Marshall Plan\n* Ostpolitik\n\n\n\nThe war led to the discrediting and dissol of the League of Nations and led to the fog of the United Nations on 24 October 1945. Like its predecessor, the UN was established to help prevent other world wars and contain or stop smaller conflicts. The principles enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations are a testament to the worlds attit at the fall of the Third Reich.\n\n\nFile:Nerg Trials reto.jpg|thumb|right|Nerg Trials. Defendants in the dock. The main target of the prosec was Hermann G\xf6ring (at the left edge on the  first row of benches), considered to be the most important sing official in the Nazi Germany after Hitlers death.\nThe effect the Nazis had on present-day international law should not be estimated. The Convention on the Prevention and Pment of the Crime of Genocide, a series of laws that made genocide a crime, was approved in December 1948, three years after the Nazi defeat. That same month, the Universal Declaration of H Rights also became a part of international law. The Nerg trials, followed by other Nazi war crimes trials, also created an tten rule stating that government officials who "follow orders" from leaders in committing crimes against hty cannot use such a motive to excuse their crimes. It also had an effect through the Fo Geneva Convention (Art 33) in making collective pments a war crime.\n\n\n\nAfter the world viewed the Nazi death camps, many Western peoples began to odly oppose ideas of racial sority. Liberal anti-racism became a staple of many Western governments. Whereas racism is  still present, openly racist pations were looked down . The move towards tolerance of different ces in Western societies has continued to the present day. Since the collapse of Nazi Germany, Western popons have been wary of racial political parties and have actively discod white people ethnocentrism, fearing the return of a catastrophe similar to the p carried out by Nazis in Germany. On the other hand, it can be argued that the conception of malism as one of the pillars of contemporary Western society has gained importance because of the same reaction. The actions of the Nazis ca an increase in Anti-German sentiment.\n\n\n\n\nGerman military doctrine  the Nazi regime, characterized (with some controversy) as Blitzkrieg, called for air strikes that softened an intended victim for attack by motorized, mechanized, and airborne forces on the schwerp (focal point), followed by encirclement by motorized forces, and exploitation of the gap by conventional infantry forces. Radio commtion allowed for the close coordination necessary for such attacks, and allowed for coordination of the air force. The Nazis as much broke the r of engagement which previo governed nations at war (such violations often deemed after the war as crimes against peace) as they innovated techniques of war. Axis reverses beginning with Allied routs of overextended German forces in Second Battle of El Alamein and Battle of Stalingrad res from British and Soviet forces adopting Nazi field strategies, and as the United States became a participant in the war it adopted much the same techniques of aerial attack  Nazi Germany, if with greater force than the Lffe could ever inflict.\n\nAs Nazi Germany faced severe defeat after the Battle of K and especially the D-Day it introd cross-English Channel use of the V-1 flying bomb and V-2 rocket, although too late and too ineffectively to turn the war to its advantage. The German military machine was developing jet aircraft as fighters and bombers and long-range missiles, but far too late (they were only in the design and test stages) to change the oe of the war.  The victorious Allies would incorporate the early innovations of jet technology and long-distance rocket-based missiles into their armed forces, but only after the end of World War II after getting them beyond the developmental stages of design and testing.\n\n\n*Steven Bela Vardy and T. Hunt Tooley, eds. Ethnic Cleansing in Twentieth-Century E ISBN 0-88033-995-0. stion by Richard Dominic Wiggers, The United States and the Ref to Feed German Civilians after World War Row(id=372416, title=u'Bakkah', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\nFile:1937mecca-makkah.jpg|thumb|The Kabba in Mecca.\nBakkah () is an ancient name for Mecca, the most holy city of Islam.<ref name=Kipferp342> Most people believe they are synonyms, but to M scholars there is a distinction: Bakkah refers to the Kaaba and the sacred site immediately snding it, while Mecca is the name of the city in which they are both located.<ref name=Leamanp337>\n\nAccording to Lisan Al Arab of Ibn Manzor, the site of Kaaba and its sndings was named Bakkah due to crowding and congestion of people in the area. The Arabic verb bakka (\u0628\u0643\u064e\u0651), with do "k", means to crowd like in a bazaar. This is not to be conf with another ated Arabic verb baka (\u0628\u064e\u0643\u064e\u0649)(single k) which is the past participle of yabki (\u064a\u064e\u0628\u0652\u0643\u0650\u064a), to cry.\n\nBakkah is mentioned in sura 3 (Al-i-Imran), ayah 96 of the Quran,Translation: " Verily the first House set apart  mankind was that at Bakka, blest, and a gce  the worlds.".<ref> \u0627\u0644\u0642\u0631\u0622\u0646 \u0627\u0644\u0643\u0631\u064a\u0645|website=tanzil.net|access-date=2016-07-18\n\n      \nBakkah (also transliterated Baca, Baka, Bakke, Bakah, Bakka, Lebanon, Becca, Bekka, etc.) is the ancient name for the site of Mecca.<ref name=Kipferp342/><ref name=Glassep302/><ref name=Phippsp85><ref name=Hrgerp174> An Arabic lang word, its etymology, like that of Mecca, is obscure.<ref name=Versteeghp513>\n \nOne meaning ascribed to it is "narrow", seen as descriptive of the area in which the valley of the holy places and the city of Mecca are located, pressed in  as they are by mons.<ref name=Glassep302> Widely believed to be a synonym for Mecca, it is said to be more specifically the early name for the valley located therein, while M scholars generally use it to refer to the sacred area of the city that immediately snds and incl the Kaaba.<ref name=Leamanp337/><ref name=Petersonp22><ref name=Map753>\n\nThe form Bakkah is  for the name Mecca in the Q in 3:96, while the form Mecca is  in 48:24.<ref name=Versteeghp513/><ref name=Hittip6> In Old South Arabian, the lang in use in the son portion of the Arabian Peninsula at the time of Mad, the b and m were interchangeable.<ref name=Hittip6/> The Qc passage  the form Bakkah says: "The first sanct appointed for mankind was that at Bakkah, a blessed place, a gce for the peoples."<ref name=Glassep302/><ref name="q96">:  Other references to Mecca in the Q (6:92, 42:5) call it Umm al-Qura, meaning "mother of all settlements".<ref name=Hittip6/>\n\nIn Islamic tradition, Bakkah is where Hagar and Ishmael (Ishmael in Islam|Ism\u0101\u012bl) settled after being taken by Abraham (Abraham in Islam|Ibr\u0101h\u012bm) to the wilderness, a story parallel to the Bibles Book of Genesis (21:14-21)(but see below for the biblical geography).<ref name=Phippsp85/> Genesis tells of how after Hagar and Ishmael ran out of water to drink.<ref name=Phippsp85/> In Arab tradition, Hagar runs back and forth between two elevated points seven times to search for help before sitting down in despair, at which point the angel speaks as recorded in Genesis 21:17-19:  Here, the tradition holds that a spring g forth from the spot where Hagar had laid Ishmael, and this spring came to be known as the Well of Zamzam.<ref name=Phippsp85/><ref name=Petersonp22/> When Ms on hajj run between the hills of Safa and Marwah seven times, it is to commemorate Hagars search for help and the resg revelation of the well of Zamzam.<ref name=Petersonp22/>\n\nIn addition to the Islamic tradition that Hagar and Ishmael settled in Bakkah, the Q relates that Abraham came to Mecca to help his son Ishmael b the Kaaba adjacent to the well of Zamzam.<ref name=Phippsp85/><ref name=Petersonp22/> However, in the Bible and ancient Jewish, Christian, and pre-Islamic tradition, Abraham is never mentioned as traveling far south into Arabia (Mekka is about 1400 kilometers south of Hebron, where Abraham is said to be b). Ishmael is mentioned in the Bible as living relatively near to Hebron since he is mentioned in Genesis at Abrahams fl. \n\nIbn Ishaq, the 8th-century Arab M historian, relates that d the renovation of Kaaba taken by the Qh tribe before Islam, found an inscription in one of the corners of the foion of the bng that mentions Bakkah. Composed in Syriac lang, it was incomprehensible to the Qh  a Jew translated it for them as follows: "I am Allah, the Lord of Bakka. I created it on the day I created heaven and earth and formed the sun and the moon, and I snded it with seven pious angels. It will stand while its two mons stand, a blessing to its people with milk and water."<ref name=Petersp47>\n\nThe name Bakkah is woven into the kiswa, the cloth covering the Kaaba that is replaced each year before the Hajj.<ref name=Forlongp536>\n\n\n\nA different Valley of Baca ("Valley of the Baka tree", see below) is mentioned in the Book of Psalms Chapter 84, in the following passage:  \n\nThe context of Psalm 84 refers to a pilgrimage route for Jews going up to the temple of Yhwh in Jerm. No responsible commentator on the Psalms has sted any place in the son half of the Arabian peninsula, 1400-1500 kilometers away. The original Hebrew lang phrase for the Valley of Baca is emeq ha-Baka \u05e2\u05de\u05e7 \u05d4\u05d1\u05db\u05d0.<ref name=Fokkelmanp235><ref name=Bp186> A literal translation of the Hebrew name is "valley of the Baka (tree)," (note the use of the word "the"), although the ancient Greek translation ass a similar-sog word \u05d1\u05db\u05d4 "crying" and translated \u1f10\u03bd \u03c4\u1fc7 \u03ba\u03bf\u03b9\u03bb\u03ac\u03b4\u03b9 \u03c4\u03bf\u1fe6 \u03ba\u03bb\u03b1\u03c5\u03b8\u03bc\u1ff6\u03bd\u03bf\u03c2 "valley of mog". The same Hebrew word \u05d1\u05db\u05d0 is associated with a famous battle in 2 Samuel 5:23-24 in the Valley of Rephaim,<ref>See, for example, Amos Hakham, Book of Psalms Heb, vol. 2: 73-150, Jerm: Mossad Rav Kook, 1990, p. 104: "There are commentators who explain that `emeq ha-baka \u05d1\u05db\u05d0 is a valley where certain trees grow that are called \u05d1\u05db\u05d0\u05d9\u05dd "baka-trees," this valley is emeq refaim \u05e2\u05de\u05e7 \u05e8\u05e4\u05d0\u05d9\u05dd "Valley of Ghosts" 2 Sam 5:22-24, and it is where pilgrims would ascend on their way to the temple area in Jerm" translated from Hebrew." about 4-7 kilometers sost of the present day Old City of Jerm. David is advised to engage the Philistines in battle when he hears the sound of marching in the Baka trees (translated "mry trees" in the King James Version, although the specific tree to which \u05d1\u05db\u05d0 refers is not known--many modern translations st "balsam tree").\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.islamic-awareness.org/History/kaaba.html Mecca & Baca Islamic site Row(id=381093, title=u'National Day of Mourning (United States protest)', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nThe National Day of Mog  an annual protest organized since 1970 by Native Americans in the United States of New England on the fo Thy of November, the same day as Thanksgiving (United States) in the United States. It coincides with an ated but similar protest, Unthanksgiving Day, held on the West Coast (United States).\n\nThe organizers consider the national holiday of Thanksgiving Day as a reminder of the democide and continued sing of the Native American peoples. Participants in the National Day of Mog honor Native ancestors and the strs of Native peoples to se today. They want to ed Americans about history. The event was organized in a period of Native American activism and general cal protests. The protest is organized by the United American Indians of New England (UAINE). Since it was first organized, social changes have res in major revisions to the portrayal of United States history, the governments and settlers relations with Native American peoples, and renewed appreciation for Native American ce.\n\n\nThe United American Indians of New England (UAINE) organized their protest to bring pity to the continued misrepresentation of Native American and colonial experience. They believed that people needed to be edd about what happened when the Pilgrims (Plymouth Colony) arrived in North America.\n\nA century ago heavy immigration bro millions of son and eastern Eans to the United States. Edrs and civic groups tho it necessary to cal assimilation the new citizens. The new arrivals were ta to view the Pilgrims as models for their own families. The tale of the "First Thanksgiving" was an essential element of this c. The story of the Native Americans and Pilgrims sharing a meal of t became part of United States tradition. The story tells of the mly beneficial relationship between these groups.\n\nUAINE, by contrast, says that the Pilgrims did not find a new and empty land. Every inch of land they claimed was Indian land. They also say that the Pilgrims immigrated as part of a commercial venture and that they introd sexism, racism, anti-homosexual bigotry, jails, and the Social class system.\n\nGovernor John Winthrop proclaimed an official "Day of Thanksgiving" in 1637 to celebrate the return of men from the Pequot War in Mystic, Connecticut, in which colonists allied with Mohegan and Narragansett tribes to defeat the Pequot. More than 700 Pequot women, children, and men died in the war, which their descendants call a massacre. In 1863, d the American Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln aized that the fo Thy of November be set aside to give thanks and praise for the nations blessings. Thanksgiving became part of American ce.\n\nUAINE believes that the Native American and colonial experience continue to be misrepresented. It asks why the "First Thanksgiving" was not celebrated or related back to the first colony at Jamestown. According to UAINE, the circnces at Jamestown were too terrible to be  as a national myth. The settlers t to cannibalism to se. The UAINE  the National Day of Mog to ed people about the history of the Wampanoag people. UAINE representatives say the only true element of the Thanksgiving story is that the pilgrims would not have sed their first years in New England without the aid of the Wampanoag or the Wampanoags already existing crops.\n\nNeither UAINE nor the National Day of Mog are sponsored by Wampanoag tribal leadership, although the tribe does not disco members from participating. In his November 2014 message to the tribe, Mashpee Wampanoag Chief Qaqeemasq  wrote, "Historically, Thanksgiving represents our first enco with the eventual erosion of our sovereignty and there is nothing wrong with mog that loss. In fact, as long as we don\u2019t wallow in regret and resentment, it\u2019s healthy to mourn. It is a necessary part of the healing process."\n\n\nSince 1921, the 300th year after the first Thanksgiving, the Commonwealth of Massachs stages an annual reenactment of Thanksgiving. People gather at a ch on the site of the Pilgrims original meeting house, in 17th century costume. After prayers and a sermon, they march to Plymouth Rock. This annual event had become a to attraction.\n\nThe UNAINE organized the first National Day of Mog on the 350th anniversary of the Pilgrims arrival on Wampanoag land. The Commonwealth of Massachs planned to celebrate friendly relations between English ancestors and the Wampanoag. Wampanoag leader Frank James, also known as Wams, was invited to make a speech at the celebration.<ref>http://www.pilgrimhall.org/daymourn.htm Pilgrim Hall M But, when the anniversary planners reviewed his speech\n\nWams based his speech on a Pilgrims account of the first year on Indian land. The book reco the opening of graves, taking the Indians corn and bean ses, and selling Wampanoag as slaves for 220 shillings each. After receiving a revised speech, written by a p relations person, Wams decided he would not attend the celebration. To protest the silencing of the American Indian people, he and his sters went to neighboring Coles Hill, near the statue of Massasoit, the leader of the Wampanoag when the Pilgrims landed. Overlooking the Plymouth Harbour and the Mayflower replica, Wams gave his speech. This was the first National Day of Mog.\n\n\nToday, the UNAINE continues leading the National Day of Mog protest in Plymouth. The son of the fo, James, participates as well. The more recent protests have been held on Coles Hill and a location overlooking Plymouth Rock. The organizers have been joined by other minority activists in protest as well. Typically several hd protesters appear. The protest generally begins at 12:00 noon on Thanksgiving Day with a march through the historic district of Plymouth. All are welcome, but the UNAINE remind participants that this is a day when the Native people speak about their history and strs, incl contemporary ones. Speakers are by invitation only. Following the march and the speeches, they have a social time. G are asked to bring non-alcoholic beverages, desserts, fresh fr and vegetables, or pre-cooked items.\n\nIn 1996 the Latinos for Social Change marched to the Plymouth Commons at the same time the Mayflower Society had their Pilgrim Progress parade, to show st of UAINE. The police rero the Pilgrim parade to avoid conflict. In 1997 the Pilgrim Progress parade was held earlier and went t.\n\nIn 1997 those who gathered to commemorate the 28th National Day of Mog had a more difficult time. State troopers and police met the protesters. Some acco state that pepper spray was  on children and the elderly. Twenty-five people were arrested on charges ranging from battery on an officer to assembling without a permit. In an effort to avoid another conflict, the state reached a settlement with UNAINE in October 1998. It stated the UNAINE were allowed to march without a permit, as long as they gave the town advanced notice.\n\nThe 35th National Day of Mog was held on Thy, November 25, 2004, and was dedicated to Leonard Peltier, a Native American activist convicted and sentenced to two consec terms of life imprisonment for first degree m in the shooting of two FBI agents. Many American Indians and sters gathered again at the top of Coles Hill, overlooking Plymouth Rock. They honored their Native ancestors and the strs of Native peoples to se today.\n\n\nAccording to a speech by Moonanum James, Co-Leader of UNAINE, at the 29th National Day of Mog, November 26, 1998:<ref>http://www..org/Mnan.htm Speech by Moonanum James, Co-Leader of United American Indians of New England at the 29th National Day of Mog, November 26, 1998\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of H Societies by Jared Diamond (1997).\n* "Death by Disease" by Ann F. Ramenofsky in "Archaeology" (March/April 1992).\n* Mayflower: A Story of Co, Comm, and War by Nathaniel Philbrick (2006).\n\n\n* http://www..org/ United American Indians of New England\n*
