Row(id=402082, title=u'Dakhla, Western Sahara', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n<br/><br/><br/>Ed-Dakhla\n|native_name =\n|image_seal =\n|image_map =\n|pn_map = Western Sahara\n|pn_label_position =bottom\n|pn_map_caption =Location in Western Sahara\n|sision_type = Territory (sision)\n|sision_type1 = Controlled by\n|sision_name = Western Sahara\n|sision_name1 = Kingdom of Morocco\n|sision_type2 = Claimed by\n|sision_name2 =  Kingdom of Morocco,<br /> Sahrawi Arab Democratic Rep\n|established_title =\n|established_date =\n|government_type =\n|leader_title =\n|leader_name =\n|area_magnitude =\n|area_total_sq_mi =\n|area_total_km2 =\n|area_land_sq_mi =\n|area_land_km2 =\n|area__sq_mi =\n|area__km2 =\n|area_metro_km2 =\n|area_metro_sq_mi =\n|popon_as_of=2014\n|popon_footnotes =<ref name="popon2014"/> \n|popon_total =70,482\n|popon_ =\n|popon_metro =\n|popon_density_sq_mi =\n|popon_density_km2 =\n|timezone =GMT+0\n|utc_offset =\n|timezone_DST = GMT+0\n|utc_offset_DST =\n|coordinates = \n|elevation_footnotes=\n|elevation_m =\n|elevation_ft =\n|postal_code_type =\n|postal_code = 73000\n|area_code =\n|website =http://www.dakhla.net/\n|footnotes =\n\nDakhla (; , Ed-Da\u1e35la; , Dajla, Ed-Dakhla) is a city in Western Sahara, a Territorial dispute ctly administered by Morocco. It is the capital of the Regions of Morocco Dakhla-Oued Ed-Dahab. It has a popon of 106,277<ref name="popon2014"> and is b on a narrow peninsula of the Atlantic Ocean (:es:Pen\xednsula de R\xedo de Oro) about 550&nbsp;km south of Laayoune.\n\n\nFile:Mezq en Dajla (Sahara Occidental).jpg|160px|left|thumb\nThe area has been inhabited by Berbers since ancient times. O Dlim is an Arab tribe of Himyarite Kingdom from Yemen that settled in the Sahara in the twelfth century. Dakhla was expanded by Spain settlers d Spanish Empire#The last territories in Africa. The Spanish interest in the desert coast of Western Africas Sahara arose as the result of fishing carried out from the nearby Canary Islands by Spanish fishers and as a result of the Barbary pirates menace.\n\nSpanish fishers were seal fur traders and hs, fishers and whalers along the Saharan coast from Dakhla to Ras Nobou from 1500 to the present, engaging in whaling for Hck whales and their calves, mostly around Cape Verde, and the G gulf in Annobon, S\xe3o Tom\xe9 and Pr\xedncipe islands through 1940. These fishing activities had a negative impact on wildlife, ca the disappearance or endangering of many species, particy marine mammals and birds.\n\nThe Spaniards established whaling stations with some cod fishing and trading. In 1881, a Wharf was anchored off the coast of the R\xedo de Oro Peninsula to st the work of the Canarian fishing fleet.File:Coat of Arms of Villa Cisneros.svg|160px|left|thumbHowever, it was not  1884 that Spain formally fo the watering place as Villa Cisneros, in the settlement dated in 1502 by Papal bull. It was incl in the enclaves conceded to the Spanish to the east of the Azores islands. In 1884, the settlement was promoted by the Spanish Society of Africanists and f by the government of Canovas del Castillo. \n\nThe Spanish military, along with the Spanish Arabist Emilio Bonelli, claimed the coast between Cape Bojador and Cabo Blanco for Spain, fog three settlements on the Saharan coast: one in Villa Cisneros, named in honour of Francisco Cardinal Jim\xe9nez de Cisneros (1436-1517), the Spanish prelate who was the Grand Inqor d the Spanish Inqion; and another in Cabo Blanco for seal hg, which was given the name of Medina Gatell; and another in Angra de Cintra with the name of P Badia, in honour of the Arabist and advent Ali Bey al-Abbasi. Bonelli got the native inhabitants of the peninsula de R\xedo de Oro to sign an agreement which placed them  the protection of the Kingdom of Spain. Due to the presence of the three new settlements, in December that year the Spanish Government officially informed the main colonial powers assembled at the Berlin Conference that the Spanish Crown was in possession of the territory lying between Cape Bojador and Cape Blanco.\n\nD the History of Western Sahara, Spanish aities made Dakhla the capital of the province of R\xedo de Oro, one of the two regions of what was known as Spanish Sahara. They b a military fortress and a modern Catholicism ch. A prison camp also existed at the fort d the Spanish Civil War, at which writers such as Pedro Garc\xeda Cabrera were imprisoned.\n\nD the 1960s the Spain  Franco dictatorship also b Dakhla Airport, one of the three paved airports in Western Sahara. It was from Dakhla, then known as Villa Cisneros, that on Jan 12, 1976, General Gomez de Salazar became the last Spanish soldier to depart what  that moment had been the colony of the Spanish Sahara; faced with Moroccan and Manian pressure, Spanish aities decided to peacef give up the territory instead of taking a fight they believed they could win, but which would have cost many lives on all sides. Between 1975 and 1979, Dakhla was the provincial capital of the Manian province of Tiris al-Gharbiyya, as Mania annexed the son portion of Western Sahara. Dakhla Airport is  as a civilian airport and by Royal Air Maroc. The 3&nbsp;km. long r can accommodate a Boeing 737 or smaller aircraft. The passenger terminal covers 670 m<sup>2</sup> and is capable of handling up to 55,000 passenger/year.\n\nDakhla was occ by Spain from the late 19th century  1975, when power was then relinqd to a joint administration between Morocco and Mania.<ref name="mes.vice.com">http://mes.vice.com/articles/oysters-are-served-with-politics-in-the-disp-western-sahara There was a United Nations-sponsored ceasefire in 1991, but as recently as 2006, the majority of UN member states have ref to recognise Moroccan sovereignty in the area.<ref name="mes.vice.com"/>\n\n\n\n\nFile:Dakhla Trip 1409.JPG|160px|left|thumb\nThe main economic activity of the city is fishing and to. In recent years the town has become a centre for aq sports, such as kitesg, windsg and Casting (fishing)<ref name="mes.vice.com" /><ref name=":0">Graham. 2014. http://mowgli-advent.com/surf-dakhla/ Surf Dakhla. Mowgli Advent. Retrieved on 20 December 2014 and is known as a centre for watersports.<ref name=":1">https://www.thegan.com/travel/2010/sep/04/middle-east-new-trips\n\nCintra Bay and the UNESCO World Heritage Site of the Banc dArguin National Park are located in the south.\n\n\nIt is believed that oil reserves lie off the coastline of Dakhla, which has been a key reason for the territorial disp.<ref name="mes.vice.com"/> US firm Kosmos Energy and its UK copart Cairn Energy began searching for oil in Western Sahara in early 2015 without the permission of the native popon.<ref name="mes.vice.com"/>\n\n\n\nOyster farming by hand is a traditional practice in Dakhla.<ref name="mes.vice.com"/> Oysters are first sold to people and bsses in Dakhla, then to restas in cities like Marrakech or Casablanca, and then any left are sold to E.<ref name="mes.vice.com"/> In April 2015, VICE reported that oysters had recently begun to be exported to high-end Ean restas.<ref name="mes.vice.com"/>\n\n\nDakhla has a Desert climate#Mild desert climates (BWn) according to the K\xf6ppen climate classification. Dakhla receives an average  of precipitation per year. The temperature averages around  d Jan, Dakhlas coldest month and around  d September, its warmest month. The temperature seems to be moderated by the Canary Ct.\n\nClimate-Data.org<ref>\n\n\n| so 2 = Danish Meteorological Institute<ref>\n\n\n\n\n\nFile:Dakhla, Western Sahara.jpg|180px|left|thumb\n\n\nLike most areas in Western Sahara, Dakhla and vicinity areas are very poor in vegetation and are mostly covered by the Sahara Desert. Unlike on land however, sea waters are or had been very rich in sea life due to the highly prode ocean ct of Canary Islands flowing offshore and the renown Nobou ling which is located nearby as well. These environmental factors provide excellent conditions for local fisheries, and result in strong local biodiversity for birds in partic. Among this, there has been a UNESCO proposal to create the "Dakhla National Park".<ref>HELIOPHORA. http://heliophora.com/en/discover/wildlife WILDLIFE. Retrieved on December 20. 2014\n\n\nDakhla Peninsula and Cintra Bay are some of the most important wintering gro for birds especially for waders. The greater flamingo is one of the most iconic birds in the region and there are nus others known to migrate or inhabit. Some of these are; pelican, great cormorant, g (Slender-billed gull, Ans gull, Lesser black-backed gull), larks (Black-crowned sparrow-lark, Bar-tailed lark), terns (Little tern, Caspian tern, Royal tern, Sandwich tern), \nblack wheatear, western reef heron, marsh harrier, sparrowhawk, lesser kestrel, lag dove, great spotted c, little swift, hoopoe, rock martin, cricket longtail, oystercatcher, bar-tailed godwit, pharaoh eagle owl, and red-knobbed coot.<ref>Prder (Team Desert Storm). 2010. http://prder.webs.com/sahara2010.htm Western Sahara Jan 2010. Retrieved on December 20. 2014<ref>Smith S.. 2014. http://birdingpooleharbobeyond.blogspot.jp/2014/04/11-feb-14-some-colour-ringed-ans.html 11 Feb 14 \u2013 Some Colour Ringed Ans G. Retrieved on December 20. 2014<ref>Smith S.. 2014. http://birdingpooleharbobeyond.blogspot.jp/2014/04/10-feb-14-back-on-road-to-nowhere.html 10 Feb 14 \u2013 Back On The Road To Nowhere. Retrieved on December 20. 2014\n\nBald ibis and bq are also rare on todays Western Sahara.\n\nSeveral species such as golden nightjar, S golden sparrow, hooded ve, dark chanting goshawk, speckled pigeon, Mog collared dove, blue-naped mord, Kordofan lark, red-chested swallow, chestnut-bellied starling, African swallow-tailed kite, tawny eagle, slender-billed c, demoiselle crane, Arabian bd, ostrich, lappet-faced ve, helmeted gfowl are seemingly locally rare or extinct, or rather visitors of vagrants.\n\n\nTerrestrial animals are less diverse than birds, incl Rls fox, fennec fox, gloved cat, caracal, hyena, camel, gazelles, addaxes, hares, hedgehog variants, fat sand rat, lesser Egyptian jerboa, bats, and others. Barbary lion and hartebeest became extinct, and possibly local cheetah and North African elephant as well.\n\nThe calm, sheltered water of the Dakhla Bay was once an ideal habitat for various forms of marine life, incl marine mammals. Most of the local animals such as Mediterranean monk seals and whales (mostly North Atlantic right whales) have disappeared due to histories of slar and exploitation like in Cintra Bay. Atlantic gray whales were likely to be seen along the coast before extinction.\n\nOn the other hand, monk seals are showing slow but certain recoveries and Ras Nobou holds the worlds most notable colony for this species. Nowadays, very small, remnant groups of bottlenose dolphins and Atlantic hck dolphins are the only marine mammals still seen regy in Dakhla Bay while there are occasional visits by some other species incl orcas while cetaceans like Minke whale, or sei whale, pilot whales, beaked whales, and dolphins are more common in offshore waters in todays Western Sahara.\n\n\nOther than mammals, limited varieties of terrestrial reptiles, amphibians, arthropods are present here incl lizards, Coronella aaca, Brongersmas toad, and Epius flavica. Sea ts are also present in the Dakhla region.\n\nLarger fish like gros, Ean seabasses or Sciaenidae inhabit along the coasts. Dakhla and Cintra Bay areas are considered to be spawning gro for local sardines.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* https://dakhla.net/ Official Website\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCategory:1502 establishments in Row(id=404171, title=u'Sharad Pawar', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n<ref name=LSMPBio>\n| birth_place = Baramati, Maharashtra<ref name=LSMPBio />\n| residence = Baramati, Pune\n| edon = B.Com (Bachelor of Commerce)<ref name=LSMPBio/>\n| death_date = \n| death_place = \n| office = Member of Parliament of Rajya Sabha for Maharashtra\n| constit =  Maharashtra\n| term_start = 3 April 2014\n| term_end= \n| predecessor =\n| ssor =\n| office1 = Chief Minister of Maharashtra\n| term_start1 = 18 July 1978\n| term_end1 = 17 Febr 1980\n| predecessor1 = Vasantdada Patil\n| ssor1 = Presidents Rule\n| office2 =\n| term_start2 = 26 June 1988\n| term_end2 = 25 June 1991\n| predecessor2 = Shankarrao Chavan\n| ssor2 = Sarrao Naik\n| office3 =\n| term_start3 = 6 March 1993\n| term_end3 = 14 March 1995\n| predecessor3 = Sarrao Naik\n| ssor3 = Manohar Joshi\n| office6 = Bharat Scouts and G\n| term_start6 = 2001\n| term_end6 = 2004\n| predecessor6 = Rameshwar Thakur\n| ssor6 = Rameshwar Thakur\n| office4 = Minister of Agrice (India)\n| term_start4 = 23 May 2004\n| term_end4 =  26 May 2014\n| predecessor4 = Rajnath Singh\n| ssor4 = Radha Mohan Singh\n| office5 = Minister of Cons Affairs, Food and P Distrib (India)\n| term_start5 = 2004\n| term_end5 =  2011\n| predecessor5 = Sharad Yadav\n| ssor5 = K.V. Thomas\n| office7 = International Cricket Co\n| term_start7 = 2010\n| term_end7 = 2012\n| predecessor7 = David Morgan (cricket administrator)\n| ssor7 = Alan Isaac\n| constit_MP8= Baramati (Lok Sabha constit)\n| parliament8 = Indian\n| term_start8 = 1991\n| term_end8 = 2009\n| predecessor8 = Ajit Pawar\n| ssor8 = Sa Sule\n| party =  Nationalist Congress Party   \n| otherparty = Indian National Congress   \n| religion = <!--Needs a reliably phed so where Pawar self identifies.-->\n| spouse = Pratibhatai Pawar\n| children = 1 dar \u2013 Sa Sule\n| profession = Politician\n| website =\n| footnotes =\n| date = 29 October\n| year = 2010\n| so = http://164.100.24.208/ls/lsmember/biodata.asp?mpsno=327\n\nSharad Govindrao Pawar (born 12 December 1940)<ref name=LSMPBio /> is an Indian politician who serves as the president of the Nationalist Congress Party which he fo in 1999, after separating from the Indian National Congress. He previo served as the Chief Minister of Maharashtra on three separate occasions and held the posts of Minister of Defence (India) and Minister of Agrice (India) in the Government of India. Pawar hails from the town of Baramati in the Pune district of Maharashtra. He is a member of the Rajya Sabha where he leads the NCP delegation. He holds a position of prominence in national politics as well as the regional politics of Maharashtra.\n\nPawar has served as the Chairman of the Board of Control for Cricket in India from 2005 to 2008 and as the president of the International Cricket Co from 2010 to 2012.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/8778604.stm Indian Sharad Pawar becomes new ICC president: BBC On 17 June 2015, he was re-elected as president of the M Cricket Association, a position he held from 2001 to 2010 and in 2012.\n\n\nSharad Pawar is one of ten children born to Govindrao Pawar, who was employed in the Baramati Farmers Cooperative (Sahakari Kharedi Vikri Sangh), and Shardabai Pawar, who looked after the family farm at Katewadi, ten kilometres from Baramati. Pawar st at Brihan Maharashtra College of Commerce (BMCC), University of Pune. He was an average st but active in st politics.\n\nPawar is married to Pratibha (n\xe9e Shinde). They have one dar, Sa Sule, who is married to Sadanand Sule. Sa ctly represents the Baramati constit in the 15th Lok Sabha. Pawars nephew, Ajit Pawar, is also a prominent politician and served as the Deputy Chief Minister of Maharashtra. Pratap Pawar, Sharad Pawars yo brother, runs the inflal Marathi daily, Sakal.\n\n\n\n===1967\u20131990===\nPawar entered the Maharashtra Legislative Assembly for the first time in 1967, representing Baramati, and as a member of the ided Indian National Congress. Yashwantrao Chavan was the political mentor of Sharad Pawar.<ref>http://www.manase.org/en/maharashtra.php?mid=68&smid=23&pmid=3&id=885 Sharad Pawar \u2013 A Short BIO by MNS . Manase.org. Retrieved on 30 July 2011.\n\nPawar broke away from the Congress party to form a coalition government with the Janata Party in 1978, becoming the Chief Minister of Maharashtra for the first time. This Progressive Democratic Front government was dismissed in Febr 1980, following Indira Gandhis return to power.\n\nIn the 1980 elections Indian National Congress#1966-84 won the majority in the state assembly, and Abdul Rehman Ant took over as chief minister. Pawar took over the Presidency of his Indian National Congress (Socialist) (Congress(S)) party in 1983. For the first time, he won the Lok Sabha election from the Baramati parliamentary constit in 1984. He also won the state assembly election of March 1985 for Baramati and preferred to continue in state politics for a while, resigning from the Lok Sabha. Congress (S), won 54 seats out of 288 in the state assembly, and he became the leader of the opposition.\n\nHis retg to Congress (I) in 1987 has been cited as a reason for the rise of the Shiv Sena at that time. Pawar had stated at the time, "the need to save the Congress Ce in Maharashtra", as his reason for retg to Congress.  In June 1988, Prime Minister of India and Congress President Rajiv Gandhi decided to induct then Maharashtra Chief Minister Shankarrao Chavan into his Union Cabinet as Finance Minister and Sharad Pawar was chosen to replace Chavan as chief minister. Sharad Pawar had the task of checking the rise of the Shiv Sena in state politics, which was a potential challenge to the dominance of Congress in the state. In the 1989 Lok Sabha elections, Congress won 28 seats out of 48 in Maharashtra. In the state assembly elections of Febr 1990, the alliance between the Shiv Sena and the Bharatiya Janata Party posed a stiff challenge to Congress. Congress fell short of an absolute majority in the state assembly, winning 141 seats out of 288. Sharad Pawar was sworn in as chief minister again on 4 March 1990 with the st of 12 independent or iliated members of the legislative assembly (MLAs).\n\n\nD the co of the 1991 election campaign, former Prime Minister of India Rajiv Gandhi was Assassination of Rajiv Gandhi. There were reports in the media that Pawars name was being considered for the prime ministers post, along with those of P.V. Narasimha Rao and N.D. Tiwari, in the event of a Congress victory. However the Indian National Congress#Ct stre and composition (party MPs) elected P.V. Narasimha Rao as its leader and he was sworn in as prime minister on 21 June 1991. Rao named Pawar as Defence Minister. On 26 June 1991, Pawar took over that portfolio, contin till March 1993. After Pawars ssor in Maharashtra, Sarrao Naik, stepped down, Rao sent Pawar back as chief minister of the state.\n\n"He was sworn in as chief minister for his fo and most controversial term on 6 March 1993. Almost immediately, M, the financial capital of India and the state capital of Maharashtra, was rocked with series of bomb blasts on 12 March 1993."\n\n\nIn 1993, the Deputy Commissioner of the Brihanm Mpal Corporation, G. R. Khairnar made a series of accons against Pawar for being involved in corrn and protecting criminals. Though Khairnar could not produce any evidence in st of his claims, it inevitably affected Pawars popty. Notable social worker Anna Hazare started a fast--death to demand the expn of 12 officers of the Maharashtra state forest department who had been acc of corrn. The opposition parties acc Pawars government of trying to shield the corrupt officers.\n\nThe 1994 Gowari stampede occ at Nagpur, d the Winter Session of Maharashtra State Assembly of the state assembly, and killed 114 people. Nagpur Police were trying to disperse almost 50,000 Gowari and Vanjari (caste) protesters  baton charges but the police created panic and triggered a stampede amongst protesters.<ref name="TIE19981231"> Allegations were made that the mishap occ because welfare minister Madhao Pichad did not meet with the delegation of the Vanjari people in time. Though Pichad, accepting moral responsibility for the mishap, stepped down, this incident was another setback to Sharad Pawars government.\n\nAfter 16 years of protest by the Namantar Andolan (Name-change Movement), the state government finally renamed Marathwada University as Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University on 14 Jan 1994, the compromise new name being an expansion of the old name (Namvistar) rather than a complete change of name (Namanatar). As chief minister Mr Sharad Pawar anno few developments in rsity departments.<ref>Damle, J. S. (2001). Beyond Economic Development: A Case Study of Marathwada, Mittal Pations, pp. 140\u2013146\n\nNew elections to the Vidhan Sabha were held in 1995. The Shiv Sena-Bharatiya Janata Party coalition was leading Congress in the polls, and there was widespread rebellion in the Congress party. Shiv Sena-BJP won 138 seats while Congress retained only 80 seats in the state assembly. Sharad Pawar had to step down and Shiv Sena leader Manohar Joshi took over as chief minister on 14 March 1995. Until the Lok Sabha elections of 1996, Sharad Pawar served as the Opposition (parliamentary) in the state assembly. In the 1996 General elections, Pawar won the Baramati seat in the Lok Sabha and left the state assembly.\n\n\nIn June 1997, Sharad Pawar cessf challenged Sitaram Kesri for the post of President of the Indian National Congress. In the mid-term parliamentary elections of 1998, Pawar not only won his constit, Baramati, but also led Congress to a win by a large majority of Maharashtran Lok Sabha constites. Congress was aligned with the Repan Party of India (Athvale) and Samajwadi Party for the Lok Sabha elections in Maharashtra. The Congress party won 33 Lok Sabha seats oht, and the allied Repan Party of India won 4 more, for a total of 37 out of 48 in the state. Sharad Pawar served as Leader of Opposition in the 12th Lok Sabha. In May 2017, Pawar r out being a candidate for the June Indian presidential election, 2017.\n\n\nIn 1999, after the 12th Lok Sabha was dissolved and elections to the 13th Lok Sabha were called, Pawar, P. A. Sangma, and Tariq Anwar (politician) demanded that the Congress party needed to propose someone native-born as the prime ministerial candidate and not the Italian-born Sonia Gandhi, who had entered party politics and replaced Kesri as Congress president. In June 1999, Pawar and Sangma fo the Nationalist Congress Party. This new party had to align with the Congress party to form a coalition government in Maharashtra, as neither party could win an absolute majority on its own in the 1999 state assembly elections. Pawar, however, did not return to state politics and Vilasrao Deshmukh of Congress was chosen as chief minister, with Chagan Bh representing the Nationalist Congress Party as his deputy.\n\n\nAfter the 2004 Lok Sabha elections, Pawar joined the United Progressive Alliance government headed by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh as the Minister of Agrice (India). In Jan 2012, Pawar anno that he would not contest the 2014 Lok Sabha election in order to make way for yo leadership.<ref>http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-01-29/india/30675770_1_ajit-pawar-ncp-leaders-sa-sule NCP chief Sharad Pawar to make way for GenNext in 2014 Also in 2012, Pawar gave up the chairmanship of the Empowered Group of Ministers investigating the 2G spectrum scam, days after his appointment by the prime minister, fearing that his association with the decision-making process would drag him into the 2G Spectrum controversy.\n\n\nPawar has interests in cricket, kabbadi, kho kho, wrestling and association football.\nHe has served as the head of various sports organisations, incl\n* M Cricket Association\n* Maharashtra Wrestling Association\n* Maharashtra Kabbadi Association\n* Maharashtra Kho Kho Association\n* Maharashtra Olympics Association\n* Board of Control for Cricket in India President 2005\u20132008\n* International Cricket Co Vice President<ref>http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/about-icc/exec.html International Cricket Co \u2013 ICC Events, ICC Cricket Rankings, Live Cricket Scores, ODI Fantasy League, Test Predictor. Icc-cricket.yahoo.com (3 July 1951). Retrieved on 30 July 2011.\n* International Cricket Co President\nPawar served as the president of Pune International Marathon Trust, which has hosted Pune International Marathon for last 22 years.\n\n\nPawar is associated with the Hon. Sharad Pawar P School,  the Shree Gtta Edon Society; the Sharad Pawar International School, Pune; and the Sharad Pawar Cricket Academy, near M.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992\u201393, the then Maharashtra Chief Minister Sarrao Naik made a statement that the state leader of Indian National Congress party and erstwhile-Chief Minister Pawar, had asked him to "go easy on Pappu Kalani", a well known criminal-t-politician.<ref name=fear> Shiv Sena chief, Bal Thackeray, later conc with these allegations.<ref name=express2>\n Fr, Chief Minister Naik also alleged that it was possible that Kalani and Hitendra Thakur, another criminal-t-politician from Virar, had been given tickets to contest election for the Maharashtra State Legislature at the behest of Pawar, who also put in a word for Naik with the police when the latter was arrested for his role in post-Demolition of the Babri Masjid riots in M.<ref name=express1>\n\n\nPawar is also alleged to have close links with the world don Dawood Ibrahim<ref>http://www.okindia.com/article.aspx?200790 Pawars Time Of Reckoning. www.okindia.com. 14 Febr 1996. Retrieved on 6 December 2011. through Ibrahims henchman Lakhan Singh based in the Middle East and close relationship with Shahid Balwa, also a st in the 2G spectrum scam. These allegations were strengthened by the revelation about the involvement of Vinod Goenka, Balwas bss partner, in a controversial commercial project in Yerwada, Pune, which was being constr  the same s n as Pawars family friend, Atul Chordia, had constr the Panchshil Tech Park. BJP leader Eknath Khadse alleged that it was Balwa who had applied for environmental clearance for the two projects, a charge that Chordia ref. Coincidentally, Chordias Panchshil Pvt. Ltd. has Pawars dar, Sa Sule, and her hd Sadanand as investors.<ref>http://www.dnaindia.com/blogs/post_will-maharashtra-forgive-sharad-pawar_1581568 Will Maharashtra forgive Sharad Pawar? \u2013 Blogs \u2013 DNA. Dnaindia.com. 5 April 2011. Retrieved on 6 December 2011. The state governments decision to hand over a 3-acre plot of the Yerwada police station for "re-development" to Balwa was retracted following Balwas arrest.\n\n\nPawar was also named as a beneficiary in a stamp paper scam by a convicted Indian criminal, Abdul Karim Telgi, d a Truth serum test, filmed by various Indian news channels, wherein he also mentioned Chhagan Bh.<ref name="Telgi names Sharad Pawar in scam">\n\n\nIn 2007, the Bharatiya Janata Party asked for Pawars resignation after alleging he was involved in a m-crore Indian r (INR) scam involving wheat imports. In May 2007, a tender floated by the Food Corporation of India (FCI) for procnt of wheat was cancelled when the lowest bid received was for 263 United States dollar/ton. The government sy allowed private traders to pse wheat directly from farmers that year resg in a pa of wheat to stock FCI granaries. By July 2007 the shortage at FCI was large enough to req import of wheat at a much higher price of 320\u2013360 USD/ton. Taking advantage of this, traders who had domestically psed wheat at 900 INR/ton earlier, were now offering the same to FCI at 1,300 INR/ton.<ref>http://www.dailypioneer.com/indexn12.asp?main_variable=NATION&file_name=nt2%2Etxt&co_img=2 BJP seeks Pawars resignation  The Pioneer \u2013 13 July 2007.<ref>http://www.hindu.com/2007/07/13/stories/2007071354361500.htm Wheat import scandalous: BJP. The Hindu. 13 July 2007.\n\n\nAs the Minister of Agrice, Pawar was consistently acc of coll in the extreme hike in prices of agrical produce:\n* Wheat import in 2007 \u2013 The Bombay High Court issued notices to Union agrice minister Sharad Pawar, qoning the decision to import defective red wheat, and asking for a directive to s details of procnt of the crop from different states and the exact process of importing it.\n* S prices in 2009 \u2013 Opposition parties, incl the BJP and the Comm Party of India (Marxist) acc Sharad Pawar of engineering a steep rise in the price of s to the advantage of hoarders and importers.\n* Wheat, S, Rice, and Bean prices in 2009-2010 \u2013 The opposition acc Pawar to be responsible on the issue of spiraling prices.\n\n\nD his tenure as Minister of Agrice, there have been farmer ses in excess of 10,000 per year, totalling over 200,000 since 1997.<ref>http://www.indiatribune.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5389:every-12-hours-one-farmer-commits-se-in-india&catid=106:magazine Every 12 hours, one farmer commits se in India. Indiatribune.com (2010-11-06). Retrieved on 2014-05-21. Sharad Pawar has stated on record that he believes that the rate of farmer se in India is a normal thing. However he reaffirms that he is taking the necessary steps to reduce the ns.<ref>http://ibnlive.in.com/news/farmer-se-is-a-normal-thing-pawar/12245-4-single.html Farmer se is a normal thing: Pawar - IBNLive. Ibnlive.in.com. Retrieved on 2014-05-21. \n\n\nEven though the pesticide endos has been banned, India is slow to phase it out. In spite of its known Endos#Health effects, Pawar made a remark that endos is not yet proved dangerous. This remark prompted activist Vandana Shiva to call him a corrupt minister.\n\n\nOn 27 October 2007, the Bombay High Court served notices to instits headed by Pawar, Ajit Pawar, and Sadanand Sule (Sharad Pawars son-in-law), along with a corresponding notice served to the Maharashtra Krishna Valley Development Corporation (MKVDC) on why special privileges were given to Pawar and his family. This was done in consideration of P Interest Litigation No. 148 of 2006, filed by Shams Potare alleging that the said 2002 land allocations in Pune were illegal. The instits and properties mentioned include:\n* Two  plots given allotted to Vidya Pratishthan, an edonal society headed by Sharad Pawar\n* A  plot allotted to Anant Smriti Pratishthan, headed by Ajit Pawar, the Maharashtra state minister for irrigation and Sharad Pawars nephew\n* A  plot allotted to Lavasa Corporation, owned by Sule. Sule handed over his share in 2006.\n* A  plot allotted to Shivajinagar Agrice College\n* A  plot allotted to Sharadchandraji Scout and G Training Institute.\n\nThese allocations were allegedly made by NCP leader and minister Ramraje Naik Nimbalkar who was in charge of MKVDC at the time.<ref name=trib><ref name=ndtv1> Sharad Pawar was served a contempt of court notice on 1 May 2008 in connection with this case for iss statements to the press even though the matter was sice at the time. Also in connection with the case, the respondents were directed not to create third-party interests in the property  dispute and to take any developments at their own risk.<ref name=bhc1>\n<ref name=toi1>\n\n\n\nIn 2010, in the case of tax exemptions of the Indian Premier League (IPL), Shiv Sena MLA Sh Desai alleged that the state cabinet decided in Jan to impose the tax, before the years IPL season started, but the decision was not implemented because of NCP chief Pawars association with the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI).<ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Tax-exemptions-for-rich-costs-govt-Rs-4-6L-cr/articleshow/11149543.cms Tax exemptions for rich costs govt Rs 4.6L cr Bombay High Court on A 2010 said there was "nothing on record" to show that the Union Minister infld the Maharashtra governments decision to exempt Indian Premier League matches from entertainment tax.<ref>http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2010-08-24/news/27613804_1_entertainment-tax-ipl-exemption No proof to show Pawar infld IPL exemption from tax: HC\n\n\nIn 2011, Sharad Pawar declared his assets to be worth  as part of a mandatory disclosure, but his critics claimed that his wealth far exceeded the stated amount.<ref>http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-indias-most-hated-politicians/20111207.htm Indias Most Hated Politicians: Sharad Pawar, Rediff.com, 7 December 2011.<ref>Abhay Vaidya & Partha Sarathi Biswas. http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_sharad-pawar-fooled-all-with-rs12-crore-assets-disclosure_1586905 Sharad Pawar fooled all with Rs12 crore assets disclosure. DNA, 14 September 2011. In 2010, it was alleged that the Pawar family indirectly held a 16% stake in the City Corporation, which had bid  for the Pune franchise of the Indian Premier League (IPL). Pawar and his family denied the allegations, but the bidders board of the IPL contradicted their claims.<ref>http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-06-06/india/28313302_1_deshpande-bid-pawar-sule-lap-finance IPL bidders Jan 31 board resol contradicts Pawar & Sules claims. The Times of India, 2010.<ref>http://ibnlive.in.com/news/ipl-controversy-ref-to-shed-pawar--family/122045-37-64.html Pawar & family get entangled in IPL mess, IBNLive 25 June 2010.<ref>http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report_ipl-scam-most-serious-blow-to-sharad-pawar-s-power-credibility_1392793 IPL scam most serious blow to Sharad Pawar\u2019s power, credibility, DNA, 7 June 2010.\n\n\nIn 2011,  investigation of the 2G spectrum scam Radia tapes controversy told the Central B of Investigation (CBI) that agrice minister Pawar may be controlling the controversial DB Realty. According to the reports, she also told the investigative agency that Pawar may have spoken with former telecom minister A. Raja about the allocation of spectrum and licence to Etisalat#Etisalat \u2013 India. Radia also said that she had no docary proof to back up her allegations. Pawar has denied any link with former DB managing director Shahid Balwa who is now in CBI cy.\n\n\nSharad Pawar is alleged to have demanded compensation for allowing the planned-city Lavasa to be constr. When Lavasa Corporation was receiving necessary clearances from the government of Maharashtra, relatives of Pawar had part-ownership of the company developing the project.<ref name=nepotism1> Pawars dar and son-in-law had more than 20% ownership between 2002 and 2004, and they later sold their stakes.<ref name=nepo> A nephew of his was chairman of Maharashtra Krishna Valley Development Corporation (MKVDC) when the MKVDC signed off on lease agreements for Lavasa and allowed it to store water and b dams.<ref name=nepotism1/><!-- added following two references from pricing scandals, where they didnt seem to belong --><ref>http://www.downtoearth.org.in/node/33283 Sharad Pawars, Ajit Pawars and Sa Sules names also prominently figure in the m-crore Lavasa land scam. Downtoearth.org.in (15 April 2011). Retrieved on 30 July 2011.\n\n\nAfter the 2010 Pune bombing of German Bakery, Sharad Pawar appeared to take the incident lightly. He said to the reporters, "It is not alright to arrive at a concl that the entire Pune city has been targeted. The place where the blast took place is an isolated area", adding "when I was Chief Minister, M saw 11 simeous blasts but everything ret to normal soon."\n\n\nPawar was slapped by a youth named Harvinder Singh at the New Delhi Mpal Corporation centre while leaving the premises after attending a literary fon on 24 November 2011.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-15868349 BBC News \u2013 India agrice minister Sharad Pawar slapped. Bbc.co.uk (24 November 2011). Retrieved on 6 December 2011. The attacker, who previo is said to have assa former telecom minister Sukh Ram, was later arrested.\n\n\nPadma Vibh (2017)\n\n\n* First Sharad Pawar ministry\n\n\n\n\n\n* P. K. Row(id=445059, title=u'Henry Lane Wilson', text_clean=u'\n\n\n \nHenry Lane Wilson (November 3, 1857 &ndash; December 22, 1932) was an United States diplomacy.\n\n\n\nHe was born in Crawfordsville, Indiana, Montgomery Co, Indiana, to Indiana congressman James Wilson (Indiana) and his wife, Emma (Ingersoll) Wilson (September 10, 1830 \u2013 Jan 22, 1912); he was the yo brother of John L. Wilson, and had been named for Henry Smith Lane.  He was a law grad of Wabash College and practiced law and phed a newspaper in Lafayette, Indiana. He married Alice Vajen in 1885,<ref name="politicalgraveyard.com">http://politicalgraveyard.com/geo/IN/MA5.html   and moved to Spokane, Washington where he was in bss  he was financially wiped out in the Panic of 1893.\n\n\nWilson served in the US Foreign Service d the presidencies of William McKinley (1897\u20131901), Theodore Roosevelt (1901\u20131909) and William Howard Taft (1909\u20131913). He was appointed Minister to Chile in 1897, remaining in that capacity  1904, when he was made Minister to Belgium, serving in Brs d the height of the Congo Free State controversy. Wilson was appointed ambassador to Mexico in 1910, where he was witness to the fall of the Mexican government of General Porfirio Diaz, and was one of the main actors in defining the Mexican Revol.<ref name="McLynn">\n\n\n\nWilson was appointed Ambassador to Mexico by President Taft on December 21, 1909 and presented his credentials to President Diaz on March 5, 1910.<ref name="emersonkent.com">  He became personally acqed with some of the most important fig of the Revol, such as \xc1lvaro Obreg\xf3n, Venno Carranza, Pancho Villa, and Francisco I. Madero.  As William Howard Tafts List of United States Ambassadors to Mexico, fearing the leftist tendencies of the new Madero government  the o of Diaz (not to mention the fact that he considered Madero a lc),<ref name="emersonkent.com"/> he ass the role of catalyst for the plot of General Victoriano H, F\xe9lix D\xedaz (politician)|Felix D\xedaz, and General Bernardo Reyes against President Madero, and was pted to have assisted in arranging the m of Madero and his vice-president, Jos\xe9 Mar\xeda Pino Su\xe1rez, d Ten Tragic Days|La decena tr\xe1gica (The Ten Tragic Days) in Febr 1913, a point that was later disp by Wilson.<ref name="McLynn" /> After his ination in March of that year, President Woodrow Wilson was informed of events in Mexico by a special agent, William Bayard Hale and was appalled by Henry Lane Wilsons assistance to the H coup d\xe9tat against Madero. The President snted him by sending as his personal envoy John Lind (politician), the former governor of Minnesota, and on 17 July 1913,<ref name="emersonkent.com"/> the President dismissed Ambassador Wilson.\n\n\n\nD the World War I, Wilson served on the  Commission for Relief in Belgium and, in 1915, accepted the chairmanship of the Indiana State Chapter of the League to Enforce Peace, a position he held  his resignation over US involvement in the League of Nations after the close of the war. Wilson was a member of Sons of the American Revol, Society of Colonial Wars and the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States.<ref name="politicalgraveyard.com"/> He phed his memoir in 1927, and died in Indianapolis in 1932.  He is b in Crown Hill Cemetery, Indianapolis.\n\n\n\n\n\n*http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Wilson&GSfn=Henry+&GSmn=Lane+&GSbyrel=in&GSdyrel=in&GSob=n&GRid=34267327& Henry Lane Wilson \u2013 Find A Grave\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCategory:1857 births\nCategory:1932 deaths\nCategory:People from Crawfordsville, Indiana\nCategory:Ambassadors of the United States to Row(id=448506, title=u'Flemish Movement', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nFile:Eerste.png|thil|Flemish flag, as  by the Flemish Movement.\nThe Flemish Movement () is the political movement for greater amy of the Belgium region of Flanders, for protection of the D lang, and for the overall protection of Flemish ce and history.\n\nThe Flemish Movements moderate wing was for a long time dominated by the Volks ("Peoples Union") \u2013 a party that from its onset in 1954  its collapse in 2002 greatly advanced the Flemish cause, though severely criticised by hardliners for being too accommodating. After the Volkss collapse, the partys representatives were absorbed by other Flemish parties. Today nearly every Flemish party (except for the far right Vlaams Belang) can be considered part of the moderate wing of the Flemish Movement. This wing has many ties with  and ind organisations, especially with the VOKA (network of the Vlaams Economisch Verbond (VEV, Flemish Economic Union).\n\nThe Flemish Movements right wing is dominated by radical right-wing organizations such as Vlaams Belang, Voorpost, Nationalistische Stenvereniging (Nationalist Sts Union), and several others. The most radical group on the left side is the socialist and Flemish independentist Flemish-Socialist Movement. The militant wing also still comprises several moderate groups such as the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA, Nieuw-Vlaamse Alliantie), and several extra-parliamentary organisations, many of which are represented in the Overlegcentrum van Vlaamse Verenigingen (OVV, Consion Centre of Flemish Associations). The most important of these is the Vlaamse Volksbeweging (VVB, Flemish Peoples Movement).\n\n\n\n\nToday, the militant wing of the Flemish Movement generally advocates the foion of an independent Flemish rep, separating from Wallonia. The rightist parties Vlaams Belang and N-VA (the largest party in the Flemish Parliament as of 2014) st this view. A part of this militant wing also advocates re with the Netherlands. This view is shared with several D right-winged activists and nationalists, as well as some mainstream politicians both in the Netherlands and Flanders (such as Louis Tobback, the mayor of Le or former minister of defence and Emmissioner Frits Bolkestein).<ref>Louis Tobbacks opinion can be read in http://knack.rnews.be/nl/acteit/nieuws/belgie/louis-tobback-dit-is-een-belachelijk-land-geworden/article-1194676682363.htm knack.rnews.be, Frits Bolkesteins in http://www.fritsbolkestein.com/site/references#this fritsbolkestein.com\n\n\nThe liberal Lijst Dedecker, as well as several representatives of important Flemish parties belonging to the moderate wing, incl the Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams (CD&V) party, the Open Vlaamse Liberalen en Democraten (VLD) party, and, to a lesser extent, the Socialistische Partij Anders (SP.A), prefer a confederal organisation of the Belgian state over the ct Federation organisation.  Such a scheme would make the Flemish government responsible for nearly all aspects of government, whereas some important aspects of government are ctly the responsibility of the Belgian federal government. The Belgian capital of Brs would remain a city where both D-speaking and French-speaking citizens share equal rights.\n\nAs of 2010, the confederalist parties make up more than half of the Flemish Parliament, which combined with the separatist parties, would result in about 80% of the Flemish Parliament (and at least this much of the Flemish part of the Belgian Federal Parliament) occ by parties who wish to see Flanders obtaining greater amy than is the case today.\n\n\nSeveral representatives of the SP.A and, to a lesser extent, the CD&V and VLD parties, prefer an improved federal organisation of the Belgian state over a confederal one. This view is shared with several social and cal organisations such as the Vermeylenfonds (Vermeylen Foion) or Willemsfonds, with labor s, and with m health inse organisations. The advocates of this view hope to improve the Belgian instits so that they work correctly.\n\n\nAfter the secession of Belgium in 1830, the Orangist sentiment in Flanders for a time so the restoration of the United Kingdom  the house of Orange. Some of the most prominent Flemish Orangists were Jan Frans Willems and Hippolyte Metdepenningen. This sentiment inspired the later Greater Netherlands movement, although that movement was not all monarchist. At present there is only little p st in Flanders (mainly around Flemish-nationalistic parties and the Algemeen-Nederlands Verbond), so there is hardly any p st for the house of Orange. A confederation state made out of these two nations is the only idea that has gained wider st.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1788 Jan-Baptist Verlooy (1747\u20131797), a j and politician from the Son Netherlands, wrote an essay titled Verhandeling op dOnacht der moederlycke tael in de Nederlanden<ref>Van der Wal, Marijke (1992) Geschiedenis van het Nederlands History of D (in D), Utrecht, Het Spectrum, p. 379, ISBN 90 274 1839 X. (Essay on the disregard of the native lang in the Low Coes), the first sign of life of the Flemish movement: a plea for the native lang, but also for freedom and democracy.\n\n\n\nWhen the Congress of Vienna created the United Kingdom of the Netherlands, with Protestant William I of the Netherlands its king, he declared D to be the only official lang in all the newly created co. Wallonia, as well as the Catholic clergy and the boisie in Brs and Flanders, spoke mainly French, ca anced representation in the D Parliament.\n\nOn October 4, 1830, Belgian separatists who were mainly French speaking Belgian Revol of Belgium from the Netherlands. The Flemish provinces were sinated by a Belgian army consisting mainly of volrs from Wallonia, sted by French troops. For example, Ghent was taken by the French Count Pont\xe9co with volrs from Brs and Paris; Antwerp by Generals De Parent, Mellinet and Niellon.\n\nLarge Flemish cities like Ghent and Antwerp were opposed to separation for  economic reasons. They had to deal with rebellious workers who mostly choose the side of the Orangism (Belgium) due to poor harvests. This was, however, more an act of discontent than an act of rejecting separatism. In Br, for instance, they opposed the separatists who had already taken power in that city. Three years after the separation Orangist parties gained a majority d the mpal elections in some of the aforementioned cities.\n\n\nUpon Belgium becoming an independent state from the Netherlands, there was an (administrative) reaction against the D people and their lang. In an attempt to remove D from the new co, Belgian officials declared that the only official lang in Belgium now was French. The Administration, Je System, and higher edon (apart from elementary schools in Flanders) all foned in the  French lang.<ref name="De1973"> Even Brs, the capital where more than 95% of the popon spoke D, lacked a formal, state-sanctioned Flemish school of higher edon.\n\nThe French-speaking Belgian government sded in removing the D lang from all levels of government more qy in Brs than in any other part of Flanders. For example: D was worth 10 points in French schools, but drawing earned 15 points.<ref name="De1973" /> Today Frenchification of Brs#Ct sitn of Brs is D-speaking, whereas in 1830 it was over 95%.<ref name="tlfq.l">\n\nThe French-speaking boisie showed very little respect for the Flemish portion of the popon. Belgiums co-fo, Charles Rogier, wrote in 1832 to Jean-Joseph Raikem, the minister of je:\n\n"Les premiers principes dune bonne administration sont bas\xe9s sur lemploi excl dune langue, et il est \xe9vident que la seule langue des Belges doit \xeatre le fran\xe7ais. Pour arriver \xe0 ce r\xe9s, il est n\xe9cessaire que to les fonctions civiles et militaires soient confi\xe9es \xe0 des Wallons et \xe0 des Lois; de cette mani\xe8re, les Flamands, priv\xe9s temporairement des avantages attach\xe9s \xe0 ces emplois, seront contraints dapprendre le fran\xe7ais, et lon d\xe9tr ainsi peu \xe0 peu l\xe9l\xe9ment germanique en Belgique."<ref name="tlfq.l" />\n\n"The first principles of a good administration are based  the excl use of one lang, and it is evident that the only lang of the Belgians should be French. In order to achieve this result, it is necessary that all civil and military fons are entr to Walloons and Ls; this way, the Flemish, temporarily deprived of the advantages of these offices, will be constrained to learn French, and we will hence destroy bit by bit the Germanic element in Belgium."\n\nIn 1838, another co-fo, senator Alexandre Gendebien, even declared that the Flemish were "one of the more inferior races on the Earth, just like the negroes".\n\nThe economic heart of Belgium in those days was Flanders. However, Wallonia would soon take the lead due to the Indal Revol. The Belgian establishment deemed it essary to invest in Flanders and no less than 80% of the Belgian GNP between 1830 and 1918 went to Wallonia. This had as a conseq that Wallonia had a ss of large coal mines and iron ore facilities, while Flanders, to a large extent, remained a r, farming region. When Belgium became independent, the economy of Flanders was hard hit. Antwerp was now almost impossible to reach by ships (The Scheldt River was blocked by the Netherlands) and foreign trade was drastically affected. The prosperous textile ind of Ghent lost a major portion of its market to Amsterdam.\n\n\nFile:Roeselare Hugo Verriest -1.JPG|thumb|Bust of  in Roeselare, Belgium.\n\nIt was decades after the Belgian revol that Flemish intellect such as Jan Frans Willems, Philip Blommaert, Karel Lodewijk Ledeganck, Ferdinand Aijn Snellaert, A Snieders, Pr van D, and Hendrik Conscience began to call for recognition of the D lang and Flemish ce in Belgium. This movement became known as the Flemish Movement, but was more intellectual than social, with contrib such as the poets G Gezelle, , and Albrecht Rodenbach.\n\nCal organizations promoting the D lang and Flemish ce were fo, such as the Willemsfonds in 1851, and the Davidsfonds in 1875. The first Vlaemsch Verbond (Constant Leirens, Ghent) and the Nederd Bond, were fo in 1861. The Liberale Vlaemsche Bond was fo in 1867. Writers such as J de Geyter and Max Rooses were active in the Nederd Bond. On 26 September 1866, J de Geyter fo the Vlaamsche Bond in Antwerp. The Flemish weekly magazine Het Volksbelang, fo by J Veke, appeared for the first time on 12 Jan 1867.\n\nIn 1861, the first Flemish political party, the Meetingpartij was fo in Antwerp, by radical liberals, Catholics and Flamingants (Jan Theodoor van Rijswijck, J. De Laet and E. Coremans), and it existed  1914. In 1888, J Hoste Sr. fo the moderate liberal Flemish newspaper Het Laatste Nieuws, to st the Flemish Movement in Brs. In 1893, the Flemish priest Adolf Daens, fo the Christene Volkspartij, which would cause a radicalization and democratization of the Catholic Party (Belgium). The first Flemish political ss was the passing of the Gelijkheidswet (Eqy law) in 1898 that for the first time recognized D as equal to French in jal matters (legal docs).\n\n\nThe liberal politician Louis Franck (politician), the Roman Catholic Frans Van Caert and the socialist Camille Hns (together they were called the three crowing cocks) worked together for the introdn of D at Ghent University. In 1911 the proposal by Lodewijk De Raet to this end was accepted, though it would not be implemented  1930. With the coming of the 20th century the Flemish Movement became more radical and d World War I some Activism welcomed the occs as "liberating Germanic peoples". The young Marnix Gijsen and the poet Paul van Ostaijen were involved in this activist movement d the war. The Germans did indeed help out their "Germanic brothers" by setting D as the sole administrative lang and by creating the D lang Von Bissing University in Ghent. Such steps were dictated by the German tactics of taking advantage of the Flemish-Walloon animosity in order to fr Germanys own aims and to boost the occg powers position known as the Flamenpolitik. With German st, Flemish activists formed a regional government, known as the Raad van Vlaanderen (World War I) (RVV) which declared Flemish amy in December 1917.\n\nMost of the Flemish popon disapproved of those who collaborated with the German occs. The lang reforms implemented by the Germans d occon did not remain in place after the defeat of Germany. The collaboration and s prosec of certain leaders of the Flemish Movement did not produce a climate congenial to compromise.\n\n\n\nThe Flemish Movement became more socially oriented through the Frontbeweging (Front Movement), an organization of Flemish soldiers who complained about the lack of consideration for their lang in the army, and in Belgium in general, and harbored pacifistic feelings. The Frontbeweging became a political movement, dedicated to peace, tolerance and amy (Nooit Meer Oorlog, Godsvrede, Zelfbestuur). A IJzerbedevaart is still held to this day. The poet Anton van Wilderode wrote many texts for this occasion.\nMany rs arose regarding the treatment of Flemish soldiers in World War I, though  Flemish historians deb many of these. One such r is that many D-speaking soldiers were slared because they could not stand orders given to them in French by French speaking officers. Whether a disproportionate amount of Flemings died in the war compared to Walloons, is to this day being disp. It is clear however, that the Belgian army de facto had only French as the official lang. The phrase "et pour les Flamands, la meme chose" originated in this environment also, allegedly being  by the French-speaking officers to "translate" their orders into D. It literally means "and for the Flemish, the same thing", which adds insult to injury for Flemish soldiers not standing French.\nAnother so of fr frtion was the Belgian royal familys poor knowledge of D. King Albert I of Belgium enjoyed some popty in the early ages of the war, because he was a proponent of the bilingual status of Flanders - even though Wallonia was monolingual French, because he declared his oath to be king in both French and D, and because he gave a speech at the start of the war in D, referring to the Battle of the Golden Spurs. In the last years of the war however, it became clear that the only wish of the king was to keep his co peaceful, and not to give the Flemish the rights the French-speaking establishment denied them.\n\nIn the 1920s the first Flemish nationalist party was elected. In the 1930s the Flemish Movement grew ever larger and D was recognized for the first time as the sole lang of Flanders. In 1931, Joris Van Severen fo the Verbond van Dietse Nationaal-Solidaristen Verdinaso, a fascist movement in Flanders.\n\n\nD World War II, Belgium was once again occ by Germany. The Third Reich enacted laws to protect and enco the D lang in Belgium and, generally, to propagate ill-feelings between Flemings and Francophones, e.g. by setting free only Flemish prisoners-of-war (see Flamenpolitik). The Nazis had no intentions of allowing the creation of an independent Flemish state or of a Greater Netherlands, and instead desired the complete annexation of not only Flanders (which they did de jure d the war through the establishment of a "Reichsgau Reichsgau Flandern" in late 1944), but all of the Low Coes as "racially Germanic" components of a Greater Germanic Reich. Most  Flemish nationalists embraced Collaboration with the Axis Powers d World War II as a means to more amy. Because of this collaboration by a few, after the war being part of the Flemish movement was associated with having collaborated with the enemy.\n\n\nWhile the Vermeylenfonds had been fo in 1945, the Flemish Movement lay dormant for nearly 20 years following the Second World War. In the 1960s the Flemish movement once more gathered momentum and, in 1962, the lingc borders within Belgium were finally drawn up with Brs being designated as a bilingual city. Also, in 1967 an official D version of the Belgian Constit was adopted.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20070614025223/http://www.d.org/UNRISD/website/doc.nsf/ab82a6805797760f80256b4f005da1ab/ec506a59176be044c1256e9e003077c3/$FILE/Deschou.pdf Ethnic stre, ineqy and governance of the p sector in Belgium For more than 130 years, the D version of the Belgian constit had been only a translation without legal value.\nThe late 1960s saw all major Belgian political parties splitting up into either Flemish or Francophone wings. It also saw the emergence of the first major nationalist Flemish party, the Volks (Pop Union, but not in a comm sense). In 1977 more radical far right-wing factions of the Volks became d and, together with earlier far right nationalist groups, formed Vlaams Blok. This party  event overtook the Volks, only to be forced later, on the gro of a discrimination conviction, to change its name to Vlaams Belang. It has become an important right-wing party of the Flemish Movement.\n\n\n\nD the existence of Belgium more and more D-speaking regions have become French-speaking regions; for example, Mon (Moeskroen), Comines (Belgium) (Komen), and particy Brs (see Francization of Brs). Every ten years the government co the people who spoke D and those who spoke French. These cogs always favo the French-speaking part of Belgium.<ref name="De1973" /> In 1962 the Lingc Border was drawn. In order to do so, a complicated compromise with the French-speakers was orchestrated: Brs had to be recognised as an amous and bilingual region while Flanders and Wallonia remained monolingual regions. The French-speakers also demanded that in certain regions where there was a minority of more than 30% French-speaking or D-speaking people; there would be Mpalities with lang facilities. This means that these people can commte with the government in their birth lang.\n\n\nThe Flemish saw these facilities as a measure of integration to another lang, as opposed to viewing it as a recognition of a permanent lingc minority. The French-speaking people, however, saw these Mpalities with lang facilities as an acq right, and a step for an eventual addition to the bilingual region of Brs, even though that would be stital.<ref> http://www2.vlaanderen.be/taalwetgeving/vlaamse_rand.html "Vlaanderen en de taalwetgeving" (Flanders and lang legislation), vlaanderen.be (ministerie van de Vlaamse Gemeenschap) As a result, the amount of French-speaking people in these regions (mostly around Brs) did not decline, and contain a growing majority of French-speaking Belgians, even though they reside in the officially monolingual Flanders. This "frenchification" is considered frting by the Flemish Movement and a reason for a call to separate.\n\nThe sitn is intensified due to a lack of D lang classes in the French-speaking schools.\n\n\n\nSince the 1960s and contin into the present time, Flanders is significantly richer than Wallonia.  Based on popon<ref>http://statbel.fgov.be/nl/binaries/Totale%20en%20belgische%20bevolking%20op%201-1-2007%20NL_tcm325-75739.pdf Statbel.fgov.be and GDP <ref>http://www.nbb.be/doc/dq/n/dq3/histo/NNCR07.pdf NBB.be fig for 2007, GDP per capita in that year was 28286 \u20ac (38186 $) in Flanders and 20191 \u20ac (27258 $) in Wallonia.   Although eqation payments between richer and poorer regions are common in federal states, the amount, the visibility and the zation of these financial transfers are a singy important issue for the Flemish Movement. A study by the University of Le<ref>http://www.econ.ken.be/vives/PUBLICATIES/BP/BP2010/vivesbeleidspaper13.pdf Econ.ken.be has estimated the size of the annual transfers from Flanders to Wallonia and Brs in 2007 at 5.7 billion e. If the effect of interest payments on the national debt is taken into account the figure could be as high as 11.3 billion e or more than 6% of Flemish GDP.<ref> http://www.niead.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=GKA9LLK1  "Geldstroom naar Walloni\xeb bereikt recordhoogte" (Money transfers reach record height), niead.be<ref> http://trends.rnews.be/nl/economie/nieuws/beleid/vlaanderen-en-wallonie-zijn-beter-af-zonder-transfers/article-1194727390543.htm "Vlaanderen en Walloni\xeb zijn beter af zonder transfers" (Flanders and Wallonia are better off without transfers) Flemish criticism is not limited to the size of the transfers but also extends to the lack of transparency and the pres inability or lingness of the recipients to use the money wisely and thus close the economic gap with Flanders. Although no longer relevant in the ct economic context, the discn is often exacerbated by the historic fact that even in the 19th century, when Flanders was much the poorer region, there was a net transfer from Flanders to Wallonia; this was mainly because of relatively heavier taxation of agrice than of indal activity.<ref name="transfer">\nThe tax system was never adj to reflect the indal affl of Wallonia, which led to an imbalance in tax revenue placing Flanders (average for 1832-1912 period: 44% of the popon, 44% of total taxes) at a disadvantage compared with Wallonia (38% of popon, 30% of taxes).<ref name="transfers"> \n\n\n\nAs a result of escalating internal conflicts the Volks ceased to exist in 2000, splitting into two new parties: Sociaal-Liberale Partij and Nieuw-Vlaamse Alliantie (Nieuwe Vlaamse Alliantie, New Flemish Alliance). Both parties tried their luck in cartel with a bigger party, N-VA allying with the Christian Democrats of Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams, and Spirit with the Flemish socialists of Socialistische Partij Anders.\nThe cartel CD&V - N-VA emerged as the clear winner of the Belgian general election in June 2007 on a platform promising a far-reaching reform of the state. However, coalition negotiations with the French-speaking parties, who rejected any reform, proved extremely difficult. When the CD&V leader Yves Leterme was event able to form a government, his reform plans had been greatly dil and with the onset of the financial crisis in the a of 2008 they were shelved completely. This led N-VA to break up the cartel in September 2008, withdrawing its parliamentary st for the federal government (which was thus left without a parliamentary majority in Flanders, a sitn that is not stital but has been deemed irable by politicians and constital experts).\n\nThe role of Spirit, which represented the more left-leaning part of the former Volks, grad declined. After a series of defections, two cessful attempts to broaden its appeal (each time accompanied by a name change) and ending far below the 5% threshold in the Flemish regional elections of 2009, what was left of the party merged with Groen! (the Flemish green party) at the end of 2009.\n\nIn the Belgian general election of June 2010, N-VA became the leading party in Flanders and even in Belgium as a whole, polling 28% of the Flemish vote, dwarfing the senior partner of their former cartel, CD&V, which ended at an all-time low of 17.5%.<ref>http://verkiezingen2010.belgium.be/nl/ Verkiezingen2010.belgium.be  The enormous growth of N-VA is generally explained as ca by an influx of "moderate" Flemish voters who do not st the partys eventual aim of Flemish independence but do want consistent and far-reaching reforms with greater amy for the regions, something they no longer trust the traditional parties to be able to achieve.<ref> http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=F02RPIDA Standaard.be On the Walloon side, the Parti Socialiste (Belgium) (PS), led by Elio Di Rupo, received an even stronger electoral mandate with 37% of the vote. After the election, coalition negotiations started with seven parties: N-VA, CD&V, SP.a and Groen! on the Flemish side, and PS, Centre d\xe9mocrate hste (nominally Christian Democrat but very much left of centre) and the green party Ecolo on the Francophone side. The talks soon ran into serious diffics, mainly because of the totally opposed objectives of the two victors: the N-VA economically conservative but with a radical constital agenda, the PS socialist and very relt to agree to any significant reform of the state. The ens deadlock has led to what can be considered 2010-2011 Belgian government formation for a democratic nation. In the end, a coalition was formed by CD&V, SP.a, Vld on the Flemish side, and PS, CDH and Mont R\xe9formateur on the Walloon side. This coalition however does not contain a majority of the Flemish representatives, with only 43 of 88 Flemish seats sting it. This sitn has never happened since the split of the political parties into Flemish and Walloon wings, and it is ar how the Flemish voters will show st for this coalition in the next elections.\n\n\n*Bdian Netherlands\n*Dietsland\n*Flemish literature\n*French Flemish\n*Partition of Belgium\n*Politics of Flanders\n*Seventeen Provinces\n*Walloon movement\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Van geyt et al., The Flemish Movement, The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.1946; 247: 128-130\n* Vos Hermans, The Flemish Movement: A Docary History, 1780-1990, Continuum International Phing Group - Athlone (Feb 1992), ISBN 0-485-11368-6\n* Clough Shepard B., History of the Flemish Movement in Belgium: A study in nationalism, New York, 1930, 316 pp.\n* Ludo Simons (ed.), Nieuwe Encyclopedie van de Vlaamse Beweging, Lannoo, 1998, ISBN 978-90-209-3042-9\n* M. Row(id=469368, title=u'Solidarity (U.S.)', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n -->\n| ideology =  Revolary SocialismFeminism\n| headqrs = 7012 Michigan Ave, Detroit, MI 48210\n| international = \n| website = \n| co = United States\n\n\n\nSolidarity is a revolary socialist organization in the United States, associated with the jo Against the Ct. Solidarity is an organizational descendant of International Socialists (U.S.), an organization based on the proposition that the Soviet Union was not a "degenerate workers state" (as Trotskyists argue) but rather "bcratic collectivism", a new and especially repressive class society.<ref>\n\n\nSolidarity describes itself as "a democratic, revolary socialist, feminist, anti-racist organization."<ref>http://www.solidarity-us.org/ Solidarity | A democratic, revolary socialist, feminist, anti-racist organization official Web site. It comes out of the Trotskyist tradition but has departed from many aspects of traditional Leninist and Trotskyism. It is more loosely organized than most "democratic centralist" groups, and it does not see itself as the vangsm or the ns of a vang. It was formed in 1986 from a f of the International Socialists (US), Workers Power (US) and Socialist Unity (United States). The former two groups had recently been red in a single organization, while the last was a fragment of the Socialist Workers Party (United States) (SWP).  Solidaritys name was originally in part an homage to the Polish Solidarno\u015b\u0107 &mdash; Solidarno\u015b\u0107 had been an independent labor  which in Solidaritys view had challenged the Soviet Union from the left. As of the 2011 convention, Solidarity is a sympathizing organization of the Fo International. <ref>http://www.internationalviewpoint.org/spip.php?r Web site.\n\n\nFrom the beginning, Solidarity was an avowedly plst organization that incl several cts of Trotskyism, socialist feminism, and veterans of New Left groups. Solidarity so to "regroup" with others to create a large revolary socialist and feminist organization. They hoped to initiate a broad regrot that would include, for example, some of the fragments of the disintegrating New Comm Movement and many more socialist-feminists and New Left veterans. Discns of regrot and "Left Refoion" have been initiated between Solidarity and other left groups of varying tendencies from the 80s to the present, but these have not yet led to broader fs.\n\nSmaller-scale regrots have occ, however.  D the 1990s, two organizations f with Solidarity&mdash;the Fo Internationalist Tendency (a group expelled from the SWP) and Activists for Independent Socialist Politics (a Socialist Action (United States) split that had previo worked in Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism). In 2002, members of the Trotskyist League (US) joined Solidarity.\n\n\nSolidarity members work in various s for shop-floor militancy and rank-and-file democracy, and some have played key roles in maintaining and providing staff for Labor Notes magazine and Teamsters for a Democratic Union. Solidarity members have worked in many other mass movements in the US, incl the anti-Apartheid, reprode rights, LGBTQ, Central American solidarity, Free M, anti-war, and Global Je movements, as well as the Green Party (United States) and the Labor Party (United States, 1996). Since the inception of Occupy Wall Street and Occupy in other cities in the Fall of 2011, Solidarity members have been deeply involved. Solidarity prides itself on a "non-sectarian" approach to bng these movements, and traditionally has prioritized the movements over bng itself: "Too often socialist groups have seen the development of a movement not for what it is and can become, but only what it might offer in the way of recr. We reject this conception and affirm the need for an effective class movement in and for itself, which req new forms of action, thinking and dialogue rather than repeating the known form." -- Regrot & Refoion of a U.S. Left, <ref>http://www.solidarity-us.org/site/refog Web site. Solidarity phes a bi-monthly left jo, Against the Ct,<ref>http://www.solidarity-us.org/atc Against the Ct Web site. which is prod by an editorial board incl Solidarity members and independent socialists.\n\nIn 2000, Solidarity endorsed both the Green Partys Ralph Nader and Socialist Party USAs David McReynolds for President (Solidarity permits joint membership in the Socialist Party USA).  In A 2004 Solidarity again endorsed the candidacy of Ralph Nader.  In 2008 Solidarity endorsed Cynthia McKinney of the Green Party.<ref>"http://www.solidarity-us.org/node/1604 A Campaign with Issues", Against the Ct editorial, July/A 2008 (accessed 24 July 2008). In the 2010 midterm elections, Dan La Botz, a member of Solidarity, ran for a seat in the United States Senate  the banner of the Ohio Socialist Party<ref> This is a news release phed on a comm forum. and received 26,454 votes, or 0.69% of the total vote.\n\n\n\n\nCategory:Political parties established in 1986\nCategory:Fo International (post-recation)\nCategory:Trotskyist organizations in the Row(id=474383, title=u'Tourism in Argentina', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nFile:Argentina to regions.svg|thumb|To regions of Argentina:<ref name="to.gov.ar">http://www.to.gov.ar/eng/menu.htm Ministry of To of Argentina: Regions Argentine Northwest (orange), Mesopotamia, Argentina (light green), Cuyo (Argentina) (beige), C\xf3rdoba Province, Argentina|C\xf3rdoba (dark green), B Aires (consisting of B Aires City and B Aires Province; light blue) and Argentine Patagonia (dark blue)\n\nArgentina is provided with a vast territory and a huge variety of climates and microclimates ranging from t and polar climate in the south to the tropical climate in the north, through a vast expanse of temperate climate and nat wonders like the Aconcagua, the highest  mon in the world oe the Himalayas, the widest river and est of the planet (the R\xedo de la Plata), the huge and very mighty Iguaz\xfa Falls, some of the flattest and wide meadows-plains of planet Earth (as the H Pampas, a large ocean-sea coast in the Argentine Sea), Ce of Argentina, cs and Argentine ce famous internationally, a higher degree of development (very high compared to other Latin American coes), good qy of life and people, and relatively well prepared infrastre make this co one of the most visited of America.\n\nMainly for its beal landscapes and then for its cal heritage, Argentina receives massive amo of travelers. The Argentine territory stretches from the highest peaks of the Andes in the west to colita del norte rivers and extensive beaches and cliffs of Argentine Sea in the east; from the tropical rainforest of the Y north to the valleys, glaciers, lakes and Bosque Andino Patag\xf3nico of Andean Patagonia in the south, and to Argentine Antarctica. Through the warm landscapes of tropical climates contrasting, in a huge gradient microclimates, the polar climates or extensive and very fertile Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrdss with the World\xb4s most flatter plains contrasting with the highest mons oe Asia, contrasted with also vast desert areas plethoric of geoforms for the annual rg extensive and extreme Dakar Rally, the high mon ranges, the pleasant Sierras pampeanas and the temperate Atlantic beaches and its extensive coastlines. The huge distances req in most cases air travel. The Misiones rainforest, Argentine Y and areas of the Andean Patagonia are scientifically considered as biodiversity hotspots large areas worldwide. The great biodiversity and the large n of different landscapes and Climate of Argentinas make Argentina a diverse co where appear to meet mle coes together harmonio (fertile temperates, deserts, cold forest, warm tropicals and spical js, glacier areas, forests, maritimes with cliffs, rias and fjord s etc.).\n\nThe co presents entire range of possible climates: temperate, dry warm, h warm, cold dry, cold h, semi-arid, steppe, sarctic, spical, snowy, cold mon, and a huge variety of microclimates.\n\nArgentina has been ding its worldwide presence as a to destination by increasing the investment on international to. The latest push can be seen by Aerolineas Argentinas, the cos national airline, adding international ro from the United States and E. There are also r that they will join a major airline alliance soon.\n\nArgentina has enjoyed the visit of 5.80 million tos in the year 2011 according to the World To Organization, the first most visited co in South America and the second most visited of all of Latin America, after Mexico.<ref name="OMT2008">Volume 6 No. 2 Page 30\n\nForeign tos mainly come from Brazil, Chile, Ur, Paraguay, Bolivia, Peru, Ec, Colombia, Venez, Costa Rica, Mexico, Cuba, Dominican Rep, US, Canada, China, South Korea, Japan, Alia and Eans from Spain, Italy, France, Germany, United Kingdom, Ireland, Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Port and R.\n\n\nFile:9 de j (B Aires).JPG|thumb\n* City of B Aires is in the midst of a to boom, according to the World Travel & To Co,<ref name=rgi0708>http://www.wttc.travel/  www.wttc.travel Retrieved on 10 March 2008  it reveals strong growth for Argentina Travel and To in 2007<ref>http://www.wttc.travel/eng/News_and_Events/Press/Press_Releases_2007/WTTC_reveals_strong_growth_for_Argentina_Travel__and_To/ WTTC reveals strong growth for Argentina Retrieved on 10 March 2008 and in coming years,  and the prestigious travel and to pation; Travel + Leisure Magazine, a monthly pation leader in the world-wide market of travel magazines,  travelers voted B Aires the second most desirable city to visit after Florence, Italy.<ref>http://www.travelandleisure.com/worldsbest/2007/res.cfm?cat=cities  Travel +Leisure Magazine worldsbest/2007 Retrieved on 10 March 2008 B Aires, regarded as the \u201cParis of South America,\u201d offers elegant architecture, exqe ce,  legendary nightlife, and fashionable shopping.\n\nThe most pop to sites are found in the historic city core, comprising Montserrat, B Aires and San Telmo. The city was originally constr around the Plaza de Mayo, the administrative center of the Spanish Empire. To the east of the sq is the Casa Rosada, the official seat of the exec branch of the government of Argentina. To the north, the B Aires Metropolitan Cathedral which has stood in the same location since colonial times, and the Banco de la Naci\xf3n Argentina bng, a parcel of land originally owned by Juan de Garay. Other important colonial instits were B Aires Cabildo, to the west, which was renovated d the constrn of Avenida de Mayo and J A. Roca. To the south is the Congreso de la Naci\xf3n (National Congress), which ctly ho the Academia Nacional de la Historia (National Academy of History). Lastly, to the northwest, is City Hall.\n\nAvenida de Mayo links the Casa Rosada with the Argentine National Congress. On this avenue there are several bngs of cal, architect and historical importance, such as Casa de la Ca (B Aires), the Palacio Barolo and Caf\xe9 Tortoni. Underneath the avenue, the first s (metro) Line A (B Aires Metro)   in South America, was opened in 1913. The avenue ends at Congressional Plaza, which feat a n of mons and scres, incl one of Ae Rodins few sing original casts of "The Thinker."\n\nThe w:es:Manzana de las L ("Illted Block") area feat the San Ignacio ch, the Colegio Nacional de B Aires, and the old city co bng (1894 to 1931). This area feat ts and catacombs, which crossed neath the Plaza de Mayo d colonial times.\nIn the neighbod of San Telmo, Plaza Dorrego hosts an antiques fair on Ss, complete with tango (dance) shows. They also have tango shows daily at the famous plaza. On weekends they involve many tos to learn how to dance. Freq tours and activities are also available at the Ch of Na Se\xf1ora de Bethlehem, the San Pedro Telmo Parish and the Antonio Ballv\xe9 Penintetiary M. The M Hist\xf3rico Nacional de Argentina in Parque Lezama is a few blocks south. The Ayres Porte\xf1os Hostel is a very famous hostel and a to attraction, it is decorated and painted by artists from La Boca and possesses a e collection of local paintings among its walls.\n\nThe borough of Recoleta, B Aires is home to a n of places of interest, incl the M Nacional de Bellas Artes (B Aires), the Biblioteca Nacional de la Rep\xfablica Argentina, the Centro Cal Recoleta, the Fac of Law of the Universidad de B Aires, the Bas\xedlica Na Se\xf1ora de Pilar, the Palais de Glace, the Caf\xe9 La Biela and the Cementerio de la Recoleta, where Eva Per\xf3ns crypt can be visited, among those of many other Argentine historical and cal fig.\n* Iguaz\xfa Falls, located in the northeast, area of spical Paran\xe1 forest, on the border with Brazil are one of the worlds nat wonders, has good infrastre development and toic with very different walks. Lined with dense forests, the Iguaz\xfa river flows into 275 waterfalls, plg more than 70 meters with a deafening noise over 2.7&nbsp;km. As this huge volume of water reaches the bottom, spray rises, and rainbows are formed in the sky. A variety of the original fauna and flora completes the setting for the waterfalls within the protection of the Iguaz\xfa National Park. This park, located at eighteen kilometres from P Iguaz\xfa, was declared World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The famous falls are inside this park. The frontier with Brazil goes through the Garganta del Diablo (Devils Throat). The National Park is full of the exotic spical vegetation which snds the falls and has 2,000 plant species - gigantic trees, ferns, lianas, orchids, - 400 bird species - parrots, hgbirds, to - jag and yacar\xe9s (caimans) from the area. Its most impressive fall is called Ig Falls. Other important are called Dos Hermanas, Bossetti or \xc1lvar N\xfa\xf1ez in honor of its discoverer, \xc1lvar N\xfa\xf1ez Cabeza de Vaca.\n\nFile:Salta - Convento de San Francisco - Noct.jpg|thumb|Basilica and Convent of San Francisco (Salta) in Salta, with the highest ch bell of South America\nFile:Vi\xf1edoCafayate.jpg|thumb|left|Vineyard in Cafayate, Province of Salta\n* Salta is a city of colonial architecture with to attractions such asch as: Qda de San Lorenzo, Calchaqu\xed Valleys, Reservoir Cabra Corral (Embalse General Belgrano), Cafayate, Salinas Grandes (J and Salta), Iruya (step bound by the Qda de Haca and Parca) Cachi, Argentina (through the C del Obispo) Molinos, Salta, La Caldera, Los Cardones National Park, El Rey National Park or Barit\xfa National Park|Barit\xfa National Pand tae hrk, hot springs of Rosario de la Frontera.
