Row(id=519163, title=u'Bengali cuisine', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\nBengali ce is a cry style originating in Bengal, a region in the eastern part of the Indian stinent, which is now divided between Bangladesh and West Bengal state of India. Other regions, such as Tripura, and the Barak Valley region of Assam (in India) also have large native Bengali people popons and share this ce. With an emphasis on fish, vegetables and lentils are served with rice as a staple diet. Bengali ce is known for its s (yet sometimes fiery) flavours, and its spread of confectioneries and desserts. It also has the only traditionally developed m-co tradition from the stinent that is analogous in stre to the modern service \xe0 la r style of French ce ce, with food served co-wise rather than all at once.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe partition of Bengal (1947) following independence from the British in 1947 separated West Bengal from Bangladesh. This ca a significant change in demographics; popons were divided along religious lines, and over three million people were Partition of India#Independence and popon exchanges the new Bengal border in either direction. This large-scale displacement along religious lines led to some changes of food, because there were differences in food habits between the Ms and the Hindus. However, large popons of each religion remained on either side of the border.\n\nThere was one major divergence, though. The newly formed West Bengal was a small state in India dominated by the city of Kolkata. This city came into prominence as the original capital of British India and qy became one of the largest and richest in the world, completely overshadowing the original city of Dhaka.\n\n\n\nThe treatment of Hindu widows has always been highly repressive. Tradition ties a womans identity to her hd; a widow is therefore left without an identity, property rights or social standing. Bengal was particy repressive in this regard; widows were either banished or led highly monastic lives within the hold, living  rigid dietary restrictions and not allowed any interests but religion and hork. The nineteenth century saw active widow reform movements in Bengal\u2014the ban on Sati (practice) in 1829 and the Hindu Widow Re-marriage Act of 1856 were key milestones\u2014but the related social practices took a long while to die out and still remain in part. and low life expectancies left many women widowed \u2013 it is estimated that 25% of holds have a widow living in them. Widows were not allowed to leave the house, so their contrib to the hold was ly restricted to the kitchen\u2014creating a e class of chefs in the dominant Hindu comm.\n\nWhile most Bengali castes ate meat and fish, this was barred for widows. Widows also did not use "heating" foods such as shallot and garlic, but ginger was allowed\u2014this found a core place in Bengali cs, both vegetarian and non-vegetarian. Expensive spices such as saffron, cinnamon or cloves were  very sparingly if at all; nuts, dry fr, milk and milk prod (such as cream, ghee or curd) were similarly scarce. In spite of all these restrictions, however, the food evolved in such a way that its deceptively simple preparations drew  Bengals vast larder of vegetable options and were often elaborate to the point of fess. Cooked with elaborate precision and served with equal refinement\u2014mle co and an intricate formality about what goes with what and in which seq\u2014it formed an end base for a rich and varied ce. Leftover cuts in partic, such as spinach ends or vegetable peel, are transformed. Chitrita Banerji in her book q a nineteenth-century Bengali writer mentioning that "it was impossible to taste the full glory of vegetarian cooking s your own wife became a widow".\n\n\n\nFile:Bengali meal.jpg|thil|left\nFile:Bengali Fish meal.jpg|thil\n\nThe traditional society of Bengal has always been heavily agrarian society; hg, except by some local clansmen, was mon. Rice is the staple, with many regions growing speciality rice varieties. Domestic cattle (especially the water bo) are common, more for agrice than large scale dairy farming. Milk is an important so of nion, and also a key ingredient in Bengals desserts. Ordinary food served at home is different from that served d social fons and festivals, and again very different from what might be served at a larger gathering (e.g., a marriage feast).\n\nNearly every Bengali comm eat meat or fish. In most parts of the Indian stinent, individual castes and commes have their own food habits; this is not true of Bengal. There is similarity in eating styles across social strata, with the Hindu  caste Brahmins sharing a diet very similar to the trading or princely castes. Fish, goat, m and chicken are commonly eaten across social strata. Beef and pork also are available throt the state.\n\nThe nature and variety of dishes found in Bengali cooking are e even in India. Fresh sweet water fish is one of its most distinctive feat; Bengals rivers, ponds and lakes contain varieties of fish such as rohu, ilish, koi or pabda. Prawns, shrimp and crabs also abound. Almost every village in Bengal has ponds  for piscice, and at least one meal a day is certain to have a fish co.\n\nBengalis also excel in the cooking of regional vegetables. They prepare a variety of the dishes  the many types of vegetables that grow there year-round. They can make ambrosial dishes out of the oftentimes rejected peels, stalks and leaves of vegetables. This style of cooking food  rejected parts of the vegetables, is predominant in Bengalis in Bangladesh and those who have migrated to West Bengal, in they use fuel-efficient methods, such as steaming fish or vegetables in a small covered bowl nestled at the top of the rice pot.\n\nThe use of spices for both fish and vegetable dishes is q extensive and incl many combinations not found in other parts of India. Examples are the onion-flavo kalonji (nigella or black onion seeds), radhuni (wild celery seeds), and five-spice or panch phoron (a mixture of c, fennel, fenk, kalonji, and black md seeds). Bengali cooking incl the phoron of a combination of whole spices, fried and added at the start or finish of cooking as a flavo special to each dish. Bengalis share their use of whole black md seeds with South Indians, but e to Bengal is the extensive use of freshly ground md paste. A pt md paste called Kash is a dipping sauce pop in Bengal.\n\nPiper chaba is a flowering vine in the family Piperaceae Chui Jhal is originally the twig of a Piper chaba. It is a very expensive spice in Bangladesh, and tastes like horse radish. People in Kh, Bagerhat and Shatkhira cut down the stem, roots, peel the skin and cut it in to small pieces and cook them with meat and fishes, especially with m.\n\n\nFish is the dominant kind of protein in Bengali ce and is cated in ponds and fished with nets in the freshwater rivers of the Ganges Delta. Almost every part of the fish (except scales, fins, and innards) is eaten; e other regions, the head is particy preferred. Other spare bits of the fish are ly  to flavour cs and dals.\n\nMore than forty types of mostly freshwater fish are common, incl carp varieties like rui (rohu), koi (Anabas testus), tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus), bhetki (Barram),Catla (Catla catla),  the wriggling catfish family\u2014tangra, magur,sole (Solea solea), shingi\u2014pabda (the pink-bellied Indian b fish), catla, ilish (ilish),pomflet (Bramidae), as well as shu\u0163ki (small or large dried sea fish). Chingri (prawn) is particy pop and comes in varieties\u2014k (tiny shrimp), bagda (tiger prawns) or galda (Scampi).\n\nFile:Fried Rohu in Bangladesh.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Fried rohu served in Dhaka, Bangladesh.\nThe salt water fish Ilish is very pop among Bengalis. Ilish (ilish fish), which migrates eam to breed is a delicacy; the varied salt content at different stages of the jo is of partic interest to the connoisseur, as is the river from which the fish comes\u2014fish from the river Padma|P\xf4dda (Padma or Lower Ganges) in Bangladesh, for example, is traditionally considered the best.\n\nFile:Smoked Hilsa cooked with Md seeds.jpg|thumb|left|190px|Shorshe Ilish, a dish of smoked ilish with Md seed paste, has been an important part of both Bangladeshi ce\nThere are nus ways of cooking fish, depending on the texture, size, fat content and the bones. It could be fried, cooked in roasted, a simple spicy tomato or ginger based gravy (jhol/jhul), or md based with green chillies (shorshe batar jhal), with posto, with seasonal vegetables, steamed, steamed inside of plantain or bnut sq leaves, cooked with doi (curd/yogurt), with sour sauce, with sweet sauce or the fish can be made to taste sweet on one side, and savoury on the other. Ilish is said be cooked in 108 distinct ways.\n\n\nFile:BengaliP.JPG|thumb|Bengali Pilaf\nFile:Bengali Peas P with M Masala - Traditional Bengali Style.jpg|thumb|right|Bengali peas Pilaf with M Masala\nFile:Deep Fried Capsicum & Chicken 7761.JPG|thil|left\n\nThe most preferred form of meat in Bengal is m or goat meat. Khashi (castrated goat) or kochi pantha (kid goat) are the common forms of goat meat taken. Some delicate dishes are cooked with rewaji khashi, a goat that has been specifically raised on a sing kind of diet, to enco the growth of intramar fat, commonly known as pardah. Pork is commonly eaten among the Santal tribes, the people in the Darjeeling district, and is q common on the menus of Chinese restas in Kolkata. Chicken is also preferred, though it has grown steadily in popty over the last few decades after the advent of po farming. Beef, though not as pop as in Bangladesh, is still vastly cons in West Bengal, especially in Kolkata, either in continental form or in mi form. Eggs\u2014both chicken and duck\u2014are q pop. Duck meat is q often found on menus in West Bengal, mostly Chinese restas, even though the birds are common in the many ponds and lakes. T meat, Emu meat, Q meat and Rabbit meat are also available to buy raw and the delicacies of these meats are pop in the food joints of Park Street area in Kolkata.\n\nSpecial Dishes of Dhaka: The Nawab of Dhaka were not the original Nawabs of Bengal. Their ancestors came from Kashmir as merchants who made their fort in Eastern Bengal in the 17th century. They finally settled in Dhaka, and, having bo large landed estates, they became the largest landowners in these parts. They were given the title of Nawab by the British.\n\nThe Nawabs bro many famous babs ("cooks") from many parts of India who introd many new dishes, especially meat dishes, to the local ce. Admittedly, these expensive dishes were hardly enjoyed by the common people. They remained the favo of the wealthy and the well-to-do aristocrats. However, with the general economic growth of Dhaka since 1971, some of them have become favorites of the rich classes especially on such festive occasions as Eid and marriages. They are:\n\nKebabs: There are many kinds of kebabs, mostly cooked over open grill. Some of the Dhakas specialty of this genre are: S Kebab, Bihari Kebab, Boti Kebab, etc., made from marinaded (by secret spice mix by each chef) m and beef. Kebabs are eaten as snacks or as starters for a big feast. Special kinds of breads: There are many kinds of breads made with cheese mix, with minced meat, with special spices, etc., all are delicacies enjoyed by the affl classes as side dishes.\n\nThe M Biriyani: This famous dish is now the mainstay speciality of the Bengali ce, especially in Kolkata. It is cooked with basmati rice and <nowiki>pakki"</nowiki> (pre-cooked) goat-m pieces . When on dum, i.e., steamed in a sealed pot over a slow wood fire or charcoal to impart a smokey-flavour, simeo cooking both rice and m. Spices such as saffron, n and star anise are employed chefs of this special dish.\n\nWhole goat roasted: Marinated whole Goat meat is roasted over charcoal fire. This dish is ly made on special occasion such as marriage feast when ly it is served on the high table reserved for the bridegroom and his party.\n\nWhole roasted chicken/duck: Highly spiced, cooked in a pot with lots of ghee.\n\nSpecial dishes meant for festive occasion: There are some delicacies that are enjoyed occasionally by the wealthy people. These are: game birds, t, rabbit or venison cooked in spicy sauce. However, the rare (mostly migratory) birds and ts and deer being protected by law, this is on the decline. However, pigeons, g fowls, My d, etc., are still eaten as hobby food by some peoples. Ts are still sold at many places although this is illegal.\n\n\n\nFile:Green Jackfruit & Potato C - Kolkata 2011-02-11 1000.JPG|thumb|right|250px\n<!--File:Chanar dalna - Kolkata 2011-09-20 5426.JPG|thil|left-->\nFile:Caowers Potatoes C - Kolkata 2011-11-16 7090.JPG|thil|left\nFile:Pointed Gourd C - Kolkata 2011-09-20 5428.JPG|thil\n\nThere are go, roots and t, leafy greens, sent stalks, lemons and limes, green and p aine, shallots, plantain, broad beans, okra, banana tree stems and flowers, green jackfruit and red pns in the vegetable markets or shobji bajar. Bitter vegetables like bitter melon/gourd ("" or "korola") and nim leaves are . Bengalis are particy fond of  leftover bits of vegetables. Peels, roots, stems and other bits that are ly disposed of are eaten in Bengal.\n\n\n\nFile:L.jpg|thil\n\nBengali people are primarily rice eaters, and the rainfall and soil in Bengal lends itself to rice prodn as well. Many varieties of rice are prod from the long grain fragrant varieties to small grain thick ones. Rice is semi-prepared in some cases when it is sold as parboiled, or in some cases as ished as well, still retaining the colour of the husk. Rice is eaten in various forms as well\u2014p, beaten, boiled and fried depending on the meal. The first two are  ly as snacks and the other as the main constit in a meal. Lightly fermented rice is also  as breakfast in r and agrarian commes (panta bhat).\n\nL (circ, deep-fried vened bread) or Porothha (ly triang, m-layered, pan fried, vened bread) are also  as the primary food item on the table. It is considered that wheat-based food came in from the north and is relatively new in advent. Both L and Parothha could have st versions as well, and the stg could vary from dal, peas, etc.\n\nP (or lentils) form another important ingredient of a meal. These dals vary from m dal|\u0111al (red lentils), mug \u0111al (mung beans), kadhaier dal, arhar dal, etc., and are  as an accompaniment to rice.\n\n\nFile:Bengali spices.JPG|thumb\nFile:Md Oil & Seeds - Kolkata 2003-10-31 00537.JPG|thil|left\nFile:Bengali cooking tools.JPG|thumb|266px\n\nShorsher tel (md oil) is the primary cooking medium in Bengali ce although Badam tel (grot oil) is also , because of its high smoke point. Of late, the use of swer oil, soybean oil and refined vegetable oil, which is a mixture of soybean, kardi, and other edible vegetable oils, is gaining prominence. This later group is popy known as "shada tel", meaning white oil, bringing out the contrast in colour between the lightly colo grot and the somewhat darker md oil and the other white oils. However, depending on type of food, ghee (clarified b) is often , e.g., for making the dough or for frying bread.\n\nMd (condiment) paste, holud (tic), poshto (poppyseed),  ada (ginger), dhone (coriander, seeds and leaves) and narikel (ripe coconut ly desiccated) are other common ingredients. The panch phoron is a general pe spice mixture composed of radhuni (Carum roxbanum seeds), jira (c), kalo jira (black c, also known as nigella), methi (fenk) and mouri (aniseed). This mixture is more convenient for vegetarian dishes and fish preparations. Panch phoron is also referred to as Bengali five spice mixture.\n\n\nAnother characteristic of Bengali food is the use of a cg instr, the boti (also called the dao in some regional dialects). South Indians also use the same sort of cg instr, where it is called katti peeta. It is a long c blade on a platform held down by foot; both hands are  to hold whatever is being cut and move it against the blade. The method gives effective control over the cg process, and can be  to cut anything from tiny shrimp to large pns. Knives are rare in a traditional Bengali kitchen.\n\nFile:Bengali kitchen ils.JPG|thumb|left|284px\nA korai (wok) is a rsal cooking vessel for most Bengali food, for making sa, frying/stir-frying, etc. The dekchi (a flat-bottomed pan) is  generally for larger amo of cooking or for making rice. The dekchi comes with a thin flat lid which is  also to strain out the starch while finishing up cooking rice. The other prominent cooking il is a handi, which is a round-bottomed pot-like vessel. The three mentioned vessels all come in various sizes and in various metals and alloys. The tawa is  to make roti and paratha.\n\nSilverware is not a part of traditional Bengali cookery. A flat metal spatula, kh, is  often, along with hata (scoop with a long handle), jhanjri (round-shaped sieve-like spatula to deep-fry food), the shanrashi (pincers to remove vessels from the fire), the gh (wooden hand blender) for pur\xe9eing dal, the old wooden belun chaki (round pastry board and rolling pin), and the shil nora, which is a rough form of a mortar and pestle or grinding stone. The k is a sker, there to grate coconuts.\n\n\nFile:Boti with coconut grater.JPG|thumb|On the left, a coconut grater known as k and on the right a boti, a type of chopper or cg tool  to cut the vegetables, fish, meat, etc.\nBengali ce is rather partic in the way vegetables and meat (or fish) are prepared before cooking. Some vegetables are  led, in some preparations fish is  nned in contrast as well. However, in most dishes vegetables are peeled, and fish scaled and skinned.\n\nIn many cases, the main ingredients are lightly marinated with salt and tic (an anti-bacterial and antiseptic). Vegetables are to be cut in different ways for different preparations. Dicing, jne, strips, scoops, slices, shreds are common and one type of cut vegetables cannot replace another style of cg for a partic preparation. Any aberration is frowned . For example, in alu-k chhakka, the potatoes and go must be diced, not shredded; if they are shredded it is called ghonto and not chhakka.\n\n\n\nBengali ce has evolved with the infl of M ce, Anglo Indian ce, Chinese ce and so on. Some characteristics stand out: great n of rivers and its tribes providing freshwater fish, flat and fertile land prod abce of paddy(Rice) and P(lentil), domestic cattle and dairy farming providing milk, beef (mainly non-Hindus) and m, all soil prod variety of fr and vegetables. Moreover, use of different spices has added to the flavour and taste of Bengali food. Ceremonial food diffees from the daily food. While daily food consists mainly of rice/roti(handmade bread), fish, lentil(dal), meat, vegetables etc.,in different occasions and festivals, g are entertained with different kind of Polao or Biryani, Chicken korma, beef kalia, Kebab, borhani, firni, jorda or different sweet dishes etc. A significant feature of the ce is a significant variety of sweets based on milk and s as part of tradition. Wheat is  alongside rice, in different types of breads, such as l, kochuri and p\xf4ro\u0163a. Special ce are also prepared in different seasons; for example, in winter, both  and r areas prepare various kinds of Pitha (Cakes like  bhapa pitha, phul pitha,  telerpitha, patishapta and taler bora) and Payesh/ khir (a special kind of dessert made of milk, rice, s/gur and spices) are prepared.\n\nProsperity and isation also led to the widespread use of professional cooks who introd complex spice mixt and more elaborate sa, along with techniques, such as roasting or braising. Also introd around this time, probably as a conseq of increased isation, was a new class of snack foods. These snack foods are most often cons with evening tea. The tea-time ritual was probably inspired by the British, but the snacks most pop are Shingara,dalpuri, samosa,peyaji,beguni, ph, chop, p rice (popy known as Muri), halim etc. Chatpati is one of the most pop street foods of Bangladesh.\n\n\n\nThe following are a list of characteristic Bengali recipe styles. There are Chinese, Sost Asian, and Be infls in the food of Bengal, as well as some British infl, because of the formation of Kolkata d the 1700s. Each entry here is a class of recipes, prod different dishes depending on the choice of ingredients. There are six different tastes to which the Bengali palate caters to, sweet, sour, salty, bitter, hot and koshay.\n\n*Ombol or Aum-bol (also known as Tok) : A sour dish made either with several vegetables or fish, especially fish bones. The so agent is ly tamarind pulp, e mango and sometimes Indian gooseberry or amloki is . Curd, though a so agent occasionally  with non-vegetarian dishes, will not be called ombol. It is served at the end of the meal as a kind of digestive, and to cleanse the palate.\n*Alu-dum: Heat oil and fry the potato and then put oil and fry onion and ginger-ggarlic paste and give all other spices and when the onion get brown put the fry potatoes on it, give some water and put the lead off  the potatoes get boiled.\n*Achar: Pickles. Generally flavo with md oil, md seeds, aniseed, caraway seed and asafoetida, or hing.\n*Bora: Anything that has been mashed and then formed into rough roh shape and fried, generally in md oil. Generally served with rice as a starter, or served with p rice crisps as a snack. The bora has q a few different kinds. When potatoes are fried in a light chickpea flour batter, they are called f (giving rise to the Trinidadian pholo)\n*Bhaja: Anything fried, either just after it has been salted or dipped in any kind of water-based batter. Does not include croqs, or crumb-coated items.\n*Bhapa: Fish or vegetables steamed with spices.\n*Bhate: A vegetable, that has been put inside the pot in which rice is cooking, and it has been cooked along with the rice. Generally, you get potatoes, bnut sq, raw papayas, bitter gourd, snake gourd and okra in the rice. Bengalis often eat it with a tinge of md oil and salt. However, a very pop one-dish Bengali meal is alu bhate bhat, which is potatoes boiled along with rice, and then served along with the rice. For this, generally gobindobhog atop rice, which is a short-grained, glus rice that cooks qy, is , and is preferred to the long-grained rice, because of its creamy qy, and ability to become ever so sticky, which aids the dish when it comes to mashing. D the serve, some fresh ghee or b, and salt to taste, to be mixed and mashed by hand into the right consistency, and then eaten. A raw green chili, and a boiled and shelled egg sometimes accompanies this dish.\n*Bhorta: Any vegetable, such as potatoes, beans, sour mangoes, papaya, pns or even dal, first boiled whole and then mashed and seasoned with red shallot, fresh chile, md oil/ghee and spices.\n*Chorchori: Us a vegetable dish with one or more varieties of vegetables cut into longish strips, sometimes with the stalks of leafy greens added, all lightly seasoned with spices like md or poppy seeds and flavo with a po. Sometimes a chochchori may have small shrimp. The skin and bones of large fish like bhetki or chitol can be made into a chochchori called kata-chochchori (kata meaning fish-bone). The stir frying process and the lightness of a chochhori is not e that of chop suey, which is a term for assorted pieces, and this shows the infl of the Chinese in Bengali hold cooking. The chochhori would be generally an assortment of vegetable and fish bones and other things that would have been rather thrown away, fried in a korai,(a slightly ro wok), over high heat at first, and then simmered to let the vegetables cook down to being just done, and then taken off the flame immediately to stop cooking. The cooking procedure adds to the confirmation of the entrance of Chinese style of cooking into Kolkata d the mid-1800s, prior to which this partic dish was not very pop in Bengali ce.\n*Chop: Croqs, ly coated with cr biscuit or breadcr.\n*C: Very different from the cs of the Brits, this is referred typically to a crumb-coated, thinly spread out dough, made generally of chicken/m minced, mixed together with shallot, bread cr and chillies. Generally it is then dipped in egg and coated in breadcrumb, fried and served with thin jne of cer, carrots, radish and shallot. Often an egg mixed with a teaspoon or two water and a pinch of salt is dropped on top of the frying c, to make it into a kabiraji, the Bengali prontion of a "Coverage or Cover:Egg" C, infld by the British.\n*Chhyanchra: A combination dish made with different vegetables, portions of fish head and fish oil (entrails).\n*Chhenchki: Tiny pieces of one or more vegetable, generally a dice of vegetables along with general odds and ends, often even the peels (of potatoes, sq, gourd, pn, bitter gourd, or potol for example)\u2014ly flavo with pach-phoron, whole md seeds or kalo jira. Chopped shallot and garlic can also be , but hardly any ground spices.\n*Ch: Generally Bengal is one of the pioneers for this partic dish, making it with everything, incl preserved mango sheets, called amshotto.\n*Dalna: Mixed vegetables or eggs, cooked in a medium thick gravy seasoned with ground spices, especially gorom moshla and a touch of ghee.\n*Dom: Vegetables, especially potatoes, or meat, cooked over a covered pot containing water, slowly over a low heat, slightly steaming. The word is derived from the dum technique pop in Mi food.\n*Dolma/Dorma: A vegetable, potol, st with fish boiled, de-boned, then prepared with Bengali five-spice powder, ginger and shallot (alternately coconut-vegetable stg is ).  A mixture of poppy seeds, grated coconut, raisins or shrimp is commonly  for stg. D the times of the M r, (who were known as the Nawabs of Bengal), this dish came to the region with its Th name, with the only noticeable change being the vegetable  for stg.\n*Ghonto: Different complementary vegetables (e.g., cabbage, green peas, potatoes or banana blossom, coconut, chickpeas) are chopped or finely grated and cooked with both a phoron and ground spices. Dried pellets of dal are often added to the ghonto. Ghee is commonly added at the end. Non-vegetarian ghontos are also made, with fish or fish heads added to vegetables. The famous monto is made with fish heads cooked in a fine variety of rice. Some ghontos are very dry while others are thick and j.\n*Jhal: Literally, hot. A great favo in Bengali holds, this is made with fish or shrimp or crab, first lightly fried and then cooked in a light sauce of ground red chilli or ground md and a flavo of pach-phoron or kalo jira. Being dryish, it is often eaten with a little bit of dal po over the rice.\n*Jhol: A light fish or vegetable stew seasoned with ground spices, like ginger, c, coriander, chilli, and tic, with pieces of fish and longitl slices of vegetables floating in it. The gravy is thin yet extremely flavo. Whole green chillies are ly added at the end and green coriander leaves are  to season for extra taste. It is the closest to a "c", yet it is more of a jus than a sauce.\n*Kalia: A very rich preparation of fish, meat or vegetables  a lot of oil and ghee with a sauce ly based on ground ginger and fresh shallots pasted or fried along with a tempering of gorom moshla.\n*Kofta (or Boras): Ground meat or vegetable croqs bound together by spices or eggs served alone or in savoury gravy. Koftas are ly softer than boras which are mainly made of ground lentils, sometimes with added chopped vegetables. Telebhaja is different.\n*Korma: A term that can also be called q, of Mi origin, meaning meat or chicken cooked in a mild yogurt-based sauce with ghee instead of oil; poppy seed paste is often added to it. People of son Bangladesh are known to add coconut milk to many of their dishes and korma is no exception.\n*Kosha: Meaning fried for a long time with ground and whole spices over high heat  shallot/garlic/ginger have dissolved into a thick paste. Us applied to meat and some shellfish.\n*Paturi: Generally oily fish is sliced evenly, and then wrapped in a banana leaf, after the fish has been hit by a basting of freshly pasted md with a hint of md oil, chili, tic and salt.\n*Pora: Literally, b. Vegetables are wrapped in leaves and roasted over a wood or charcoal fire. Some, like aine, are put directly over the flames. Before eating the roasted vegetable is mixed with oil and spices.\n*Poshto: anything cooked with poppy seed paste as the main flavo agent. Often poppy seed paste with some md oil is eaten mixed with rice all by itself as a mild beginner for any Bengali meal.\n*Torkari: A general term often  in Bengal the way `c is  in English. The word first meant ked garden vegetables. From this it was a nat extension to mean cooked vegetables or even fish and vegetables cooked together.\n*Sh: A favo Bengali palate cleanser, made with a lot of different vegetables incl at least one bitter veg, simmered with a hint of s and milk to bring out the bitterness of the fresh vegetables.\n*Shak: Any kind of green leafy vegetable, like spinach and md greens, often cooked till just wilted in a touch of oil and tempering of nigela seeds.\n\n\nBengali food today has some broad (though not so distinct) traditional variations.\n\n\nIslam arrived in Bengal probably around the mid-thirteenth century, coming into force with the penetration of the M r from the northwest. Dhaka (the present-day capital of Bangladesh), in partic, expanded greatly  M rule. The partition of India in 1947 res in a large migration of people to and from present-day Bangladesh, resg in a much stronger divide along religious lines. Bangladesh today shows a much greater M infl than West Bengal.\nFile:Food-M-Chaanp.jpg|thumb|right\nThe infl on the food was from the top down, and more gradual than in many other parts of India. This led to a e ce where even commoners ate the dishes of the royal court, such as biryani, korma and bhuna. The infl was reinforced in the British Raj era, when Kolkata became the place of refuge for many prominent exiled Nawabs, especially the family of Tipu S from Kingdom of Mysore and Wajid Ali Shah, the o Nawab of Awadh. The exiles bro with them hds of cooks and masalchis (spice mixers), and as their royal patronage and wealth diminished, they became interspersed into the local popon. These cooks came with the knowledge of a very wide range of spices (most notably jafran (saffron) and mace (spice)), the extensive use of ghee as a method of cooking, and special ways of marinating meats.\nFile:Food-M-Rezala.jpg|thumb|right\nIn Bangladesh, this food has over time become the staple food of the pop. In West Bengal, however, this has remained, more than the other categories, the food of professional chefs; the best examples are still available at restas. Specialties include chap (ribs slow cooked on a Tava), rezala (meat in a thin yogurt and cardamom gravy) and the famous kathi roll (kebabs in a wrap). The local popon absorbed some of the ingredients and techniques into their daily food, resg in meat-based varieties of many traditional vegetarian dishes, but the foods remained largely distinct.\n\nThe M infl is most distinct in preparations involving meat, especially m. However, even chicken and other meats became more prevalent. The infl was also seen in desserts; traditional desserts were based on rice pastes and jaggery but  the M infl moved towards significantly increased use of milk, cream and s along with expensive spices such as cardamom and saffron.\n\n\nFile:Chicken Kabiraji C - Kolkata 2013-12-15 5382.JPG|thumb\nAnglo-Indian food is not p the result of the infl of the British; Bengal was once the home of a French colony, and also hosted popons of Porte, D and other Eans. These collective western infls are seen in the foods created to satisfy the tastes of the western r. The result is a e ce, local ingredients adapted to French and Italian ce cooking techniques\u2014characterised by creamy sa, the restrained use of spices, and new techniques such as baking. English and Jewish bakers such as Flurys and Nahoums dominated the confectionery ind which migrated from British tables to everyday Bengali ones, resg in e creations such as the p\xea\u0163is (savory ters, from the English "pasty"). Another end contrib to Bengali ce is pau ru\u0163i, or Western-style bread. Raj-era ce lives on especially in the variety of finger foods popsed in the p clubs of Kolkata, such as m chop, kabiraji c or fish orly.\n\nThe British also infld food in a somewhat different way. Many British families in India hired local cooks, and through them discovered local foods. The foods had to be toned down or modified to suit the tastes of the "Sahib#Colonial and modern use". The most distinct infl is seen in the desserts, many of which were created specifically to satisfy the British\u2014most notably the very pop sweet le\u0111ikeni named after the first Vicereine Lady Canning; it is a derivative of the pantua created for an event hosted by her.\n\n\nFile:Bangladeshi style home-made beef chow mein.jpg|thumb\nFile:Pork Roll - Sun Yat-sen Street - Kolkata 2013-03-03 5307.JPG|thil\n\nThe Chinese of Kolkata originally settled into a village called Achipur south of Kolkata in the late 18th century, later moving into the city and finally into its present home in Tangra, Calc at the eastern edge of Kolkata. The Chinese-origin people of Kolkata form a sntial and ssful comm with a distinct identity. With this identity came Chinese food, available at almost every street corner in Kolkata at present, due to the taste, q cooking procedure, and no similarity with the original Chinese recipe other than the use of soy sauce. They were mostly Cantonese people tradesmen and sailors who first settled down here and decided to cook with whatever items they had at hand.\n\nThe infl of this e syncretic ce cannot be overstated; it is available in every town in India and Bangladesh as "Chinese" food. Bengali immigrants to other coes have started carrying this abroad as well; Indian Chinese restas have appeared in many places in the United States and UK.\n\nIndian Chinese food was given a second boost when a large n of Tibetans migrated into Indian Territory, following the 14th Dalai Lamas flight. Tibetans bro with them their own delicacies to add to this genre, such as the very pop Momo (food) (a kind of dng) or th (a hearty noodle soup). Tibetans and Nepali immigrants also found ready employment in kitchens as "Chinese" cooks because of their looks, and helped power the millions of eateries that serve this e f on virt every street in Kolkata. The chop suey became a favorite, and versions like "American chop suey" and "Chinese chop suey" were constantly talked about.\n\n\n\n\nFile:Macher Jhol.JPG|thumb|250px|A traditional Bengali fish meal \u2013 Rice with Macher Jhol (Literally translated to "Fishs gravy").\nThe medium of cooking is md oil which adds on its own pcy. Another very important item of Bengali ce is the variety of sweets or mishti as they call them. Most of them are milk-based and are prepared from chhana (paneer as it is popy known). The most pop among the Bengali sweets are the Roshogolla, Shondesh, Pantua and Mishti Doi and these four sweets are deemed essential at every wedding besides some other sweets, which may vary as per individual choice. A meal, for the Bengali, is a ritual in itself even only boiled rice and lentils (dal bhat), with a little fish. Bengalis, like the French, spend not only the great deal of time thinking about the food but also on its preparation and eating. Q like "Bengalis live to eat" and "Bengalis spend most of their income on food" are not exactly exaggerated. The early morning shopping for fresh vegetables, fish etc. is the prerogative of the head of the family, even in affl hold, because he feels that he alone can pick up the best at a bargain price. The Bengalis are very partic about the way and the order in which the food should be served. Each dish is to be eaten separately with a little rice so that the individual flavours can be enjoyed. The first item served may be a little ghee which is po over a small portion of rice and eaten with a pinch of salt. Then come the bitter preparation, sh, followed by lentils or dals, together with roasted or fried vegetables (bhaja or bharta). Next come the vegetable dishes, the lightly spiced vegetables, chenchki, chokka, followed by the most heavily spiced dalna, ghonto and those cooked with fish. Finally the chicken or m, if this being served at all. Chaatni comes to clear the palate together with crisp savoury wafers, papor. Dessert is ly sweet yogurt (mishti doi). The meal is finally concl with the handing out of betel leaf (paan), which is considered to be an aid to digestion and an astringent. Traditionally the people here eat seated on the floor, where individual pieces of carpet, called asans, are spread for each person to sit on and the meal is served on a large gun-metal or silver plate (thala) and the various items of food are placed in bowls (batis) around the top of the thala, rg from right to left. Rice is mo and placed on the middle of the thala, with a little salt, chilies and lime placed on the  right hand corner. They eat with the fingers of the right hand and strict etiq is observed with regard to this.\nThe typical Bengali fare incl a certain seq of food\u2014somewhat like the co of Western dining.  Two seqs are commonly followed, one for ceremonial dinners such as a wedding and the day-to-day seq. Both seqs have regional variations, and sometimes there are significant differences in a partic co between West Bengal and Bangladesh.\n\nAt home, Bengalis traditionally ate without silverware: ka\u0163a (forks), chamoch (spoons), and chhuri (knives) grad finding use on Bengali tables in  areas. Most Bengalis eat with their right hand, mashing small portions of meat and vegetable dishes with rice and in some cases, lentils. In r areas, Bengalis traditionally eat, sitting on the floor with a large banana or plantain leaf serving as the plate or plates made from Sal tree leaves sown together and dried.\n\nThe elaborate dining habits of the Bengalis were a reflection of the attention the Bengali hofe paid to the kitchen. In modern times, thanks to Western infl, this is rarely followed any more. Co are freqy skipped or combined with everyday meals. Meals were ly served co by co to the diners by the yot hoves, but increasing infl of nr families and isation has replaced this. It is now common to place everything on platters in the centre of the table, and each diner serves him/herself. Ceremonial occasions such as weddings  to have elaborate serving rit, but professional catering and b-style dining is now commonplace. The traditions are far from dead, though; large family occasions and the more lavish ceremonial feasts still make sure that these rit are observed.\n\n\nThe foods of a daily meal are ly simpler, geared to balanced nion and makes extensive use of vegetables. The co progress broadly from lighter to richer and heavier and goes through various tastes and taste cleansers. Rice remains common throt the meal and is the main constit of the meal,  the cha\u0163ni (ch) co.\n\n\nFile:Vegetables C - Kolkata 2011-02-24 1725.JPG|thil|left\nThe starting co is made from bitter vegetables or herbs, often deep fried in oil or steamed with c potatoes. Portions are ly tiny\u2014a spoonful or so to be had with rice\u2014and this co is considered to be both a palate-cleanser and of great medicinal value. The ingredients  for this co change seasonally, but commonly  ones are k\xf4rola  or  (forms of bitter gourd) which are available nearly all year round, or tender neem leaves in spring.\n\nA thick soupy mixture of vegetables in a ginger-md sauce called Sh in West Bengal ly follows the bitter starting co, but sometimes replaces it as a starter altogether. Eaten in much bigger portions, Sh is ly eaten in s. It is a complex dish, feat a fine balance of many different tastes and text and is often a critical measure of a Bengali cooks abilities in the kitchen.\n\n\nThe first co is then followed by shak (leaf vegetabless) such as spinach, palong chard, methi fenk, or amaranth. The shak can be steamed or cooked in oil with other vegetables such as begun (aine). Steamed shak is sometimes accompanied by a pt paste of fermented md seeds, spices and sometimes dried mangoes, dried Indian plum and olives which is called Kash.\n\n\nFile:L&al.jpg|thumb|right|240px\nThe dal|\u0111al co is ly the most sntial co, especially in West Bengal. It is eaten with a generous portion of rice and a n of accompaniments. Common accompaniments to \u0111al are aaloo bhaate (potatoes mashed with rice), and bhaja (stir fried). Bhaja literally means fried; most vegetables are good candidates but begun (aines), k (pns), or alu (potatoes) like French fries, or shredded and fried, , potol pointed gourd are common. Machh bhaja (fried fish) is also common, especially rui (rohu) and ilish (hilsa) fishes. Bhaja is sometimes coated in a Gram flour (chickpea flour) and posto (poppyseed) batter. A close co of bhaja is b\xf4ra or deep-fried savoury balls ly made from poshto (poppyseed) paste or coconut mince. Another variant is fried pointed gourd as potoler dorma with roe (egg)/prawn.\n\nAnother accompaniment is a vegetable preparation ly made of mle vegetables stewed slowly together without any added water. Labra, chorchori, ghonto, or chanchra are all traditional #glossary.  There also are a host of other preparations that do not come  any of these categories and are simply called t\xf4rkari\u2014the word merely means vegetable in Bengali. Sometimes these preparations may have spare pieces of fish such as bits of the head or gills, or spare portions of meat. A charchari is a vegetable dish that is cooked without stirring, just to the point of charring.\n\nPickles such as raw mangoes pickled in md oil and spices or sweet and tangy tamarind picckles and lemon pickle are also served with the dal co. A variety of pickles are a permanent fixture of Bengali meal.\n\n\nFile:Deep-fried Carp - Kolkata 2011-02-17 1411.JPG|thil\n\nThe next co is the fish co. Generally there is one fish co a day, because Bengalis tend to eat fish and generally derive the necessary protein intake from fish and dal. Meat was generally a once-a-week affair  the 1990s, but now with changing ce, meat is served more often in the hold. Generally the most common fish dish is the Jhol, where a thin jus of fish is made with ginger, tic, chili and c (the basic group of spices), and fish and sometimes potato or other vegetable.\n\nBengalis fame in cooking fish, both dried fish called "Sh" (more present in East Bengali holds) as well as fresh fish. Prawn or shrimp is often considered to be a kind of fish, and crabs are also a favo of the Bengalis. Apart from it, m and chicken feature largely in the non-vegetarian menu, while the vegetarian menu contains homemade paneer, gram flour "dhoka" (a co to the gatta of the Marwari/Gi food group).\n\nGenerally one or two pieces of fish or meat are served d l, with rice, to balance out the meal.\n\n\nThen comes the meat co. This co may be eaten occasionally for 2 reasons: the Hindu principle of ahimsa, which is observed throt the region, and cost, as meat is very costly. The divide among the Bengalis of Bangladesh and West Bengal is most evident when it comes to the meat co. Meat is readily cons in  parts of Bangladesh and some consider it the meals main co. Beef is mainly cons in some of the feasts and banq in major cities like Dhaka and Chittagong. Because the conson of beef is prohibited among Bengali Hindu commes, Khashi Goat#Meat is traditionally the meat of choice in West Bengal, but m Chicken (food) and \u0111im egg (food) are also commonly cons. At the time of Partition, it was rare for caste Hindus to eat chicken or even eggs from hens, choosing rather duck eggs if eggs were to be cons. Although it is debatable as to whether chicken is more pop than khashi in West Bengal today, the proliferation of po farms and hatcheries makes chicken the cheaper alternative.\n\n\nFile:Unripe Mango Ch - Kolkata 2011-02-23 1714.JPG|thumb|right|250px\nNext comes the ch co, which is typically tangy and sweet; the ch is ly made of am mangoes, tomatoes, anar\xf4sh pineapple, tetul tamarind, pepe papaya, or just a combination of fr and dry fr called mixed fruit ch served in biye badi (marriage). The ch is also the move towards the sweeter part of the meal and acts also as a palate cleanser, similar to the practice of serving sorbet in some Western ces.\n\nPapo\u0157 (papadum), a type of wafer, thin and flaky, is often made of dal|\u0111al or potatoes or shagu (sago) and is a  accompaniment to the chs.\n\n\nFile:Mishti Doi.jpg|thil|left\n\nThe last item before the sweets is Doi or yogurt. It is generally of two varieties, either nat flavour and taste or Mishti Doi \u2013 sweet yogurt, typically sweetened with charred s. This brings about a brown colour and a distinct flavour. Like the fish or sweets mishti doi is typically identified with Bengali ce.\n\nIn a daily meal it is likely that some of the co might get missed, for instance the Shak, the additional co, Ch and Papor. In some cases, the dessert might be missed as well. The co overall are the same at home or at a social fon (e.g. marriage feast). Rice, which is the staple across the meal gets replaced by l or l st with dal or mashed green peas. The replacement is a relatively recent phenomenon and has been seen in practice only from about the early 20th century.\n\n==Mish\u0163i (sweets)==\nSweets occupy an important place in the diet of Bengalis and at their social ceremonies. It is an ancient c among both Hindu and M Bengalis to distribute sweets d festivities. The confectionery ind has floed because of its close association with social and religious ceremonies. Competition and changing tastes have helped to create many new sweets, and today this ind has grown within the co as well as across the world.\n\nThe sweets of Bengal are generally made of sweetened cottage cheese (chhena), e the use of khoa (red solidified milk) in Northern India. Flours of different cereals and p (legume)s are  as well.\nSome important sweets of Bengal are:\n\n===Sh\xf4ndesh===\nFile:Sondeshnolen.jpg|thil|left\nMade from sweetened, finely ground fresh paneer, sh\xf4ndesh in all its variants is among the most pop Bengali sweets. The basic sh\xf4ndesh has been considerably enhanced by the many famous confectioners of Bengal, and now several hd different varieties exist, from the simple kachagolla to the complicated abar khabo, j\xf4lbh\xf4ra or indrani. Another variant is the k\xf4rapak or hard mixture, which blends rice flour with the paneer to form a shell-like dough that lasts much longer.\n\n\nFile:Rasag.jpg|thil\nRossogolla|R\xf4shogolla/Rossogolla, a Bengali traditional sweet, is one of the most widely cons sweets in India which originated in Odisha cent ago as offerings made at the temple of Lord http://www.jagannathtemplepuri.com/ Jagannath at Puri as a part of a ritual known as Bachanika, d "List of festivals observed at Jagannatha Temple, Puri". It spread to Bengal in 1868.  Channa based sweets were introd in Eastern India from about the 18th century; as the process and technology involved in synthesizing "Chhana" was introd to the Indians by the D in the 1790s. The cottage cheese "schmierkase" was also known as D cheese. The earlier versions of Rossogolla  lacked binding capacity of the modern avatar that is well known and highly acclaimed today. This was due to the fact that the know-how involved in synthesizing such a sweet was wn before being experimentally developed by Nobin Chandra Das and then constantly improved and fr standardized by his ssors. Frmore, one must clearly stand that the "chhana" man in those days was a coarse and gran variety and had low binding capacity. It was made by Citric acid and ascorbic acid from nat fruit extracts.This type of "chhana" cannot be worked on to compact into any reg and firm shape for the pe of sweet-making, leave alone making Rossogolla. This is because of a doced technological issue - lactic acid (extracted from whey)  to c milk now was introd to India in the late 18th century by D and Porte colonists (along with acetic acid) - and it is this method that creates the fine, smooth modern "chhana" with high binding capacity - which is now the staple raw material for Bengali people Confectionery. At present, Nobin Chandra Das is referred to have invented the spongy variant of rossogolla\n\n\nFile:BD Porabarir Chamcham.JPG|thumb|240px|right\nLaddu is a very common sweet in West Bengal and Bangladesh, especially d celebrations and festivities.\n\n\nFile:Ras Malai.JPG|thil|left\nRas malai is composed of white, cream, or yellow clo balls of paneer which are dipped and soaked in s and malai or cottage cheese. This dessert resembles the rasg greatly. Though it is not a primarily Bengali sweet and originated from other places, Ras Malai is still very pop.Comilla is famous for its Roshmalai.\n\n\nFile:Pantua - Kolkata 2011-09-20 5431.JPG|thil|left\nPantua is somewhat similar to the r\xf4shogolla, except that the cottage cheese balls are fried in either ghee (clarified b) or oil  golden or deep brown before being put in syrup. There are similar tasting, but differently shaped versions of the Pantua e.g. Langcha (cylindrical) or Ledikeni. Interestingly, the latter was created in honour of Charlotte Canning, Cos Canning (wife of the then Governor General to India Charles Canning) by Bhim Nag, a sweet maker in Kolkata.\n\nPantua is similar to g jamun, and could be called a Bengali variant of that dish.\n\n===Ch\xf4mch\xf4m===\nCham cham|Ch\xf4mch\xf4m, (\u099a\u09ae\u099a\u09ae) (originally from Porabari, Tangail District in Bangladesh) goes back about 150 years. The modern version of this oval-shaped sweet is reddish brown in colour and has a denser texture than the r\xf4shogolla. It can also be preserved longer. Gran of maoa or dried milk can also be sprinkled over it.\n\n===Pi\u0163ha or pithe===\nFile:Pitha for Wedding- Pakan, Patishapta, Bharandash.jpg|thumb|200px|right\nFile:Bhapa Pitha Bangladeshi Style, 3 Febr, 2013.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Bhapa Pitha, often sweetened with molasses, is a pop Bangladeshi style rice cake.\nIn both Bangladesh and West Bengal, the tradition of making different kinds of pan-fried, steamed or boiled sweets, lovingly known as pi\u0163he or the "pitha", still floes. These symbolise the coming of winter, and the arrival of a season where rich food can be incl in the otherwise mild diet of the Bengalis. The richness lies in the creamy silkiness of the milk which is mixed often with molasses, or jaggery made of either date palm or sane, and sometimes s. They are mostly divided into different categories based on the way they are created. Generally rice flour goes into making the pithe.\n\nThey are ly fried or steamed; the most common forms of these cakes include bhapa pi\u0163ha (steamed), pakan pi\u0163ha (fried), and puli pi\u0163ha (dngs), among others. The other common pithas are chandrapuli, gokul, pati shapta, chitai pi\u0163ha, aski pithe, m puli and  dudh puli.\n\nThe Pati Shapta variety is basically a thin-layered rice-flour crepes with a milk-cd creme-filling, similar to the hoppers or appams of South India, or the French crepes. In  areas of Bangladesh and West Bengal most ho hold Pitha-festivals sometime d the winter months. The celebration of the Pi\u0163ha as a traditional sweet is the time for the Winter Harvest festival in r Bangladesh and West Bengal. The harvest is known as Nobanno \u2013 (literally new sance) and calls for not only rare les celebrating food and sweets but also other pop and festive cal activities like P Dramas at night and Open Air Dance Performances.\n\n\nSeveral varieties of yogurts such as mish\u0163i doi, cds, and rice pg (khir or firni) are also pop in West Bengal.\n\nSh\xf4ndesh, chhanar jilapi, kalo jam, darbesh, raghobshai, payesh,ba ,naleng sh\xf4ndesh, shor bhaja, langcha and a variety are examples of sweets in Bengali ce.\n\nFile:Bengali Sweets.svg|thumb\n\n\n\n===Mu\u0157i===\nMu\u0157i (p rice) is made by heating sand in a pot, and then throwing in grains of rice. The rice may have been washed i brine to provide seasoning. The rice p up and is separated from the sand by a strainer. Mu\u0157i is very pop and is  in a wide variety of sec and religious occasions, or even just cons plain. Muri is also often  as a replacement for or in combination with reg rice.\n\nA variant of mu\u0157i is khoi, which is popped rice. Both varieties are  to make many different snack foods.\n\n===Jhal-Mu\u0157i===\nOne of the most pop and iconic snack foods of Bengal, jhal literally means hot or spicy. Jhal-mu\u0157i is p rice with spices, vegetables and raw md oil. Depending on what is added, there are many kinds of jhal-mu\u0157i but the most common is a bh\xf4rta made of chopped shallot, jira roasted ground c, bitnoon black salt l\xf4ngka / morich chilis (either kacha ripe or sh dried), md oil, dhone pata (fresh coriander leaves)\nand m.\n\n\nA moa is made by taking muri with jaggery as a binder and forming it into a ball, made all over Bengal. Another pop kind of moa is Joynagarer moa, a moya particy made in Jaynagar Mazilpur, South 24 Parganas district, West Bengal which  khoi and nolen gur as binder. Nolen gur is fresh jaggery made from the sap of date palm. Moas are made specially d winter.\n\n\nChide Bhaja is made up of Flattened rice fried in sand and then strained in metal strainers, not tea strainer.\nIt is mostly cons with fried peanuts, jhuri-bhaja and fried c leaves .\n\n\nThough the ce of having several types of Rolls are not atic Bengali ce but it has a partial Awadhi touch made in Bengali style.Us common within office goers,st. Predominantly nonveg, it is prepared by lacha paratha wrapped with egg or st with chicken,chicken tikka,m keema and so on,sometimes with paneer and onion on demand.This is good\n\n\n\nKochuri has its advent from the time immemorial. It is p st in Puri or L and paired with Alur dam or Cholar Dal is always very famous within Bengalis.\n\n\nAlso known as Golgappa within North India, Kolkata Ph has its own flavour and taste.\nIt is a very good appetizer where each small golgappa is st with potato smash and tamarind.\nUsage of Bhaja Masala or Fried spices powder and chilli makes it goes mouth watering.\n\n\n<!--Are we aised to have this content? If so  what terms and conditions does the following material come ? Is there any copyright? Should the name S Ray be mentioned or should the entire para be removed?-->\n<div id="glossary"></div>\n* Ambal: A sour dish made either with several vegetables or with fish, the sos being prod by the addition of tamarind pulp or lime j.\n* Biryani: Fragrant dish of long-grained aromatic rice combined with beef, m, or chicken and a mixture of characteristic spices. Sometimes cooked in sealed containers (dum biriyani).\n* Bhaja or Bhaji: Anything fried, either by itself or in batter.\n* Bhapa: Fish or vegetables steamed with oil and spices. A classic steaming technique is to wrap the fish in banana leaf to give it a faint m, smoky scent.\n* Bhate: (steamed with rice) any vegetable, such as potatoes, beans, pns, or even dal, first boiled whole and then mashed and seasoned with md oil or ghee and spices. Traditionally the vegetables were placed on top of the rice; they steamed as the rice was being boiled.\n* Bhuna: A term of Urdu origin, and applies to meat cooked in spices for a long time without water. The spices are slow-cooked in oil (bh). The spices first absorb the oil, and when f cooked release the oil again.\n* Bora: See Kofta\n* Chochchori: Us a vegetable dish with one or more varieties of vegetables cut into longish strips, sometimes with the stalks of leafy greens added, all lightly seasoned with spices like md or poppy seeds and flavo with a phoron. The skin and bone of large fish like bhetki (Red snapper (fish)) or chitol can be made into a chochchori called kata-chochchori, kata, meaning fish-bone.\n* Chhanchra: A combination dish made with different vegetables, portions of fish head and fish oil (entrails).\n* Chechki: Tiny pieces of one or more vegetable\u2014or, sometimes even the peels (of potatoes, lau, pn or Trichosanthes dioica for example)\u2014ly flavo with panch phoron or whole md seeds or black c. Chopped shallot and garlic can also be , but hardly any ground spices.\n* Dalna: Mixed vegetables or eggs, cooked in medium thick gravy seasoned with ground spices, especially garom mashla and a touch of ghee.\n* Dam or Dum: Vegetables (especially potatoes), meat or rice (biriyanis) cooked slowly in a sealed pot over a low heat.\n* Dolma or Patoler Dolma: The name is coming from T, but the food is different. The vegetable Potol is st either with a combination of grated coconut, chickpeas, etc. or more commonly with fish and then fried. The fish is boiled with tic and salt, then bones are removed and then shallot, ginger and gorom moshla are fried in oil and boiled fish is added and ch to prepare the stg.\n* Ghonto: Different complementary vegetables (e.g., cabbage, green peas, potatoes or banana blossom, coconut, chickpeas) are chopped or finely grated and cooked with both a phoron and ground spices. Dried pellets of dal (boris) are often added to the ghonto. Ghee is commonly added at the end. Non-vegetarian ghontos are also made, with fish or fish heads added to vegetables. The famous muri-ghonto is made with fish heads cooked in a fine variety of rice. Some ghontos are very dry while others a thick and j.\n* Jhal: Literally, hot. A great favo in West Bengali holds, this is made with fish or shrimp or crab, first lightly fried and then cooked in a light sauce of ground red chilli or ground md and a flavo of p\xe3ch-phoron or black c. Being dry, it is often eaten with a little bit of dal po over the rice.\n* Jhol: A light fish or vegetable stew seasoned with ground spices like ginger, c, coriander, chili, and tic with pieces of fish and longitl slices of vegetables floating in it. The gravy is thin yet extremely flavo. Whole green chilis are ly added at the end and green coriander leaves are  to season for extra taste. This term is also  to refer to any type of stew in meat, fish or vegetable dishes.\n* Kalia: A very rich preparation of fish, meat or vegetables  a lot of oil and ghee with a sauce ly based on ground ginger and shallot paste and gorom moshla.\n* Kas or Kash: A pt paste of fermented md seeds, spices and sometimes dried mangoes, dried Indian plum and olives, pop as a dipping sauce in Bengali ce.\n* Khichdi|Khichu\u0157i: Rice mixed with Moong Dal or Lentil(kinds of lentil) and vegetables, and in some cases, boiled or fried eggs. Us cooked with spices and tic powder.\n* Kofta: Ground meat or vegetable croqs bound together by spices or eggs served alone or in savoury gravy.\n* Korma: Another term of Urdu origin (literally braised with onions), meaning meat or chicken cooked in a mild shallot and yogurt sauce with ghee.\n* L: Small round vened bread fried in oil or ghee.\n* Panch phoron: A spice mixture of consisting of five whole seeds  in equal proportions and fried in oil or ghee. The spices can vary, but the mixture ly incl c, fennel or anise, Nigella sativa, fenk, and either wild celery (radhuni) or black md seeds.\n* Paratha|Poro\u0163a: Bread made from wheat flour and fried in the oven  golden-brown.\n* Paturi: Typically fish, seasoned with spices (ly md seed) wrapped in banana leaves and steamed or roasted over a charcoal fire.\n* Polau (See Pilaf): Fragrant dish of rice with ghee, spices and small pieces of vegetables. Long grained aromatic rice is ly , but some aromatic short grained versions such as Kalijira or Gobindobhog may also be .\n* Pora: The word literally means charred. Vegetables are wrapped in banana leaves and roasted over a wood, charcoal or coal fire. Some vegetables with skin such as eggplant, are put directly on the flame or coals. The roasted vegetable is then mixed with shallot, oil and spices.\n* Roti|Ru\u0163i: Unleavened bread made in a Tava and p over an open flame.\n* T\xf4rkari: A general term often  in Bengal the way `c is  in English (it is specd to be one of the origins of c). Originally from Persian, the word first meant ked garden vegetables. From this it was a nat extension to mean cooked vegetables or even fish and vegetables cooked together.\n\n\nThough the beginnings of Hakka Chinese food in India can be traced to innovators like Eau Chew and Pou Chong in the old city, it is in Tangra, a neighborhood 30 kilometers away from Kolkota, that the ce took true shape.\n\nTangra, which means "tannery" in Bengali, was home to Chinese leather factories, which were shut down after the Indo-Sino war in 1962. After India granted asylum to the Dalai Lama in 1959, relations between India and China began to weaken. In 1962, China invaded India through Ladakh in the north, which spiraled into a disastrous war between the two coes. India lost many soldiers to the war, and in response began to imprison the Chinese immigrants in detention camps in Rajasthan. After the war, hostilities between the Indian and Chinese commes began to grow leaving Chinese bsses in Tangra, and restas in the older Dharmatala area, to s.\n\nAfter the animosity ca by the war died down, however, some Chinese moved back and converted the tanneries to restas, and Tangra became the new center of Indian-Chinese ce.\n\n*Bangladeshi ce\n* Chaunk\n* List of Bangladeshi dishes\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\nCategory:Bengali ce', tokenized=[u'bengali', u'ce', u'is', u'a', u'cry', u'style', u'originating', u'in', u'bengal', u'a', u'region', u'in', u'the', u'eastern', u'part',
